    Development and Therapeutic Potential of Selenazo Compounds

    Abstract

    Incorporation of selenium (Se) atom into small molecules can substantially enhance their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimutagenic, antitumoral or chemopreventive, antiviral, antibacterial, antifungal, antiparasitic, and neuroprotective effects. Specifically, selenazo compounds have received great attention owing to their chemical properties, pharmaceutical applications, and low toxicity. In this Perspective, we compile extensive literature evidence with the description and discussion of the most recent advances in different selenazo and selenadiazo motifs as potential pharmacological candidates. We also provide some perspectives on the challenges and future directions in the advancement of these selenazo compounds, each of which could generate drug candidates for various diseases.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The importance of selenium (Se) and its derivatives was recognized soon after the isolation of the element by Berzelius, and this persists to date.(1) Over time, several experimental models have demonstrated that Se is implicated in many physiological processes mainly through selenoproteins, which include at least 25 eukaryotic proteins.(2) The most commonly known are gluthathione peroxidases (GPx), iodothyronine deiodinases, thioredoxin reductases (TrxR), and selenoprotein P. The different GPx are involved in the elimination of free radicals, while the iodothyronine deiodinases enable the activation and deactivation of thyroid hormones. TrxR regenerates thioredoxin (Trx), an important antioxidant protein, and selenoprotein P is involved in the transport of Se throughout the body. In addition, Se supplementation directly or indirectly exerts antioxidant functions, thereby increasing the cellular defense against oxidative stress. Moreover, several reports have demonstrated the role of Se in human health including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimutagenic, antitumoral or chemopreventive, antiviral, antibacterial, antifungal, antiparasitic, and neuroprotective effects.(3) Considering the aforementioned, development of Se compounds is a promising toolkit, which has attracted great interest recently, to achieve potent and selective therapeutic agents.
    Although there are three main categories of Se-containing compounds (inorganic, organic, and selenoproteins) with potential pharmacological properties, the most developed and studied are the organic derivatives.(4) The main reasons are their lower toxicity and comparable or even better bioactivity than inorganic Se compounds.(5) Different organic Se compounds have been reported, and the heterocycles containing Se have received great attention as therapeutic drugs for a plethora of diseases including cancer, diabetes, stroke, Alzheimer, inflammatory processes, etc. Several research and review articles have summarized compounds from different sources and with different mechanisms of action for these pathologies. Specifically, selenazo derivatives have occupied an important position in the field of pharmaceuticals development. Over the past six years, several review papers have appeared comprising mainly of the antioxidant,(6,7) antitumoral,(8,9) or anti-inflammatory(10) effects, among others, of several derivatives of 1,2-selenazoles. However, this Perspective encompasses a much wider variety of selenazo compounds, including selenadiazo scaffolds, and their broad pharmacological activities, merging all of them in a single review paper. Additionally, a summary of the structureâactivity relationships is also presented, which could encourage readership to design novel selenazo compounds as potential multifunctional drugs.
    Albeit several selenazo derivatives have demonstrated potent pharmacological effects over the past decade,(11â14) herein we compile extensive literature evidence, covering the past six years, with the description and discussion of the most recent advances in different selenazo and selenadiazo motifs as potential pharmacological candidates. For didactic purposes, we have classified the compounds according to different structural properties such as the relative position of Se and nitrogen and the number of nitrogen atoms present in the heterocycle. Different biological applications have been considered in each section.

    2. 1,2-Selenazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The most relevant compound related to SeâN containing heterocycles is 2-phenyl-1,2-benzoisoselenazol-3-[2H]one, named ebselen (EBS; I-1 in Figure 1). It was first synthesized in 1924,(15) and in the 1980s it was rediscovered as a potential antioxidant and therapeutic agent.(16â20) It is a multifunctional selenoorganic derivative, with immunomodulatory effects, currently under phase III clinical trials for cerebral ischemia, bipolar disorder, and noise-induced hearing loss.(21) Its multifunctional effects may be due to the fact that EBS can bind with at least 462 targeted proteins in HeLa cells, as identified by biotinylated EBS probe.(22) EBS shows potent antioxidant capacity through the catalysis of several essential reactions for the protection of cellular components from oxidative and free radical damage. It was developed as a GPx mimic reducing hydroperoxides including hydrogen peroxide, phospholipid hydroperoxide, and cholesterol ester hydroperoxide.(23) In addition, EBS affects the Trx system and might cause cell dysfunction via inhibition of this enzyme.(24) All these properties, in addition to its documented safety profile, make EBS a potent and safe bioactive molecule effective in the treatment of various diseases.

    2.1. EBS and Cancer

    Studies by Azad and co-workers(25) have suggested a potential role for EBS in cancer prevention by inhibiting tumor necrosis factor Î± (TNF-Î±)-mediated nuclear factor ÎºB (NF-ÎºB) activity, sensitizing tumor cells to undergo apoptosis, ameliorating the progression of microvasculopathy, and partially restoring angiogenesis. It is remarkable that, based on its radical-scavenging action and its potential use in oxidative stress conditions, this molecule exerts a potent cytotoxic effect on pancreatic cancer AR42J cells(26) and oxidative stress-induced apoptosis in human multiple myeloma cell lines.(27) On the other hand, EBS can act through other emergent targets such as quiescin sulfhydryl oxidase 1 (QSOX1), an excellent biomarker in cancer since it is overexpressed in diverse tumor types such as pancreatic, breast, lung, and prostate cancers and plays a role in cancer progression and metastasis.(28) Likewise, combination of EBS with radiotherapy shows major antitumor efficiency provoking apoptosis and inhibiting cancer cell progression, including the regulation of gene and protein expression along with the modulation of pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines in a breast cancer model.(29) In view of these facts, many researchers have modified and incorporated this privileged scaffold into new molecules in order to identify novel drug candidates for the treatment of cancer. These efforts led to the discovery of ethaselen (BBSKE; I-2 in Figure 1), a potent cancer cell growth inhibitor targeting TrxR1, an enzyme implicated in carcinogenesis and cancer progression. These observations have been confirmed in different tumor cell lines including HeLa (human cervical cancer), BGC823 (human stomach adenocarcinoma), HL60 and K562 (human leukemia), A549 (human lung cancer), LoVo (human colon cancer), Bel-7402 (human epithelial hepatoma), Tca8113 (human tongue cancer), and KB (human nasopharyngeal epidermal carcinoma) cells, as well as in a human non-small-cell lung cancer xenograft mouse model.(30) Moreover, combination of BBSKE with sodium selenite in non-small-cell lung cancer cells(31) or with sunitinib(32) in colorectal cancer showed synergistic effects, resulting in a promising new strategy for cancer therapy. In addition, this derivative is able to reverse cisplatin resistance in drug-resistant K562 cells.(33) Recently, Zheng et al.(34) have reported that BBSKE could inhibit migration and invasion in human breast cancer MCF-7 cells and colorectal cancer LoVo cells. In addition, BBSKE not only leads to primary tumor regression but also significantly reduces metastasis in lung and liver in a mouse breast cancer 4T1 model. The underlying mechanisms may include the markedly elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS) level caused by TrxR inhibition, which results in disruption of a sophisticated network comprising epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), epithelialâmesenchymal transition (EMT), CD44, matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9), and vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2).
    Taking into account the above-mentioned and inspired by these structures, many research groups have developed new series of compounds related to EBS and BBSKE in order to discover more effective agents and to explore new mechanisms of action. Among the different approaches proposed, hybridization (combination in a single chemical entity of two structures with different pharmacophoric features) is one of the most used approaches. Thus, Yan et al.(35) reported new compounds (I-3 in Figure 1) designed by combining chemical structures of resveratrol and EBS. All the hybrid compounds exhibited potential antiproliferative activities against four human cancer cell lines (Bel-7402, A549, HeLa, and MCF-7). It is noticeable that the inclusion of two methoxide groups in the resveratrol moiety resulted in an increase in the level of apoptosis and the G2/M cell cycle arrest and also exhibited the best TrxR inhibitory activity. On the other hand, the incorporation of other versatile bioactive nucleus such as 1,2,4-triazole (I-4 in Figure 1)(36) or 1,3,4-thiadiazole (I-5 in Figure 1)(37,38) reinforced the idea that the nature of the functional groups on the triazole or thiadiazole rings is determinant for the antiproliferative activity and selectivity. For example, among the triazole compounds, the aliphatic chains were the most active against SMMC-7721 cells while in the thiadiazoles, the substituent groups over the phenyl ring were of vital importance for modulating the antitumor activity. It is well-known that chirality can influence the pharmacological activity of the compounds. Thus, Pacula et al.(39) described the synthesis of new analogs of EBS with a chiral terpene scaffold (I-6 in Figure 1) or with several chiral amino acidic methyl esters (I-7 in Figure 1). The determination of the anticancer and antioxidant activities showed that the highest antiproliferative activity was observed for N-leucinemethyl ester, while the other chiral compounds showed poor activity.
    Other structural modifications include the introduction of small functional groups to evaluate the impact in the biological profile. So the generation of ebselenols with an OH group in the benzisoselenazolone ring (I-8 in Figure 1) improved the GPx activity and exerted a scavenging effect on ROS and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) species produced by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA)-induced human mononuclear cells (MNC).(40) Besides, the dimerization of EBS through azo core in order to obtain azo-bis-EBSs (I-9 in Figure 1) has been explored. In general, this modification accomplished poor synthetic GPx mimics with no toxic effects.(41)
    Related to alternative mechanisms of action, the overexpression of different isoforms of histone deacetylases (HDACs) has been found in several types of cancer cells and in neurological and inflammatory pathologies. For these reasons, HDAC inhibitors have been aggressively pursued as antineoplastic drugs. Wang et al.(42) have published a study with a collection of EBS and its analogs including the EBS oxide (I-10 in Figure 1) and different ebsulfur derivatives (I-11 in Figure 1). EBS was identified as HDAC5, HDAC6, HDAC8, and HDAC9 inhibitor with IC50 values of 3.4, 6.9, 1.2, and 3.7 Î¼M, respectively. In 2018, Tang and co-workers(43) published a paper related to the importance of the glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) biosynthesis dysfunctions in many pathological conditions, including tumor progression. On the basis of these observations, they developed novel Î²-d-xylosides by conjugating EBS and xylose (I-12 in Figure 1) in order to understand the role of the aglycone and primed GAGs in contributing to Î²-d-xyloside-dependent cytotoxicity in cancer cells. They concluded that only EBS-Î²-d-xyloside showed significant cytotoxicity with IC50 ranging from 6.4 to 7.3 Î¼M in four human cancer cell lines. Recently, Bartolini et al.(44,45) have proposed the glutathione S-transferase P (GSTP) as a new target for EBS and related compounds. This enzymatic system is implicated in both the prevention and therapy of drug resistant cancers. EBS has shown interaction with one of the isoenzymes, GSTP1, which plays a prominent role in the anticancer and redox modulation. Finally, the potential of some EBS derivatives as radiation mitigators must be considered. [[2-[4-(3-Oxo-1,2-benzoselenazol-2-yl)phenyl]acetyl]amino]ethyltriphenylphosphonium chloride (MitoEBS-2; I-13 in Figure 1) is effective in reducing lipid hydroperoxides, preventing apoptotic cell death and increasing the survival when administered 24 h postradiation.(46) Additionally, benzisoselenazolones obtained by introducing isothiourea, tetramethylthiourea, and heterocyclic groups into the C-ring of EBS (I-14 in Figure 1) exhibited more potent antitumor activity in EBC-1 cells than EBS. Additionally, these derivatives have shown inhibition of autophosphorylation of mesenchymal epithelial transition factor (c-MET).(47)
    In the case of BBSKE, some of the structural modifications have addressed its poor solubility. In 2016, Ye et al.(48) designed and synthesized a new series of analogs by combining BBSKE and carmustine, a DNA-cross-link agent, resulting in deactivators of TrxR with high toxicity and low selectivity. The resultant 1-(2-chloroethyl)-1-nitroso-3-(2-(3-oxobenzoelenazol-2(3H)-yl)ethyl) ureas (I-15 in Figure 1) showed good solubility, low toxicity, and excellent antitumor activity. In addition, other minor modulations have been introduced such as the inclusion of alkyl chain of three carbon atoms. It was observed that this derivative (I-16 in Figure 1) inhibited glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), an enzyme implicated in cancer disease, and presented higher anticancer activity.(49)

    2.2. EBS and Neurodegenerative Diseases

    Brain disorders with a vascular and/or neurodegenerative component affect one billion people worldwide, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Among them, Alzheimerâs disease (AD) ranks first affecting 45â60% of the population followed by Parkinsonâs disease (PD) affecting 2% of population.(50)
    Considering the antioxidant properties of EBS (I-1 in Figure 1), several studies have shown that this derivative has neuroprotective effects in damaged tissues after the interruption of blood flow(51) as well as may improve or at least preserve cognitive function in AD and other forms of dementia.(52) These facts have been corroborated by Xie and co-workers(53) using both AD model cells and mice. They demonstrated that EBS was able to improve cognitive impairment, reduce the level of amyloid Î² (AÎ²), and inhibit tau hyperphosphorylation. In addition, EBS suppressed ROS-mediated activation of p38 kinase, which subsequently reduced tau phosphorylation and Î²-secretase 1 (BACE1) levels and AÎ² generation.
    This accumulated evidence has promoted the development of new derivatives of EBS by fusion/combination with other structures with recognized efficacy in AD treatment. Luo et al.(54) described a new multitarget compound named âselenpezilâ (II-17 in Figure 2), formed by the union of EBS and donepezil, a well-known acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used for AD treatment. Selenpezil showed potent acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) inhibition with no acute toxicity. These authors(55) further carried out new modifications in the parent compound, âselenpezilâ by replacing the benzylpiperidine group in donepezil by several nitrogen heterocyclic rings (II-18 in Figure 2). The results indicated that the presence of piperidine ring is crucial for the activity.
    Other series of compounds have been designed and synthesized by hybridization between EBS and other described AChE inhibitors. Among these hybrid molecules tacrine-EBS analogs were potent inhibitors of AChE and BuChE. One of the derivatives having two methoxy groups in the EBS moiety and five carbons in the alkyl chain (II-19 in Figure 2) exhibited superior activity and a better balance of AChE and BuChE activities than tacrine.(56) Moreover, using rational computer assisted design, Wang et al.(57) fused the pharmacophores of quinolin and EBS into new molecules to obtain âselenoxy-chinolinsâ. One of them, with a hydroxyl group in the EBS moiety (II-20 in Figure 2), was able to penetrate the central nervous system (CNS) without exhibiting acute toxicity and presented an effective interaction with AÎ². Later, the authors modulated these compounds and developed a series of 8-hydroxyquinoline derivatives substituted with benzo[d][1,2]selenazol-3(2H)-one at the 2-position. The resulting novel compounds (II-21 in Figure 2) provided a significant inhibition ability of the Cu(II)-induced AÎ² aggregation of clioquinol and the scavenging peroxide ability of EBS.(58) In addition, other targets such as HDACs have attracted much attention for their use as potential targets for the treatment of AD, mainly the isoforms HDAC2 and HDAC6 both being overexpressed in the cortex and hippocampus of AD patients. Considering this, Hu et al. hypothesized that the fusion of two key features from EBS and the hydroxamic moiety, specific for HDAC pharmacophore, through different structural arrangements, could result in a new class of compounds (II-22 in Figure 2) for AD treatment. The results confirmed their hypothesis showing some of the compounds to exhibit better free oxygen radical scavenging ability than EBS, significant protective effects against damage induced by H2O2, and significant preventive effects against ROS accumulation.(59)
    Compared to AD, there are limited reports of application of selenazoles in PD. Only Tio et al.(60) have reported a study in a transgenic drosophila showing that EBS may be a useful neuroprotective drug for carriers of coiled-coil-helix-coiled-coil-helix domain containing 2 (CHCHD2), which is related with late-onset Parkinson disease.
    Finally, EBS has been used in mental illness. EBS inhibits the inositol monophosphatase (IMPase) following a mechanism similar to lithium. In addition, EBS also inhibited the 5-HT2A receptor function reducing impulsivity in rat models of impulsive behavior(61â64) such as neuroprotective agent in depression or schizophrenia and bipolar disorder(65) or as suicidality prevention.(66) In addition, EBS has been explored as neuroprotective agent in rat spinal cord injury with limited effect.(67)

    2.3. EBS and Cardiovascular Diseases

    It is well established that oxidative stress, particularly lipid peroxidation, could be the principal mechanism in the pathogenesis of myocardial injuries which would lead to death, and for this cause EBS has been explored to have potential applications in heart ischemic injuries.(68) It acts by attenuating ischemiaâreperfusion induced cardiomyocyte apoptosis seemingly by increasing the expression of Bcl-2, decreasing the expression of caspase-3 and -8, Bax, and poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP), and enhancing the expression and function of antioxidant enzymes.(69) It can be used as an adjuvant to diminish the oxidative stress during cardiopulmonary bypass and hypothermia.(70)
    Additionally, EBS has a special relevance as a promising cardioprotective agent against cardiotoxicity induced by doxorubicin (DOX) and daunorubicin, the two anthracyclines used in cancer therapy.(71) Endothelial dysfunction in uremia may be induced by accumulation of ROS, and deficient levels of glutathione peroxidase-3 (GPx3) may cause the development of kidney disease-induced cardiac risk. Thus, the potentiation of the antioxidant pathways by using GPx mimetic EBS can be an effective strategy to reduce the cardiovascular risk.(72,73) Recently, Haas et al.(74) have reported that EBS can reduce the levels of proinflamatory cytokines secretion such as interleukin-1Î² (IL-1Î²), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and interleukin-8 (IL-8) in cells maintained in different high dextrose concentrations acting as human coronary artery endothelial protector.

    2.4. EBS and Diabetes

    There exists a great controversy between the associations of high levels of dietary or serum Se levels and prevalent type 2 diabetes.(75) Some authors concluded that high levels of Se are associated with the presence of this illness,(76) while others considered that circulatory Se concentration is essential for insulin regulation and energy metabolism.(77) A study, published in 2013, refers that EBS ameliorated the hyperglycemia and lowered the glycosylated hemoglobin, prevented the oxidative stress and the nucleocytoplasmic dislocation of pancreatic and duodenal homeobox 1 (Pdx-1) and v-maf musculoaponeurotic fibrosarcoma oncogene homolog A (MafA) in Î²-cells, and also Î²-cell apoptosis associated with hyperglycemia.(78) In addition, two new EBS-analogs named m-hydroxy- (III-23 in Figure 3) and ethanol-EBS (III-24 in Figure 3) were designed as antidiabetic agents. Although the m-hydroxy EBS decreased end-points of two often linked diabetic complications in vitro, it did not augment the attenuation of diabetes associated atherosclerosis and renal injury in an in vivo model.(79) EBS did not improve the oxidative stress profile or conduit and arteriolar vascular function.(80)

    2.5. EBS and Miscellaneous Diseases

    In the addition to the above, EBS and its derivatives could potentially have application in several other diseases. For example, EBS has been implicated as antibacterial agent. Despite growing research, multidrug-resistant bacteria have increased in frequency resulting in significant patient morbidity and mortality. Further, new and recurrent bacterial infections continue to impose significant challenges on global health care. EBS showed activity against several Gram-positive bacteria, such as Clostridium difficile infection by inhibiting the release of the toxic glucosyltransferase domain.(81) Another disease with high associated mortality where EBS may find use is anthrax. It has been described that EBS and its analogs (IV-25 in Figure 4) could be classified as a novel class of antibiotics for treating B. anthracis acting through TrxR inhibition. Moreover, these molecules exhibited low minimal inhibitory concentration values against B. subtilis, B. cereus, S. aureus, and M. tuberculosis with a pronounced bactericidal mode of action.(82) Thanna et al.(83) described a library of EBS derivatives with potential inhibition of M. tuberculosis growth and M. tuberculosis antigen 85C (Ag85C) activity. The derivative with an allyl chain substituent (IV-26 in Figure 4) was identified as the most promising as antitubercular agent. As a go in depth in Ag85 as target, a study with the 85 C enzyme cocrystallized with different p-amino- (IV-27 in Figure 4), azido- (IV-28 in Figure 4), and adamantyl-EBS (IV-29 in Figure 4) derivatives was carried out by Goins and co-workers.(84) The obtained results confirmed the importance of the structural modifications and their effects on the covalent bond on Cys209 residue and represented a guiding principle for developing new more specific and potent Ag85 inhibitors.
    EBS, due to its antiurease activity as well as the ability to inhibit H+/K+-ATPase proton pumps,(85) may also emerge as relevant drug for treating infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, e.g., the one caused by ureolitic Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) which is resistant to antibiotics. Xu et al.(86) investigated the effect of EBS on the GPx-ROS pathways and IL-8 expression induced by H. pylori in gastric cancer cells. The results suggested that EBS may inhibit ROS production triggered by H. pylori. The formulation as salts for some EBS derivatives (IV-30 in Figure 4) displayed significant actions against Gram-negative pathogens due to an alteration of intracellular levels of glutathione and cysteine thiols of proteins in the bacterial cells.(87) In addition, the synergistic antibacterial effect of EBS in combination with silver is described as novel efficient treatment against multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections.(88)
    Moreover, some compounds containing EBS as molecular template, act synergistically with well-known antimicrobials such as some members of carbapenem family against Enterobacteriaceae. A new synthesized derivative, tert-butyl (2-(3-oxobenzo[d][1,2]selenazol-2(3H)-yl)ethyl)carbamate (IV-31 in Figure 4), displayed stronger synergistic activity with meropenem (Mem) than EBS along with better physicochemical properties.(89) On the basis of the promising results described above, some authors have advocated the repurposing of EBS for reducing the bacterial infections, mainly in patients infected with enterococci and exhibiting resistance to vancomycin.(90) Similar proposal has been explored by May et al.(91) based on the impact of EBS on Trx. EBS has shown efficacy against a variety or pathogen organisms (H. pilory, M. tuberculosis, E. coli, S. aureous, C. albicans, K. pneumoniae, A. niger, P. aeruginosa, P. falciparum, ...). As an extension of these studies, EBS and derivatives were tested as potential antifungal and antiparasitic agents. Different mechanisms of action have been proposed. One of them has been the inhibition of the fungal plasma membrane H+-ATPase. This study was carried out in a fluconazole resistant strain of C. albicans, and some of the EBS-analogs (IV-32 and IV-33 in Figure 4) demonstrated inhibitory activity comparable to the reference fluconazole.(92) Another suggested mechanism is the reduction of intracellular glutathione levels, accompanied by increasing ROS and disturbing the redox homeostasis in fungal cells.(93) These facts had been analyzed already with EBS in combination with amphotericin B and voriconazole.(94) In addition, EBS is emerging as a repositionable agent for the treatment of candidiasis and other mycoses.(95) More recently, EBS has been reported as a potent and selective antifungal drug targeting TrxR.(96) Moreover, EBS has shown high effectivity for treating diarrhea caused by Cryptosporidium parvum, one of the main diarrheal pathogens in children. This effect might be attributed to its effects as inhibitor of cryptosporidium parvumglucose-phosphate isomerase as well as other enzymes in the parasite,(97) e.g., some hexokinase in a similar form as Plasmodium falciparum or Tripanosoma brucei.(98) Recently, EBS, in combination with amphotericin B, exhibits synergistic effects inhibiting Trichosporon asahii growth.(99) Finally, EBS and propyl EBS (IV-34 in Figure 4) have been evaluated as amebicidal agents,(100) especially against primary amebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri. Given the vast variety of pathways altered by EBS, efficacy values for each enzyme or protein altered by EBS have been summarized in Table 1 for the sake of clarity.
    Table 1. Efficacy Values on Enzymes and Proteins Amended by EBS
    enzymes/proteinsefficacyrefs
    Cancer
    quiescin sulfhydryl oxidase 1 (QSOX1)IC50 = 5.4 (Î¼M)(28)

    3. 1,3-Selenazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    1,3-Selenazoles have received a great deal of attention due to the wide variety of pharmacological activities reported for these heterocyclic compounds, including antibacterial,(101) antifungical,(102) and antitumoral(103) activities.

    3.1. 1,3-Selenazoles and Infectious Diseases

    Recently, 2,4-disubtituted (V-35 in Figure 5) and tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran-4-yl based (V-36 in Figure 5) selenazoles demonstrated significant bacteriostatic/bactericidal effect against Gram positive bacteria, both pathogenic staphylococci S. aureus and opportunistic bacteria, such as S. epidermis and M. luteus, respectively.(101,102) Tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran-4-yl based selenazoles have also shown very strong fungicidal or fungistatic activity against albicans and non-albicansCandida spp. strains, such as C. parapsilosis, C. sake, C. dubliniensis, C. famata, C. lusitaniae, C. krusei, or C. inconspicua,(102) which may be due to the combined activity of sulfur and Se in these compounds. In addition, these tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran-4-yl based selenazoles demonstrated anticonvulsant and antiepileptic activity.(102) Hydrazinoselenazoles (V-37 in Figure 5) have shown better antibacterial activity than reference compound chloramphenicol on K. pneumonia KP63,(104) and ferrocenyl selenazoles (V-38 in Figure 5) demonstrated excellent activity against E. coli.(105) Interestingly, a nickel(II) complex containing 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylic acid and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) (V-39 in Figure 5) exhibits stronger antimicrobial activities against E. coli, S. epidermidis, S. viridans, A. baumanii than benzylpenicillin sodium.(106)
    Structurally, two main functionalities are being used to decorate 1,3-selenazole core: (i) hydrazine entity with different substituted aromatic and carbo- or heterocycles and (ii) a transition metal element complexing or decorating the selenazo scaffold. On the basis of the reported bioactivity, we consider that this metalloselenazo association presents a great potential for developing novel anti-infectious agents.

    3.2. 1,3-Selenazoles and Cancer

    A number of recent studies have indicated that 1,3-selenazole derivatives possess cytotoxic and/or cytostatic activity against several tumor cell lines. Thus, 1,3-selenazole-containing 1,3,4-thiadiazole derivatives (V-40 in Figure 5) showed potent activity against MCF-7 cells(107) and selenazolopyridine (V-41 in Figure 5) could induce apoptosis in MCF-7 cells by scavenging intracellular ROS.(108) 2,5-Disubstituted 1,3-selenazoles (V-42 in Figure 5) have showed potent inhibition against the tumor-associated transmembrane human carbonic anhydrase IX isoform with effective antitumor activity in human prostate (PC3) and breast (MDA-MB-231) cancer cell lines.(103) Besides, di-n-butyltin(IV) and triphenyltin(IV) derivatives (V-43 in Figure 5) show much greater antitumoral activity in three cancer cell lines (Caco-2, A549, and HCT-116) than cisplatin, the anticancer drug used clinically.(109) Furthermore, some selenazolyl-hydrazones (V-44 in Figure 5) showed comparable or even better antitumoral activity against six human solid tumor cell lines than 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and exhibited excellent antioxidant properties. Surprisingly, p-nitrophenyl-substituted and unsubstituted selenazolyl-hydrazones exhibited monoamine oxidases (MAO) B/A inhibition and MAO B inhibition, respectively, in nanomolar concentration range, which indicates their possible multitargeting properties for the treatment of neurodegenerative disorders.(110) Aryl-hydrazinyl and aryl-hydrazonyl-1,3-selenazoles (V-45 in Figure 5) have shown antiproliferative effects against two leukemia cell lines (CCRF-CEM and HL60).(111)
    Again, the two same structural features described in the previous section, e.g., hydrazine and metalloselenazole, are also present in the 1,3-selenazole derivatives with anticancer activity. Additionally, the conjugation of sulfur and Se atoms seems to also play a role. Thus, these findings reinforce the idea that these hydrazine- and metallo-conjugated 1,3-selenazoles may form a privileged lead skeleton in designing more potent and selective bioactive agents.

    3.3. 1,3-Selenazoles and Miscellaneous Diseases

    Some 2-phenyl-4-methyl-1,3-selenazole-5-carboxylic acids (V-46 in Figure 5) have shown potent xanthine oxidase inhibition, and these appear to be promising candidates for the treatment of hyperuricemia, gout, and other diseases in which xanthine oxidase may be involved.(112) Likewise, some 1,3-selenazole-substituted ritonavir analogs (V-47 in Figure 5) exhibited promising anti-HIV-1 activity.(113) For these reasons, 1,3-selenazoles can be considered as interesting new leading structures in search of new antibacterial, antifungal, antitumoral, antiepileptic, xanthine oxidase inhibiting, and anti-HIV-1 drugs.

    4. 1,2,3-Selenadiazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    These compounds are promising candidates for developing cancer therapeutics. Particularly, benzopyrano-1,2,3-selenadiazole derivatives (VI-48 in Figure 6) were able to improve the hematological parameters of tumor-bearing mice, showing significant antitumoral activity and increasing the life span to a higher extent as compared with 5-FU.(114) The antiproliferative effect of 4,5âdihydrobenzoferroceno[1,2-d][1,2,3]selenadiazole (VI-49 in Figure 6) on ovarian carcinoma cell line was comparable to that produced by cisplatin. Additionally, this ferrocene derivative showed antiproliferative effect against cervical and breast cancer cell lines.(115) Besides, 17-[1â²,2â²,3â²]-selenadiazolylpregnenolone derivatives (VI-50 in Figure 6) showed selective inhibitory activity against prostate and ovarian cancer cells and the cytotoxicity was greater than that of abiraterone (anti-androgen chemotherapeutic drug for prostate cancer).(116) Besides, some of these heterocycles show high antifungal, antibacterial, and antimicrobial activities. Some examples include substituted 1,2,3-selenadiazoles (VI-51, VI-52, and VI-53 in Figure 6), such as carbaldehyde-substituted derivatives (VI-51 in Figure 6) that showed activity against the yeast-like fungi C. albicans.(117) Some of carbocycle-fused mono- and bis-1,2,3-selenadiazoles have shown moderate to good activity and have zone inhibition comparable to that of the standard clotrimazole and ciprofloxacin against C. albicans and against E. coli and S. aureus, respectively. Furthermore, some of these compounds, present high antituberculosis activity.(118)

    5. 1,2,4-Selenadiazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The syntheses of 1,2,4-selenadiazoles are scarce, and only a few reports have appeared in the literature recently.(119,120) Nevertheless, there is a report concerning biological activity of diferrocenyl-1,2,4-selenadiazoles,(105) demonstrating their antibacterial activity against S. aureus, E. coli, and P. aeruginosa.

    6. 1,2,5-Selenadiazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    1,2,5-Selenadiazoles are typically synthesized from 1,2-diamines with Se dioxide (SeO2) as Se source, although other Se reagents have been used (Se chlorides). The interest of scientific community for this Se scaffold is awakening not only in medicinal chemistry but also in diverse technological areas, such as solar cells development and light emitters, due its physical and optical properties. Therefore, many synthetic efforts have been made in order to structurally diversify 1,2,5-selenadiazole moiety. In recent years, this selenated scaffold has found a very promising use as antiproliferative and death promoter of cancerous cells through different pathways. Reports of effective synergetic combination with other therapies such as radiotherapy are constantly appearing in the literature and represent a positive advance against diverse cancers.
    Most of recently reported 1,2,5-selenadiazoles with biological activities are constructed from aryldiamines such as o-phenylenediamine and 3,3â²-diaminobenzidine (DAB) scaffolds. Examples of active benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazoles (VII-54 in Figure 7) with different substitutions on 5-position were reported by He et al.(121) Specifically, 5-nitrobenzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole was found to have the best anticancer activity in HeLa cervical cancer cells, due to the increased lipophilicity, resulting in a higher cellular uptake, which can be monitored due its fluorogenic nature. This compound also enhanced the sensitivity of cancerous cells to X-ray induced apoptosis by inhibition of TrxR, with good results in vitro and in vivo.(121) Related benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole-5-carboxylic acid was conjugated into polyethylenimine (PEI) nanoparticles with RGD (Arg-Gly-Asp) peptide as integrin targeting molecule, achieving good selectivity in human glioma cells and provoking apoptosis by ROS-mediated p53 phosphorylation pathway.(122) Conjugation in mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) improved bloodâbrain barrier (BBB) permeability and cellular uptake in glioma cells, achieving cell death.(123) Furthermore, it inhibited U87 tumor (glioblastoma) spheroids growth in vitro and prolonged blood circulation time.(123) Several alkyl benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole-5-carboxylates were prepared and found to have a moderate activity (the lowest IC50 being 28 Î¼M) in several cancer cell lines.(124) More importantly, it was found that 1,2,5-selenadiazoles bind to bovine serum albumin (BSA) through lipophilic interactions, improving cellular uptake.(124) A collection of N-alkyl- and N-arylbenzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole-5-carboxamides were synthesized and tested in vitro against five human cancer cell lines, leading to the identification of various derivatives with high antiproliferative activities and radical scavenging ability.(125) Amides of 4-methylchacogen-anilines (O, S, and Se) and 2-aminobenzothiazole showed antiproliferative activity toward several cancer cell lines. The compound containing Se presents impressive selectivity toward cancer cells compared to normal cells in mammary and lung, improving at least 15-fold selectivity of EBS and BBSKE in both the cancer cell lines.(125) Related carboxamides with hydrophobic chains exhibited good IC50 values in MCF-7 cancerous cells, obtaining better results when formulated with poloxamine micelles, i.e., dodecyl derivate in T904 cells (IC50 = 0.05 Î¼M, 100-fold improvement with respect to EBS).(126) 6-Alkyl-1H-benzo[d]imidazole-2-yl derivatives, obtained from the corresponding amides, proved effective as cytotoxic compounds against breast cancer cell lines, especially toward triple-negative cell line MDA-MB-231.(127) Mechanism of action involves AKT inhibition and mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) activation by overproduction of ROS.(127)
    1,2,5-Selenadiazole-DAB derivative 4-(benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazol-6-yl)-benzene-1,2-diamine (VIII-55 in Figure 8) was shown to induce apoptosis in SWO-38 glioma cells by AKT dephosphorylation.(128) Derivatization of the previous 1,2-diamine to diaryl quinoxalines (VIII-56 in Figure 8) yielded other 1,2,5-selenadiazolic compounds able to enhance X-ray sensitization on A375 human melanoma and HeLa cells by induction of cell cycle arrest.(129) Chemo- and radio-combined treatment pointed out to a TrxR activity inhibition. Liang et al. developed the synthesis of analogous benzimidazole derivatives through condensation reactions with substituted benzaldehydes, obtaining in most cases mixtures of 5-(2-arylbenzimidazol-6-yl) (VIII-57 in Figure 8) and 5-(2-aryl-N-methylarylbenzimidazol-6-yl)1,2,5-selenadiazoles (VIII-58 in Figure 8).(130) 3,4,5-Trimethoxybenzaldehyde derived 1,2,5-selenadiazoles also disrupted ROS balance of A375 melanoma cells through interaction with TrxR target, in agreement with the finding of TrxR model peptide scission.(130) 2-(p-Methoxyphenyl)benzimidazol-6-yl derivative was found to have better antiproliferative activity than reference drug mitomycin and caused cell death through cell internalization by endocytosis and subsequent ROS-mediated apoptosis.(130) In another study, benzaldehyde derivative was found to improve cellular uptake of DOX in hepatic HepG2 cells under hyperglycemia conditions, representing an opportunity to contest against diabetes-related drug resistance.(131) In line with these results, another related compound, a 2-(p-methoxyphenyl)-N-(p-methoxyphenylmethyl)benzimidazol-6-yl derivative, was found to also improve DOX uptake in breast cancer MCF-7 cell lines.(132) Several of the same library of compounds were tested in antiproliferative assays against bladder cancer cell lines.(123)p-Methylbenzaldehyde derived selenadiazole also showed breast cancer tumor growth inhibition in murine model, due to antiangiogenic effect, as reflected by a greater growth inhibition of endothelial cells HUVEC in Matrigel plug assays.(133) 2-Indol-3-ylbenzimidazol-6-yl derivative was conjugated to a cyclic peptide containing RGD sequence, able to target Î±VÎ²3 integrin.(134) Taking advantage of fluorescent properties of the compound, improved cellular uptake of integrin-overexpressing cancer cells (HepG2) could be confirmed, thus enhancing the effectiveness of radiotherapy in vitro and reproducibility in vivo.(134) 1,2,5-Selenadiazole moiety incorporated in 1,10-phenanthrolines and subsequent iron(II) complexes has been demonstrated to increase antiangiogenic efficiency, compared with nonselenated analog, by potently inducing endothelial cell apoptosis.(135)
    Combretastatin A-4, a tubulin polymerization inhibitor, was subjected to derivatization with 1,2,5-selenadiazole motif with a cis disposition of the two rings (VIII-59 in Figure 8).(136) Antiproliferative assays in several cancerous cell lines showed IC50 values at nanomolar range, and activity was found to be caused by microtubule destabilization. One of these derivatives (G-1103) was also demonstrated to cause cell cycle arrest in G2/M phase and apoptosis in human HeLa and fibrosarcoma cells.(137) A 1,2,5-selenadiazole derived quinolone (VIII-60 in Figure 8) presented good antiproliferative activity in HeLa cells through apoptosis induction, which improved when irradiated with ultraviolet A (UVA) light.(138) The same compound also exhibited high antiproliferative activity in leukemia cells and immunomodulatory effect on murine cell lines.(139)
    In addition to their application in cancer, 1,2,5-selenadiazoles have shown application in other emerging fields, e.g., in semiconducting polymer dots (Pdots) used for fluorescent probes in biology and medicine. Pdots have been derivatized with 1,2,5-selenadiazole motif (IX-61 in Figure 9), achieving an improved sensitivity for ratiometric detection of hypochlorous acid in vivo,(140) an endogenous ROS linked to the progression of many human diseases. 1,2,5-Selenadiazole substructure has also been included in conjugated polymer nanoparticles (NPs) (IX-62 in Figure 9), where switching the chalcogenide atom permits the adjustment in NP photoacoustic properties, which enables in vivo brain vasculature imaging.(141)
    A summary of the efficacy against a wide variety of diseases and related mechanism of actions of various selenazo compounds is outlined in Tables 2 and 3.

    7. Summary and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Incorporation of Se atom into small molecules is a recent toolkit used by medicinal chemists to yield potent and selective compounds mainly for cancer treatment and for several other diseases as well. There exist two main approaches to incorporate the atom of Se: (i) as an open chain, where the Se atom can be present in many functionalities,(142) such as selenocyanate (SeCN), diselenide (SeâSe), isoselenocyanate (NCSe),(143,144) selenourea (H2N-C(âSe)-NH2), or methylseleno (CH3Se) and (ii) being part of a cyclic scaffold, where mostly the redox status of Se is +2, the +4 status being also possible in certain cases. There are many examples of very potent compounds achieved by the open chain functionalities, i.e., p-XSC,(145) diphenyldiselenide,(146) ISC-4,(147,148) NISC-6,(149,150) Se-aspirin,(151) PBISe,(152) and EI-201.(153) Among the examples of cyclic Se compounds, heterocycles with Se atom in endo position emerge as very promising candidates for several diseases given their low toxicity. Specifically, selenazo compounds have emerged as valuable agents presenting some assets compared with different Se heterocyclic compounds. From a chemistry point of view, most selenazo compounds can be synthesized with good yields and few reaction steps. Because of the relative ease of synthesis, several modifications have been performed over the selenazo scaffold through a great variety of reactions and positions, as discussed herein. Most importantly, by means of simple modifications different properties of the selenazo compounds can be modulated, including efficacy against different diseases. One of the most used modulation strategy is the fragment-based design, which has achieved potent analogs, e.g., selenazo derivatives of tacrine (II-18 in Figure 2),(56) ferrocene (VI-48 in Figure 5),(115) and combrestatin A4 (VIII-58 in Figure 8).(136,137) This strategy has the potential to lead to the development of bioactive selenazo compounds in order to obtain more potent and selective agents and therefore requires further attention. Other structural features that might have an impact on their activity are (i) the presence or absence of fused aromatic rings to the selenazo cycle, (ii) the existence or not of SeâN bond, and (iii) the ratio of Se/N in the cyclic scaffold. After critically revisiting the most recent literature, we consider the presence in the structure of at least one SeâN bond is important for the activity of the compounds. EBS (I-1 in Figure 1) and BBSKE (I-2 in Figure 1), the two most well studied selenazo compounds, both present this bond and a phenyl ring fused to the Se cycle. Although most of the modifications have been made over these two compounds, we hypothesize that the use of different polycycles fused to the selenazo cycle and, mainly, the increase of the ratio of N atoms related to Se are worth considering in search for more potent, selective, multifunctional, and immunomodulatory agents.
    From the bioactivity point of view, selenazo compounds mostly exert their efficacy by means of radical species quenching through different catalytic cycles. Nonetheless, several mechanisms of action have been unveiled as discussed above in this article. Among them, TrxR modulation can be considered as a novel and promising target, amply discussed by Bian et al.(154) The lack of toxicity and TrxR modulation, among other mechanisms, might be crucial features that allow further development of these derivatives. Overproduction of radical species is associated with the development of inflammation, aging, and various human diseases (such as cancer, cardiovascular, neurodegenerative, and metabolic disorders), along with side effects provoked by radiation. Given the plethora of pathways altered by selenazo compounds, we surmise that the combination of selenazo compounds with different drugs with complementary mechanisms of action or radiation, mitigating the side effects or sensitizing the cells, could have an outstanding impact on the treatment of many of these diseases. Nonetheless, considering altogether the facts reported herein, we consider TrxR inhibition as the most prominent and promising pathway to further explore these selenazo scaffolds. Likewise, cancer might be deemed as the disease where these derivatives can cause the greatest impact on the treatment.
    In summary, selenazo skeleton stands out as privileged feature within the selenoheterocycles, presenting preclinical efficacy in a plethora of illnesses as different as cancer, diabetes, or cardiovascular disorders. Furthermore, these effects were achieved through a great variety of mechanisms of action, encompassing, among others, apoptosis, QSOX1, HDACs, and TrxR. Overall, recent developments clearly indicate that appropriately designed selenazo compounds could lead to promising drug candidates for various diseases in the near future.

    Trx

    thioredoxin

    TrxR

    thioredoxin reductase

    UVA

    ultraviolet A

    VEGFR2

    endothelial growth factor receptor 2

    World Health Organization

    1. 1
      Santi, C.; Bagnoli, L. Celebrating two centuries of research in selenium chemistry: state of the art and new prospective. Molecules 2017, 22, 2124, Â DOI: 10.3390/molecules22122124
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      1
      Celebrating two centuries of research in selenium chemistry: state of the art and new prospective
      Santi, Claudio; Bagnoli, Luana
      Molecules (2017), 22 (12), 2124/1-2124/4CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      In 2017, the 200th anniversary of the discovery of selenium was celebrated. In 1817, the Swedish chemists, Berzelius and Gahn, on roasting 200 kg of sulfur from a pyrite from the Falun mine, obtained about 3 g of a ppt. that they first wrongly identified as tellurium. Berzelius doubted this result and repeated the anal. some months later realizing that a new element was in his hands and he named this element Selenium (Greek: Selene, moon) in consideration of its resemblance to Tellurium (Latin: Tellus, earth). Several events were organized in the year for this special celebration and this Special Issue would like to be an addnl. contribution to the success of a research that, esp. during the last decades, rapidly grew in different fields: synthesis, medicinal chem., biol., material, and environment. These studies are strongly characterized by multi- and interdisciplinary connections, and, for this reason, we collected here contributions coming from different areas and disciplines, not exclusively synthetic org. chem.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslWjsr0%253D&md5=80f85396167508eaed2e6b156da81b3f
    2. 2
      Wrobel, J. K.; Power, R.; Toborek, M. Biological activity of selenium: revisited. IUBMB Life 2016, 68, 97â 105, Â DOI: 10.1002/iub.1466
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      2
      Biological activity of selenium: Revisited
      Wrobel, Jagoda K.; Power, Ronan; Toborek, Michal
      IUBMB Life (2016), 68 (2), 97-105CODEN: IULIF8; ISSN:1521-6543. (John Wiley & Sons Inc.)
      Selenium (Se) is an essential micronutrient that exerts multiple and complex effects on human health. Se is essential for human well-being largely due to its potent antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral properties. The physiol. functions of Se are carried out by selenoproteins, in which Se is specifically incorporated as the amino acid, selenocysteine. Importantly, both beneficial and toxic effects of Se have been reported suggesting that the mode of action of Se is strictly chem. form and concn. dependent. Addnl., there is a relatively narrow window between Se deficiency and toxicity and growing evidence suggests that Se health effects depend greatly on the baseline level of this micronutrient. Thus, Se supplementation is not an easy task and requires an individualized approach. It is essential that we continue to explore and better characterize Se contg. compds. and mechanisms of action, which could be crucial for disease prevention and treatment. Â© 2015 IUBMB Life, 2015.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXitV2rs7nL&md5=6464c0cf45ed3fb134e4b967143bbf5d
    3. 3
      Hosnedlova, B.; Kepinska, M.; Skalickova, S.; Fernandez, C.; Ruttkay-Nedecky, B.; Malevu, T. D.; Sochor, J.; Baron, M.; Melcova, M.; Zidkova, J.; Kizek, R. A summary of new findings on the biological effects of selenium in selected animal species-a critical review. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2017, 18, 2209, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijms18102209
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      3
      A summary of new findings on the biologicaleffects of selenium in selected animalspecies-a critical review
      Hosnedlova, Bozena; Kepinska, Marta; Skalickova, Sylvie; Fernandez, Carlos; Ruttkay-Nedecky, Branislav; Malevu, Thembinkosi Donald; Sochor, Jiri; Baron, Mojmir; Melcova, Magdalena; Zidkova, Jarmila; Kizek, Rene
      International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2017), 18 (10), 2209/1-2209/47CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
      Selenium is an essential trace element important for many physiol. processes, esp. for the functions of immune and reproductive systems, metab. of thyroid hormones, as well as antioxidant defense. Selenium deficiency is usually manifested by an increased incidence of retention of placenta, metritis, mastitis, aborts, lowering fertility and increased susceptibility to infections. In calves, lambs and kids, the selenium deficiency demonstrates by WMD (white muscle disease), in foals and donkey foals, it is assocd. with incidence of WMD and yellow fat disease, and in pigs it causes VESD (vitamin E/selenium deficiency) syndrome. The prevention of these health disorders can be achieved by an adequate selenium supplementation to the diet. The review summarizes the survey of knowledge on selenium, its biol. significance in the organism, the impact of its deficiency in mammalian livestock (comparison of ruminants vs. non-ruminants, herbivore vs. omnivore) and possibilities of its peroral administration. The databases employed were as follows: Web of Science, PubMed, MEDLINE and Google Scholar.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitVOjsbzM&md5=119910d01bc4383d22977ce7735ec865
    4. 4
      Reich, H. J.; Hondal, R. J. Why nature chose selenium. ACS Chem. Biol. 2016, 11, 821â 841, Â DOI: 10.1021/acschembio.6b00031
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      4
      Why Nature Chose Selenium
      Reich, Hans J.; Hondal, Robert J.
      ACS Chemical Biology (2016), 11 (4), 821-841CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors were asked by the Editors of ACS Chem. Biol. to write an article titled "Why Nature Chose Selenium" for the occasion of the upcoming bicentennial of the discovery of selenium by the Swedish chemist Jons Jacob Berzelius in 1817 and styled after the famous work of Frank Westheimer on the biol. chem. of phosphate. This work gives a history of the important discoveries of the biol. processes that selenium participates in, and a point-by-point comparison of the chem. of selenium with the atom it replaces in biol., sulfur. This anal. shows that redox chem. is the largest chem. difference between the two chalcogens. This difference is very large for both one-electron and two-electron redox reactions. Much of this difference is due to the inability of selenium to form Ï bonds of all types. The outer valence electrons of selenium are also more loosely held than those of sulfur. As a result, selenium is a better nucleophile and will react with reactive oxygen species faster than sulfur, but the resulting lack of Ï-bond character in the Se-O bond means that the Se-oxide can be much more readily reduced in comparison to S-oxides. The combination of these properties means that replacement of sulfur with selenium in nature results in a selenium-contg. biomol. that resists permanent oxidn. Multiple examples of this gain of function behavior from the literature are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xjs1Ors70%253D&md5=e1f53c0a82a1eb27b7c66ec75f15c5af
    5. 5
      Tan, H. W.; Mo, H. Y.; Lau, A. T. Y.; Xu, Y. M. Selenium species: current status and potentials in cancer prevention and therapy. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2019, 20, 75, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijms20010075
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Selenium species: current status and potentials in cancer prevention and therapy
      Tan, Heng Wee; Mo, Hai-Ying; Lau, Andy T. Y.; Xu, Yan-Ming
      International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2019), 20 (1), 75/1-75/26CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
      Selenium (Se) acts as an essential trace element in the human body due to its unique biol. functions, particularly in the oxidn.-redn. system. Although several clin. trials indicated no significant benefit of Se in preventing cancer, researchers reported that some Se species exhibit superior anticancer properties. Therefore, a reassessment of the status of Se and Se compds. is necessary in order to provide clearer insights into the potentiality of Se in cancer prevention and therapy. In this review, we organize relevant forms of Se species based on the three main categories of Se-inorg., org., and Se-contg. nanoparticles (SeNPs)-and overview their potential functions and applications in oncol. Here, we specifically focus on the SeNPs as they have tremendous potential in oncol. and other fields. In general, to make better use of Se compds. in cancer prevention and therapy, extensive further study is still required to understand the underlying mechanisms of the Se compds.

      Small Organoselenium Compounds: More than just Glutathione Peroxidase Mimics
      Wirth, Thomas
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (35), 10074-10076CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review of organoselenium compds. as glutathione peroxidase mimics. Glutathione peroxidase is one of the mammalian antioxidant enzymes which is able to decomp. ROS, such as peroxides. The human enzymes have a selenocysteine residue in their active site which is responsible for the catalytic activity.

      Santi, C.; Tidei, C.; Scalera, C.; Piroddi, M.; Galli, F. Selenium containing compounds from poison to drug candidates: a review on the GPx-like activity. Curr. Chem. Biol. 2013, 7, 25â 36, Â DOI: 10.2174/2212796811307010003
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      7
      Selenium containing compounds from poison to drug candidates: a review on the GPx-like activity
      Santi, Claudio; Tidei, Caterina; Scalera, Claudia; Piroddi, Marta; Galli, Francesco
      Current Chemical Biology (2013), 7 (1), 25-36CODEN: CCBUB2; ISSN:2212-7968. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Oxidative stress results from the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as peroxides that cause damage to cell membranes and react with various biomols. in mammalian cells. The selenoenzyme glutathione peroxidase (GPx) destroys peroxides by catalyzing their redn. to alcs. or water with the stoichiometric reductant glutathione. The effects of oxidative stress have been implicated in a variety of degenerative processes and disease states and for these reasons, there is considerable interest in the discovery of small mol. compds. that could reproduce a GPx-like activity. A review on the most recent acquisition in this area is here reported.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXotlykt70%253D&md5=cd39e1b58fa824b8d44c0e7283ed4e8a

    9. 9
      Fernandes, A. P.; Gandin, V. Selenium compounds as therapeutic agents in cancer. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 2015, 1850, 1642â 1660, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bbagen.2014.10.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      9
      Selenium compounds as therapeutic agents in cancer
      Fernandes, Aristi P.; Gandin, Valentina
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2015), 1850 (8), 1642-1660CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. With cancer cells encompassing consistently higher prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and with an induced antioxidant defense to counteract the increased basal ROS prodn., tumors have a limited reserve capacity resulting in an increased vulnerability of some cancer cells to ROS. Based on this, oxidative stress has been recognized as a tumor-specific target for the rational design of new anticancer agents. Among redox modulating compds., selenium compds. have gained substantial attention due to their promising chemotherapeutic potential. This review aims in summarizing and providing the recent developments of our understanding of the mol. mechanisms that underlie the potential anticancer effects of selenium compds. It is well established that selenium at higher doses readily can turn into a prooxidant and thereby exert its potential anticancer properties. However, the biol. activity of selenium compds. and the mechanism behind these effects are highly dependent on its speciation and the specific metabolic pathways of cells and tissues. Conversely, the chem. properties and the main mol. mechanisms of the most relevant inorg. and org. selenium compds. as well as selenium-based nanoparticles must be taken into account and are discussed herein. Elucidating and deepening our mechanistic knowledge of selenium compds. will help in designing and optimizing compds. with more specific antitumor properties for possible future application of selenium compds. in the treatment of cancer. This article is part of a Special Issue entitled Redox regulation of differentiation and de-differentiation.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVSnu77E&md5=49d79e46bf4ab507c3a97d00d688ef20

      Bijian, K.; Zhang, Z.; Xu, B.; Jie, S.; Chen, B.; Wan, S.; Wu, J.; Jiang, T.; Alaoui-Jamali, M. A. Synthesis and biological activity of novel organoselenium derivatives targeting multiple kinases and capable of inhibiting cancer progression to metastases. Eur. J. Med.       11
      Synthesis and biological activity of novel organoselenium derivatives targeting multiple kinases and capable of inhibiting cancer progression to metastases
      Bijian, Krikor; Zhang, Zhongwei; Xu, Bin; Jie, Su; Chen, Bo; Wan, Shengbiao; Wu, JianHui; Jiang, Tao; Alaoui-Jamali, Moulay A.
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 48 (), 143-152CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      The present study reports synthesis and biol. activity of novel benzoisoselenazolone compds. derived from ebselen and conjugated to a sugar mol. Cell proliferation assay using cancer cells combined with in vitro biochem. assays revealed that benzoisoselenazolone, e.g. I, exerted antiproliferative activity, which correlated with selective in vitro inhibition of focal adhesion kinase, AKT-1, and protein kinase C-Î±. Active mols. were able to significantly inhibit cell migration and invasion in vitro compared to cells treated with the vehicle alone or ebselen. Moreover, in vivo anticancer activity focusing on lead compd. 2d and using an invasive human breast cancer orthotopic mouse model revealed a potent anti-metastatic activity at well-tolerated doses. In summary, these novel benzoisoselenazolones we report herein target multiple kinases with established roles in cancer progression and possess anti-invasive and anti-metastatic activity in pre-clin. models supporting a potential for therapeutic application for human disease.

      Design and Synthesis of Selenazole-Containing Peptides for Cocrystallization with P-Glycoprotein
      Tao, Hou-Chao; Weng, Yue; Zhuo, Ru-Peng; Chang, Geoffrey; Urbatsch, Ina L.; Zhang, Qing-Hai
      ChemBioChem (2011), 12 (6), 868-873CODEN: CBCHFX; ISSN:1439-4227. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Over-expression of P-glycoprotein (Pgp) in some cancer cells is a primary cause of multidrug resistance (MDR) that results in chemotherapy failure. In order to produce a diverse array of selenium-labeled peptides for structural studies directed at mapping the flexible binding sites of Pgp, the authors developed a procedure for the efficient prepn. of optically pure selanazole-contg. peptides. Thus, all 20 natural amino acid-derived selenazoles I (R = amino acid side chain) were synthesized in a three-step procedure starting from chiral nitriles (S)-BocNHCH(R)CN. Next, selenazole-contg. cyclic peptides were prepd., and their binding activity towards Pgp was evaluated using a commonly used calcein acetoxymethyl ester (calcein-AM) transport assay in Pgp-overexpressing CR1R12 cells.

      Synthesis and in vitro antitumor activity of 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives based on benzisoselenazolone
      Luo, Zhen-Hua; He, Shuang-Yan; Chen, Bao-Quan; Shi, Yan-Ping; Liu, Yu-Ming; Li, Cai-Wen; Wang, Qiu-Sheng
      Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin (2012), 60 (7), 887-891CODEN: CPBTAL; ISSN:0009-2363. (Pharmaceutical Society of Japan)
      A series of novel 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivs. based on benzisoselenazolone was prepd. and was tested for antiproliferative activity in vitro against human cancer cell lines: SSMC-7721 (liver cancer), MCF-7 (breast cancer), and A549 (lung cancer). All the compds. exhibited antiproliferative activity and showed selective cytotoxicity against different cancer cells. Two of the compds. showed significant antiproliferative activities against MCF-7 cells, with IC50 of 1.07 and 1.76 Î¼M. One of latter compds. was also the most potent compd. against SSMC-7721 cells, with IC50 = 4.46 Î¼M.

      Synthesis of a series of novel 2,4,5-trisubstituted selenazole compounds as potential PLTP inhibitors

      15
      Aromatic compounds containing selenium. VI
      Lesser, R.; Weiss, R.
      Berichte der Deutschen Chemischen Gesellschaft [Abteilung] B: Abhandlungen (1924), 57B (), 1077-82CODEN: BDCBAD; ISSN:0365-9488.
      cf. C. A. 9, 80. A more convenient method for the prepn. of selenoxanthone (I) has been worked out. The product (II) of the action of CrO3 on I is not an addn. product of I, as previously supposed, but of selenoxide-xanthone (III) and its cleavage product is III itself, which on heating at its m. p. or under the influence of other reagents loses O, not H2O, giving I. The soly. of III (in part even in H2O) with yellowish color is due to the addn. of H2O with production of HO groups. The o-HSeC6H4COCl (IV) is very reactive, giving with NH3 benzoylene selenimide, Se.C6H4.CO.NH (V), with primary bases the corresponding substituted imides, with Na2S benzoylene selenosulfide (VI) and with Na2Se benzoylene diselenide (VII). I, m. 191-2Â° (all m. ps. are cor.), is obtained in 10.3 g. yield of crude or 7.5 g. yield of pure product from 10 g. IV in 100 cc. dry thiophene-free C6H6 slowly treated with 11 g. AlCl3 and, when the gas evolution ceases, heated 1 hr. at 50-60Â° and then 1 hr. at the b. p. II, C13H8O2Se.CrO3, gives with NH3 III, decomps. 236-7Â°; air-dry, III contains varying amts. of H2O which it loses in vacuo over P2O5 or at 120-30Â°. With PhMe instead of C6H6, IV gives Î²1- or Î²2-methylselenoxanthone, faintly yellowish, m. 112-3Â°, sol. in concd. H2SO4 with orange-yellow color. V (7.4 g. crude product from 10 g. IV in cold C6H6 with dry NH3), needles or tables mutually interconvertible by seeding, m. 234-5Â°, both forms giving a red color with alc. FeCl3, forms alkali salts easily sol. in H2O but difficultly sol. in excess of alkali, gives in AcOH with CrO3 an addn. product which has approx. the compn. C7H5ONSe.CrO3 (no solvent suitable for crystn. could be found) but which on decompn. yields no homogeneous product; on long boiling with excess of Ac2O V gives an Ac deriv., begins to turn yellow 130Â°, m. 172-4Â°, sol. in hot AcOH with a yellowish color which disappears on cooling. Benzoyleneselenmethylimide, obtained with MeNH2 gas instead of NH3, prisms with faintly yellowish shimmer, m. 159-60Â°, also obtained from the Ag salt of V with excess of MeI on the H2O bath in a sealed tube. Et homolog, m. 102-3Â°. Ph analog, from IV and PhNH2 in cold Et2O, m. 182-3Â°. o-Tolyl homolog, m. 187-8Â°. N,N-Methylene di[benzoyleneselenimide], from the K salt of V and CH2I2 refluxed in AmOH, m. 331-2Â°. VI (4.4 g. of crude product from 5.1 g. IV in 80 cc. Me2CO treated with 5 g. Na2S (fused in its H2O of crystn.) and then refluxed), orange, m. 83-4Â°, insol. in Na2CO3 or NaOH even on heating, dissolves unchanged in concd. H2SO4 with yellow color. VII (8 g. from K2Se (prepd. by passing into 5.6 g. K2CO3 in 10 cc. H2O under CO2 the H2Se from 12 g. FeSe and 31 g. HCl of d. 1.12) treated cold with 10 g. IV in 50 cc. Me2CO and then refluxed 1 hr.), red, m. 91-2Â°, sol. in concd. H2SO4 with yellow color, the soln. becoming turbid on standing and evolving the odor of SO2. (PhCH2)2Se2, m. 90-1Â°, is obtained in 184 g. yield from 159 g. PhCH2Cl shaken with 100 g. red pptd. Se and 310 g. crystd. Na2S in 500 cc. H2O; 50 g. slowly added to 220 g. cold HNO3 (d. 1.4) gives 21 g. PhCH2SeO2H, m. 122-3Â° (Jackson, Ann. 179, 13(1875), gives 85Â°); Ba salt (2H2O); Ca salt (6H2O); the acid with PCl5 in dry Et2O gives, not the chloride, but (PhCH2)2SeCl2, m. 134-5Â° (Strecker and Willing, C. A. 9, 1179, give 128Â°).

      Safayhi, H.; Tiegs, G.; Wendel, A. A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--V. Inhibition by ebselen (PZ 51) of rat peritoneal neutrophil lipoxygenase. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985, 34, 2691â 2694, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(85)90569-6
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      16
      A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - V. Inhibition by ebselen (PZ 51) of rat peritoneal neutrophil lipoxygenase
      Safayhi, Hasan; Tiegs, Gisa; Wendel, Albrecht
      Biochemical Pharmacology (1985), 34 (15), 2691-4CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
      Suspensions of rat peritoneal polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNLs) elicited with glycogen were stimulated by Ca and an ionophore to produce leukotrienes from endogenous arachidonic acid. The effect of the nontoxic, anti-inflammatory seleno-org. compd., ebselen (PZ 51)(I) [60940-34-3] was investigated. When ethanolic exts. of the medium of stimulated cells were analyzed by HPLC, a concn.-dependent inhibition by ebselen of leukotriene b4 (LTB4) [71160-24-2] formation with a concomitant decrease of 5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (5-HETE) [71030-39-2] prodn. was found. Half-max. inhibition was obsd. at 20-Î¼M ebselen. Similar findings were obtained after anal. of CHCl3 exts. of both cells and medium using a different HPLC system. Under these conditions, enhanced 5-HETE formation was assocd. with reduced prodn. of LTB4 and other dihydroxyeicosatetraenoate (di-HETE) isomers, when purified glutathione peroxidase [9013-66-5] plus GSH were present. Thus, the reported GSH peroxidase-like activity of ebselen, catalyzing the redn. of 5-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoate (5-HPETE) [70968-82-0] to 5-HETE, can not account for these findings. Therefore, the lipoxygenase [9029-60-1] reaction itself apparently represents the site of inhibition of LTB4 formation by ebselen.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXkvFyntrY%253D&md5=0c6b904a21350720941f6fe0123ce1a5

      Muller, A.; Gabriel, H.; Sies, H. A novel biologically active selenoorganic compound--IV. Protective glutathione-dependent effect of PZ 51 (ebselen) against ADP-Fe induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985, 34, 1185â 1189, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(85)90493-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      17
      A novel biologically active selenoorganic compound--IV. Protective glutathione-dependent effect of PZ 51 (ebselen) against ADP-Fe induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes
      Muller A; Gabriel H; Sies H
      Biochemical pharmacology (1985), 34 (8), 1185-9 ISSN:0006-2952.
      PZ 51 (Ebselen) is capable of inhibiting ADP-Fe-induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes, assessed by generation of low-level chemiluminescence, and the formation of alkanes (ethane, n-pentane) and malondialdehyde. The sulphur analog PZ 25 is much less active. PZ 51 is ineffective in glutathione-depleted hepatocytes that were obtained after phorone pretreatment of the animals. However, other antioxidants, like (+)-cyanidanol-3 or diethyldithiocarbamate are effective in inhibiting lipid peroxidation also in glutathione-depleted cells. The results are attributed to a GSH peroxidase-like activity of PZ 51. Addition of the chemically synthetized compound, PZ 51-SG, a glutathione adduct of PZ 51, does not provide extra protection in GSH-depleted cells in comparison to the parent compound, PZ 51. Dithioerythritol exhibits a protective effect, and PZ 51 is more efficient than in the absence of this thiol reductant. Dithioerythritol also exerts an effect in glutathione-depleted cells. A peroxidase-like activity using DTE as reductant is demonstrated in vitro.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL2M7pvFWqsA%253D%253D&md5=9c105e936b8f63bb05adea11a9e3ceb3

      Wendel, A.; Fausel, M.; Safayhi, H.; Tiegs, G.; Otter, R. A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--II. Activity of PZ 51 in relation to glutathione peroxidase. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1984, 33, 3241â 3245, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(84)90084-4
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      18
      A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - II. Activity of PZ 51 in relation to glutathione peroxidase
      Wendel, Albrecht; Fausel, Martina; Safayhi, Hasan; Tiegs, Gisa; Otter, Rainer
      Biochemical Pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3241-5CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
      The antiinflammatory compd. PZ 51 (I) [60940-34-3] catalyzed GSSG formation from GSH in the presence of hydroperoxides in an NADPH/GSSG reductase system with the following rates (Î log GSH/min per M selenium): 1.1 Ã 106 with H2O2, 1.2 Ã 106 with butylhydroperoxide, 1.7 Ã 106 with cumenehydroperoxide. The reaction catalyzed by the sulfur analog of PZ 51 was negligible. Similar results were obtained in a direct assay of glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) [9013-66-5] activity based on GSH estn. by dithionitrobenzoate. The activation energy of the reaction was detd. as 55 kJ/molÂ·deg in the presence of 30 Î¼mol/L PZ 51 compared to 36.5 kJ/molÂ·deg obtained in the presence of 1 nmol/L pure GSH-Px isolated from bovine red blood cells. In mouse liver microsomes NADPH-dependent aminopyrine dealkylase [9037-69-8] activity was totally inhibited in the presence of 50 Î¼mol/L PZ 51. In vivo expts. with Se-deficient mice showed that the Se-moiety of PZ 51 is not available for the synthesis of the selenoenzyme GSH-Px after dietary treatment or i.p. doses up to 25 mg Se as PZ 51 per kg body wt. After oral administration of labeled PZ 51, unlike with selenite, no radioactivity was incorporated into GSH-Px within 48 h. The data suggest that several similarities between PZ 51 and the active site of GSH-Px exist, resulting in the capability of the compd. to catalyze the GSH-Px reaction. An extracellular pharmacodynamic action of the drug seems likely.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXjvFKitw%253D%253D&md5=a1475814e1a0c5ab4599dd82235b2993

      A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - III. Effects of PZ 51 (ebselen) on glutathione peroxidase and secretory activities of mouse macrophages
      Parnham, Michael J.; Kindt, Sabine
      Biochemical Pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3247-50CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
      PZ 51 (I) a selenium-contg. compd. with glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px)-like activity, was administered to selenium-deficient mice for 5 days. A significant increase in peritoneal macrophage GSH-Px activity after treatment was only obsd. when basal GSH-Px activity was almost zero (i.e. in 19 wk selenium-deficient animals), possibly due to binding of PZ 51 to the macrophages. This indicates that PZ 51 releases very little, if any, free selenium for incorporation into endogenous GSH-Px. The compd. in vitro exerted a concn.-dependent inhibition of the generation of chemiluminescence by resident mouse peritoneal macrophages and a partial inhibition of the prodn. of prostaglandin E2 by resident peritoneal macrophages. Î²-Glucuronidase prodn. by C. parvum-activated peritoneal macrophages was unaffected by PZ 51. These in vitro data can be explained on the basis of a selective peroxide scavenging and/or GSH-Px-like activity of PZ 51, offering a novel approach to anti-inflammatory therapy.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXktVShu7g%253D&md5=967be0e8b251a7c2e9c1e3c5660966a6

      A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--I. Glutathione peroxidase-like activity in vitro and antioxidant capacity of PZ 51 (Ebselen)
      Muller A; Cadenas E; Graf P; Sies H
      Biochemical pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3235-9 ISSN:0006-2952.
      a synthetic seleno-organic compound, 2-phenyl-1,2-benzoisoselenazol-3(2H)-one (PZ 51), exhibits GSH peroxidase-like activity in vitro, in contrast to its sulfur analog, PZ 25. In addition, PZ 51 behaves as an antioxidant shown by a temporary protection of rat liver microsomes against ascorbate/ADP-Fe-induced lipid peroxidation, an effect also elicited by PZ 25 but to a smaller extent. This protection against lipid peroxidation is independent of GSH and of P-450 monooxygenase activity.

      Martini, F.; Rosa, S. G.; Klann, I. P.; Fulco, B. C. W.; Carvalho, F. B.; Rahmeier, F. L.; Fernandes, M. C.; Nogueira, C. W. A multifunctional compound ebselen reverses memory impairment, apoptosis and oxidative stress in a mouse model of sporadic Alzheimerâs disease. J. Psychiatr. Res. 2019, 109, 107â 117, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2018.11.021
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

      A multifunctional compound ebselen reverses memory impairment, apoptosis and oxidative stress in a mouse model of sporadic Alzheimer's disease
      Martini Franciele; Rosa Suzan Goncalves; Klann Isabella Pregardier; Fulco Bruna Cruz Weber; Carvalho Fabiano Barbosa; Rahmeier Francine Luciano; Fernandes Marilda Cruz; Nogueira Cristina Wayne
      Journal of psychiatric research (2019), 109 (), 107-117 ISSN:.
      Alzheimer 's disease (AD) is characterized by progressive cognitive decline including memory impairment, cortical dysfunction, and neuropsychiatric disturbances. The drug discovery to treat AD consists to develop compounds able to act in multiple molecular targets involved in the pathogenesis of the disease and the repositioning of old drugs for new application. This way, the intracerebroventricular (icv) injection of streptozotocin (STZ) has been used as a metabolic model of sporadic AD. The aim of the present study was to investigate whether ebselen (1-10 mg/kg), a multifunctional selenoorganic compound, ameliorates memory impairment, hippocampal oxidative stress, apoptosis and cell proliferation in a mouse model of sporadic AD induced by icv STZ (3 mg/kg, 1 Î¼l/min). The administration of ebselen (10 mg/kg, i.p.) reversed memory impairment and hippocampal oxidative stress, by increasing the activities of antioxidant enzymes and the level of a non-enzymatic antioxidant defense, in Swiss mice administered with icv STZ. The anti-apoptotic property of ebselen was demonstrated by its effectiveness against the increase in the ratios of Bax/Bcl-2, cleaved PARP/PARP and the cleaved caspase-3 levels in the hippocampus of icv STZ mice. Although ebselen reversed memory impairment, it was ineffective against the reduction in the number of BrdU positive cells induced by icv STZ. In conclusion, the multifunctional selenoorganic compound ebselen was effective to reverse memory impairment, hippocampal oxidative stress and apoptosis in a mouse model of sporadic AD induced by icv STZ.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3crpt1KjsA%253D%253D&md5=3d86850110eb7986c65035f3c5e29f16

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
