      152
      A selenium containing inhibitor for the treatment of hepatocellular cancer
      Tagaram, Hephzibah Rani S.; Desai, Dhimant; Li, Guangfu; Liu, Dai; Bart, Rountree C.; Gowda, Kavitha; Berg, Arthur; Amin, Shantu; Staveley-O'Carroll, Kevin F.; Kimchi, Eric T.
      Pharmaceuticals (2016), 9 (2), 18/1-18/14CODEN: PHARH2; ISSN:1424-8247. (MDPI AG)
      Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the third most deadly cancer in the world. New treatment strategies are desperately needed due to limited std. therapies. Activation of the Erk, Akt, and STAT3pathways is implicated in the prognosis of HCC. The Se,Se'-1,4-phenylenebis(1,2- ethanediyl) bisisoselenourea (PBISe), is a selenium-contg. MAPK and PI3 kinase inhibitor, effectively inhibit tumorigenesis in a variety of exptl. models. The aim of our study is to demonstrate the potential role of PBISe in the treatment of HCC. The anti-proliferative and pro-apoptotic ability of PBISe is studied in vitro in four human HCC cell lines and in vivo in a spontaneous murine HCC model. Inhibition of cancer growth was performed by cell viability assay and apoptosis by caspase 3/7, PARP cleavage, annexin-V, and TUNEL assays. Role of PBISe on PI3 kinase, MAPK and STAT3 signaling is detd. by Western blotting. In vivo effects of PBISe on tumor sizes were monitored using MRI in a spontaneous murine HCC. Liver tissues from the PBISe-treated mice are analyzed for angiogenesis, proliferation, and signaling pathway markers. Overall, PBISe activated caspase-3/7 and increased DNA fragmentation, which is pos. correlated with the increased PARP cleavage. PBISe promoted apoptosis by inhibiting PI3K, MAPK, and STAT3 signaling with significant redn. in the tumor sizes (p < 0.007). PBISe-treated tumors reduced survival marker PCNA, and angiogenesis markers Vegf-A, Vegf-R3 and CD34. These results demonstrate the chemotherapeutic effects of PBISe, by inhibiting tumor growth and facilitating tumor apoptosis for HCC treatment.

      Ibanez, E.; Agliano, A.; Prior, C.; Nguewa, P.; Redrado, M.; Gonzalez-Zubeldia, I.; Plano, D.; Palop, J. A.; Sanmartin, C.; Calvo, A. The quinoline imidoselenocarbamate EI201 blocks the AKT/mTOR pathway and targets cancer stem cells leading to a strong antitumor activity. Curr. Med. Chem. 2012, 19, 3031â 3043, Â DOI: 10.2174/092986712800672076

      153
      The quinoline imidoselenocarbamate EI201 blocks the AKT/mTOR pathway and targets cancer stem cells leading to a strong antitumor activity
      Ibanez, E.; Agliano, A.; Prior, C.; Nguewa, P.; Redrado, M.; Gonzalez-Zubeldia, I.; Plano, D.; Palop, J. A.; Sanmartin, C.; Calvo, A.
      Current Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 19 (18), 3031-3043CODEN: CMCHE7; ISSN:0929-8673. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      Methylimidoselenocarbamates have previously proven to display potent antitumor activities. In the present study we show that these compds. act as multikinase inhibitors. We found that the most effective compd., quinoline imidoselenocarbamate EI201, inhibits the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, which is persistently activated and contributes to malignant progression in various cancers. EI201 blocked the phosphorylation of AKT, mTOR and several of its downstream regulators (p70S6K and 4E-BP1) and ERK1/2 in PC-3, HT-29 and MCF-7 cells in vitro, inducing both autophagy and apoptosis. EI201 also contributes to the loss of maintenance of the selfrenewal and tumorigenic capacity of cancer stem cells (CSCs). 0.1 Î¼Mol/L EI201 triggered a redn. in size and no. of tumorspheres in PC-3, HT-29 and MCF-7 cells and 4 Î¼mol/L induced the elimination of almost all the tumorspheres in the three studied cell lines. In addn., EI201 suppressed almost 80% prostate tumor growth in vivo (p < 0.01) compared to controls at a relatively low dose (10 mg/kg) in a mouse xenograft model. There was a significant decrease in the s.c. primary tumor [18F]-FDG uptake (76.5% redn., p < 0.05) and in the total tumor burden (76.8% redn., p < 0.05) after EI201 treatment compared to vehicle control, without causing toxicity in mice. Taken together, our results support further development of EI201 as a novel multi-kinase inhibitor that may be useful against cancers with aberrant upregulation of PI3K/AKT and MAPK signaling pathways.

      Bian, M.; Fan, R.; Zhao, S.; Liu, W. Targeting the thioredoxin system as a strategy for cancer therapy. J. Med. Chem. 2019, 62, 7309â 7321, Â DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.8b01595
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      154
      Targeting the thioredoxin system as a strategy for cancer therapy
      Bian, Mianli; Fan, Rong; Zhao, Sai; Liu, Wukun
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2019), 62 (16), 7309-7321CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) participates in the regulation of redox reactions in organisms. It works mainly via its substrate mol., thioredoxin, to maintain the redox balance and regulate signal transduction, which controls cell proliferation, differentiation, death, and other important physiol. processes. In recent years, increasing evidence has shown that the overactivation of TrxR is related to the development of tumors. The exploration of TrxR-targeted antitumor drugs has attracted wide attention and is expected to provide new therapies for cancer treatment. In this perspective, we highlight the specific relationship between TrxR and apoptotic signaling pathways. The cytoplasm and mitochondria both contain TrxR, resulting in the activation of apoptosis. TrxR activity influences reactive oxygen species (ROS) and further regulates the inflammatory signaling pathway. In addn., we discuss representative TrxR inhibitors with anticancer activity and analyze the challenges in developing TrxR inhibitors as anticancer drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      1. 1
        Santi, C.; Bagnoli, L. Celebrating two centuries of research in selenium chemistry: state of the art and new prospective. Molecules 2017, 22, 2124, Â DOI: 10.3390/molecules22122124
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        1
        Celebrating two centuries of research in selenium chemistry: state of the art and new prospective
        Santi, Claudio; Bagnoli, Luana
        Molecules (2017), 22 (12), 2124/1-2124/4CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
        In 2017, the 200th anniversary of the discovery of selenium was celebrated. In 1817, the Swedish chemists, Berzelius and Gahn, on roasting 200 kg of sulfur from a pyrite from the Falun mine, obtained about 3 g of a ppt. that they first wrongly identified as tellurium. Berzelius doubted this result and repeated the anal. some months later realizing that a new element was in his hands and he named this element Selenium (Greek: Selene, moon) in consideration of its resemblance to Tellurium (Latin: Tellus, earth). Several events were organized in the year for this special celebration and this Special Issue would like to be an addnl. contribution to the success of a research that, esp. during the last decades, rapidly grew in different fields: synthesis, medicinal chem., biol., material, and environment. These studies are strongly characterized by multi- and interdisciplinary connections, and, for this reason, we collected here contributions coming from different areas and disciplines, not exclusively synthetic org. chem.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslWjsr0%253D&md5=80f85396167508eaed2e6b156da81b3f
      2. 2
        Wrobel, J. K.; Power, R.; Toborek, M. Biological activity of selenium: revisited. IUBMB Life 2016, 68, 97â 105, Â DOI: 10.1002/iub.1466
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        2
        Biological activity of selenium: Revisited
        Wrobel, Jagoda K.; Power, Ronan; Toborek, Michal
        IUBMB Life (2016), 68 (2), 97-105CODEN: IULIF8; ISSN:1521-6543. (John Wiley & Sons Inc.)
        Selenium (Se) is an essential micronutrient that exerts multiple and complex effects on human health. Se is essential for human well-being largely due to its potent antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral properties. The physiol. functions of Se are carried out by selenoproteins, in which Se is specifically incorporated as the amino acid, selenocysteine. Importantly, both beneficial and toxic effects of Se have been reported suggesting that the mode of action of Se is strictly chem. form and concn. dependent. Addnl., there is a relatively narrow window between Se deficiency and toxicity and growing evidence suggests that Se health effects depend greatly on the baseline level of this micronutrient. Thus, Se supplementation is not an easy task and requires an individualized approach. It is essential that we continue to explore and better characterize Se contg. compds. and mechanisms of action, which could be crucial for disease prevention and treatment. Â© 2015 IUBMB Life, 2015.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXitV2rs7nL&md5=6464c0cf45ed3fb134e4b967143bbf5d
      3. 3
        Hosnedlova, B.; Kepinska, M.; Skalickova, S.; Fernandez, C.; Ruttkay-Nedecky, B.; Malevu, T. D.; Sochor, J.; Baron, M.; Melcova, M.; Zidkova, J.; Kizek, R. A summary of new findings on the biological effects of selenium in selected animal species-a critical review. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2017, 18, 2209, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijms18102209
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        3
        A summary of new findings on the biologicaleffects of selenium in selected animalspecies-a critical review
        Hosnedlova, Bozena; Kepinska, Marta; Skalickova, Sylvie; Fernandez, Carlos; Ruttkay-Nedecky, Branislav; Malevu, Thembinkosi Donald; Sochor, Jiri; Baron, Mojmir; Melcova, Magdalena; Zidkova, Jarmila; Kizek, Rene
        International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2017), 18 (10), 2209/1-2209/47CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
        Selenium is an essential trace element important for many physiol. processes, esp. for the functions of immune and reproductive systems, metab. of thyroid hormones, as well as antioxidant defense. Selenium deficiency is usually manifested by an increased incidence of retention of placenta, metritis, mastitis, aborts, lowering fertility and increased susceptibility to infections. In calves, lambs and kids, the selenium deficiency demonstrates by WMD (white muscle disease), in foals and donkey foals, it is assocd. with incidence of WMD and yellow fat disease, and in pigs it causes VESD (vitamin E/selenium deficiency) syndrome. The prevention of these health disorders can be achieved by an adequate selenium supplementation to the diet. The review summarizes the survey of knowledge on selenium, its biol. significance in the organism, the impact of its deficiency in mammalian livestock (comparison of ruminants vs. non-ruminants, herbivore vs. omnivore) and possibilities of its peroral administration. The databases employed were as follows: Web of Science, PubMed, MEDLINE and Google Scholar.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitVOjsbzM&md5=119910d01bc4383d22977ce7735ec865
      4. 4
        Reich, H. J.; Hondal, R. J. Why nature chose selenium. ACS Chem. Biol. 2016, 11, 821â 841, Â DOI: 10.1021/acschembio.6b00031
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        4
        Why Nature Chose Selenium
        Reich, Hans J.; Hondal, Robert J.
        ACS Chemical Biology (2016), 11 (4), 821-841CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors were asked by the Editors of ACS Chem. Biol. to write an article titled "Why Nature Chose Selenium" for the occasion of the upcoming bicentennial of the discovery of selenium by the Swedish chemist Jons Jacob Berzelius in 1817 and styled after the famous work of Frank Westheimer on the biol. chem. of phosphate. This work gives a history of the important discoveries of the biol. processes that selenium participates in, and a point-by-point comparison of the chem. of selenium with the atom it replaces in biol., sulfur. This anal. shows that redox chem. is the largest chem. difference between the two chalcogens. This difference is very large for both one-electron and two-electron redox reactions. Much of this difference is due to the inability of selenium to form Ï bonds of all types. The outer valence electrons of selenium are also more loosely held than those of sulfur. As a result, selenium is a better nucleophile and will react with reactive oxygen species faster than sulfur, but the resulting lack of Ï-bond character in the Se-O bond means that the Se-oxide can be much more readily reduced in comparison to S-oxides. The combination of these properties means that replacement of sulfur with selenium in nature results in a selenium-contg. biomol. that resists permanent oxidn. Multiple examples of this gain of function behavior from the literature are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xjs1Ors70%253D&md5=e1f53c0a82a1eb27b7c66ec75f15c5af
      5. 5
        Tan, H. W.; Mo, H. Y.; Lau, A. T. Y.; Xu, Y. M. Selenium species: current status and potentials in cancer prevention and therapy. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2019, 20, 75, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijms20010075
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        5
        Selenium species: current status and potentials in cancer prevention and therapy
        Tan, Heng Wee; Mo, Hai-Ying; Lau, Andy T. Y.; Xu, Yan-Ming
        International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2019), 20 (1), 75/1-75/26CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
        Selenium (Se) acts as an essential trace element in the human body due to its unique biol. functions, particularly in the oxidn.-redn. system. Although several clin. trials indicated no significant benefit of Se in preventing cancer, researchers reported that some Se species exhibit superior anticancer properties. Therefore, a reassessment of the status of Se and Se compds. is necessary in order to provide clearer insights into the potentiality of Se in cancer prevention and therapy. In this review, we organize relevant forms of Se species based on the three main categories of Se-inorg., org., and Se-contg. nanoparticles (SeNPs)-and overview their potential functions and applications in oncol. Here, we specifically focus on the SeNPs as they have tremendous potential in oncol. and other fields. In general, to make better use of Se compds. in cancer prevention and therapy, extensive further study is still required to understand the underlying mechanisms of the Se compds.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFahtr7F&md5=cd9dcd0c5245b0a5d7082130c5ba621f

        Wirth, T. Small organoselenium compounds: more than just glutathione peroxidase mimics. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54, 10074â 10076, Â DOI: 10.1002/anie.201505056
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        6
        Small Organoselenium Compounds: More than just Glutathione Peroxidase Mimics
        Wirth, Thomas
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (35), 10074-10076CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review of organoselenium compds. as glutathione peroxidase mimics. Glutathione peroxidase is one of the mammalian antioxidant enzymes which is able to decomp. ROS, such as peroxides. The human enzymes have a selenocysteine residue in their active site which is responsible for the catalytic activity.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFyqurrF&md5=b7cf2151dd89b251c5a49e88dd4b6bd1
      7. 7
        Santi, C.; Tidei, C.; Scalera, C.; Piroddi, M.; Galli, F. Selenium containing compounds from poison to drug candidates: a review on the GPx-like activity. Curr. Chem. Biol. 2013, 7, 25â 36, Â DOI: 10.2174/2212796811307010003
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        7
        Selenium containing compounds from poison to drug candidates: a review on the GPx-like activity
        Santi, Claudio; Tidei, Caterina; Scalera, Claudia; Piroddi, Marta; Galli, Francesco
        Current Chemical Biology (2013), 7 (1), 25-36CODEN: CCBUB2; ISSN:2212-7968. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. Oxidative stress results from the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as peroxides that cause damage to cell membranes and react with various biomols. in mammalian cells. The selenoenzyme glutathione peroxidase (GPx) destroys peroxides by catalyzing their redn. to alcs. or water with the stoichiometric reductant glutathione. The effects of oxidative stress have been implicated in a variety of degenerative processes and disease states and for these reasons, there is considerable interest in the discovery of small mol. compds. that could reproduce a GPx-like activity. A review on the most recent acquisition in this area is here reported.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXotlykt70%253D&md5=cd39e1b58fa824b8d44c0e7283ed4e8a

      9. 9
        Fernandes, A. P.; Gandin, V. Selenium compounds as therapeutic agents in cancer. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 2015, 1850, 1642â 1660, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bbagen.2014.10.008
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        9
        Selenium compounds as therapeutic agents in cancer
        Fernandes, Aristi P.; Gandin, Valentina
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2015), 1850 (8), 1642-1660CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. With cancer cells encompassing consistently higher prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and with an induced antioxidant defense to counteract the increased basal ROS prodn., tumors have a limited reserve capacity resulting in an increased vulnerability of some cancer cells to ROS. Based on this, oxidative stress has been recognized as a tumor-specific target for the rational design of new anticancer agents. Among redox modulating compds., selenium compds. have gained substantial attention due to their promising chemotherapeutic potential. This review aims in summarizing and providing the recent developments of our understanding of the mol. mechanisms that underlie the potential anticancer effects of selenium compds. It is well established that selenium at higher doses readily can turn into a prooxidant and thereby exert its potential anticancer properties. However, the biol. activity of selenium compds. and the mechanism behind these effects are highly dependent on its speciation and the specific metabolic pathways of cells and tissues. Conversely, the chem. properties and the main mol. mechanisms of the most relevant inorg. and org. selenium compds. as well as selenium-based nanoparticles must be taken into account and are discussed herein. Elucidating and deepening our mechanistic knowledge of selenium compds. will help in designing and optimizing compds. with more specific antitumor properties for possible future application of selenium compds. in the treatment of cancer. This article is part of a Special Issue entitled Redox regulation of differentiation and de-differentiation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVSnu77E&md5=49d79e46bf4ab507c3a97d00d688ef20

        Bijian, K.; Zhang, Z.; Xu, B.; Jie, S.; Chen, B.; Wan, S.; Wu, J.; Jiang, T.; Alaoui-Jamali, M. A. Synthesis and biological activity of novel organoselenium derivatives targeting multiple kinases and capable of inhibiting cancer progression to metastases. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 48, 143â 152, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2011.12.006

        11
        Synthesis and biological activity of novel organoselenium derivatives targeting multiple kinases and capable of inhibiting cancer progression to metastases
        Bijian, Krikor; Zhang, Zhongwei; Xu, Bin; Jie, Su; Chen, Bo; Wan, Shengbiao; Wu, JianHui; Jiang, Tao; Alaoui-Jamali, Moulay A.
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 48 (), 143-152CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        The present study reports synthesis and biol. activity of novel benzoisoselenazolone compds. derived from ebselen and conjugated to a sugar mol. Cell proliferation assay using cancer cells combined with in vitro biochem. assays revealed that benzoisoselenazolone, e.g. I, exerted antiproliferative activity, which correlated with selective in vitro inhibition of focal adhesion kinase, AKT-1, and protein kinase C-Î±. Active mols. were able to significantly inhibit cell migration and invasion in vitro compared to cells treated with the vehicle alone or ebselen. Moreover, in vivo anticancer activity focusing on lead compd. 2d and using an invasive human breast cancer orthotopic mouse model revealed a potent anti-metastatic activity at well-tolerated doses. In summary, these novel benzoisoselenazolones we report herein target multiple kinases with established roles in cancer progression and possess anti-invasive and anti-metastatic activity in pre-clin. models supporting a potential for therapeutic application for human disease.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        12
        Design and Synthesis of Selenazole-Containing Peptides for Cocrystallization with P-Glycoprotein
        Tao, Hou-Chao; Weng, Yue; Zhuo, Ru-Peng; Chang, Geoffrey; Urbatsch, Ina L.; Zhang, Qing-Hai
        ChemBioChem (2011), 12 (6), 868-873CODEN: CBCHFX; ISSN:1439-4227. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Over-expression of P-glycoprotein (Pgp) in some cancer cells is a primary cause of multidrug resistance (MDR) that results in chemotherapy failure. In order to produce a diverse array of selenium-labeled peptides for structural studies directed at mapping the flexible binding sites of Pgp, the authors developed a procedure for the efficient prepn. of optically pure selanazole-contg. peptides. Thus, all 20 natural amino acid-derived selenazoles I (R = amino acid side chain) were synthesized in a three-step procedure starting from chiral nitriles (S)-BocNHCH(R)CN. Next, selenazole-contg. cyclic peptides were prepd., and their binding activity towards Pgp was evaluated using a commonly used calcein acetoxymethyl ester (calcein-AM) transport assay in Pgp-overexpressing CR1R12 cells.

        Luo, Z. H.; He, S. Y.; Chen, B. Q.; Shi, Y. P.; Liu, Y. M.; Li, C. W.; Wang, Q. S. Synthesis and in vitro antitumor activity of 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives based on benzisoselenazolone. Chem. Pharm. Bull. 2012, 60, 887â 891, Â DOI: 10.1248/cpb.c12-00250

        Synthesis and in vitro antitumor activity of 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives based on benzisoselenazolone
        Luo, Zhen-Hua; He, Shuang-Yan; Chen, Bao-Quan; Shi, Yan-Ping; Liu, Yu-Ming; Li, Cai-Wen; Wang, Qiu-Sheng
        Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin (2012), 60 (7), 887-891CODEN: CPBTAL; ISSN:0009-2363. (Pharmaceutical Society of Japan)
        A series of novel 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivs. based on benzisoselenazolone was prepd. and was tested for antiproliferative activity in vitro against human cancer cell lines: SSMC-7721 (liver cancer), MCF-7 (breast cancer), and A549 (lung cancer). All the compds. exhibited antiproliferative activity and showed selective cytotoxicity against different cancer cells. Two of the compds. showed significant antiproliferative activities against MCF-7 cells, with IC50 of 1.07 and 1.76 Î¼M. One of latter compds. was also the most potent compd. against SSMC-7721 cells, with IC50 = 4.46 Î¼M.

        Synthesis of a series of novel 2,4,5-trisubstituted selenazole compounds as potential PLTP inhibitors
        Ling, Cui; Zheng, Zhibing; Jiang, Xian Cheng; Zhong, Wu; Li, Song

Biol. evaluation reveals that compds. I (R1 = Ph, R2 = H, R3 = H; R1 = Bu, R2 = R3 = OH) exhibit favorable PLTP activity, and their IC50s are 8 Î¼M and 10 Î¼M, resp.

        15
        Aromatic compounds containing selenium. VI
        Lesser, R.; Weiss, R.
        Berichte der Deutschen Chemischen Gesellschaft [Abteilung] B: Abhandlungen (1924), 57B (), 1077-82CODEN: BDCBAD; ISSN:0365-9488.
        cf. C. A. 9, 80. A more convenient method for the prepn. of selenoxanthone (I) has been worked out. The product (II) of the action of CrO3 on I is not an addn. product of I, as previously supposed, but of selenoxide-xanthone (III) and its cleavage product is III itself, which on heating at its m. p. or under the influence of other reagents loses O, not H2O, giving I. The soly. of III (in part even in H2O) with yellowish color is due to the addn. of H2O with production of HO groups. The o-HSeC6H4COCl (IV) is very reactive, giving with NH3 benzoylene selenimide, Se.C6H4.CO.NH (V), with primary bases the corresponding substituted imides, with Na2S benzoylene selenosulfide (VI) and with Na2Se benzoylene diselenide (VII). I, m. 191-2Â° (all m. ps. are cor.), is obtained in 10.3 g. yield of crude or 7.5 g. yield of pure product from 10 g. IV in 100 cc. dry thiophene-free C6H6 slowly treated with 11 g. AlCl3 and, when the gas evolution ceases, heated 1 hr. at 50-60Â° and then 1 hr. at the b. p. II, C13H8O2Se.CrO3, gives with NH3 III, decomps. 236-7Â°; air-dry, III contains varying amts. of H2O which it loses in vacuo over P2O5 or at 120-30Â°. With PhMe instead of C6H6, IV gives Î²1- or Î²2-methylselenoxanthone, faintly yellowish, m. 112-3Â°, sol. in concd. H2SO4 with orange-yellow color. V (7.4 g. crude product from 10 g. IV in cold C6H6 with dry NH3), needles or tables mutually interconvertible by seeding, m. 234-5Â°, both forms giving a red color with alc. FeCl3, forms alkali salts easily sol. in H2O but difficultly sol. in excess of alkali, gives in AcOH with CrO3 an addn. product which has approx. the compn. C7H5ONSe.CrO3 (no solvent suitable for crystn. could be found) but which on decompn. yields no homogeneous product; on long boiling with excess of Ac2O V gives an Ac deriv., begins to turn yellow 130Â°, m. 172-4Â°, sol. in hot AcOH with a yellowish color which disappears on cooling. Benzoyleneselenmethylimide, obtained with MeNH2 gas instead of NH3, prisms with faintly yellowish shimmer, m. 159-60Â°, also obtained from the Ag salt of V with excess of MeI on the H2O bath in a sealed tube. Et homolog, m. 102-3Â°. Ph analog, from IV and PhNH2 in cold Et2O, m. 182-3Â°. o-Tolyl homolog, m. 187-8Â°. N,N-Methylene di[benzoyleneselenimide], from the K salt of V and CH2I2 refluxed in AmOH, m. 331-2Â°. VI (4.4 g. of crude product from 5.1 g. IV in 80 cc. Me2CO treated with 5 g. Na2S (fused in its H2O of crystn.) and then refluxed), orange, m. 83-4Â°, insol. in Na2CO3 or NaOH even on heating, dissolves unchanged in concd. H2SO4 with yellow color. VII (8 g. from K2Se (prepd. by passing into 5.6 g. K2CO3 in 10 cc. H2O under CO2 the H2Se from 12 g. FeSe and 31 g. HCl of d. 1.12) treated cold with 10 g. IV in 50 cc. Me2CO and then refluxed 1 hr.), red, m. 91-2Â°, sol. in concd. H2SO4 with yellow color, the soln. becoming turbid on standing and evolving the odor of SO2. (PhCH2)2Se2, m. 90-1Â°, is obtained in 184 g. yield from 159 g. PhCH2Cl shaken with 100 g. red pptd. Se and 310 g. crystd. Na2S in 500 cc. H2O; 50 g. slowly added to 220 g. cold HNO3 (d. 1.4) gives 21 g. PhCH2SeO2H, m. 122-3Â° (Jackson, Ann. 179, 13(1875), gives 85Â°); Ba salt (2H2O); Ca salt (6H2O); the acid with PCl5 in dry Et2O gives, not the chloride, but (PhCH2)2SeCl2, m. 134-5Â° (Strecker and Willing, C. A. 9, 1179, give 128Â°).

        Safayhi, H.; Tiegs, G.; Wendel, A. A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--V. Inhibition by ebselen (PZ 51) of rat peritoneal neutrophil lipoxygenase. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985, 34, 2691â 2694, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(85)90569-6
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        16
        A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - V. Inhibition by ebselen (PZ 51) of rat peritoneal neutrophil lipoxygenase
        Safayhi, Hasan; Tiegs, Gisa; Wendel, Albrecht
        Biochemical Pharmacology (1985), 34 (15), 2691-4CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
        Suspensions of rat peritoneal polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNLs) elicited with glycogen were stimulated by Ca and an ionophore to produce leukotrienes from endogenous arachidonic acid. The effect of the nontoxic, anti-inflammatory seleno-org. compd., ebselen (PZ 51)(I) [60940-34-3] was investigated. When ethanolic exts. of the medium of stimulated cells were analyzed by HPLC, a concn.-dependent inhibition by ebselen of leukotriene b4 (LTB4) [71160-24-2] formation with a concomitant decrease of 5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (5-HETE) [71030-39-2] prodn. was found. Half-max. inhibition was obsd. at 20-Î¼M ebselen. Similar findings were obtained after anal. of CHCl3 exts. of both cells and medium using a different HPLC system. Under these conditions, enhanced 5-HETE formation was assocd. with reduced prodn. of LTB4 and other dihydroxyeicosatetraenoate (di-HETE) isomers, when purified glutathione peroxidase [9013-66-5] plus GSH were present. Thus, the reported GSH peroxidase-like activity of ebselen, catalyzing the redn. of 5-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoate (5-HPETE) [70968-82-0] to 5-HETE, can not account for these findings. Therefore, the lipoxygenase [9029-60-1] reaction itself apparently represents the site of inhibition of LTB4 formation by ebselen.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXkvFyntrY%253D&md5=0c6b904a21350720941f6fe0123ce1a5

        Muller, A.; Gabriel, H.; Sies, H. A novel biologically active selenoorganic compound--IV. Protective glutathione-dependent effect of PZ 51 (ebselen) against ADP-Fe induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985, 34, 1185â 1189, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(85)90493-9
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        17
        A novel biologically active selenoorganic compound--IV. Protective glutathione-dependent effect of PZ 51 (ebselen) against ADP-Fe induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes
        Muller A; Gabriel H; Sies H
        Biochemical pharmacology (1985), 34 (8), 1185-9 ISSN:0006-2952.
        PZ 51 (Ebselen) is capable of inhibiting ADP-Fe-induced lipid peroxidation in isolated hepatocytes, assessed by generation of low-level chemiluminescence, and the formation of alkanes (ethane, n-pentane) and malondialdehyde. The sulphur analog PZ 25 is much less active. PZ 51 is ineffective in glutathione-depleted hepatocytes that were obtained after phorone pretreatment of the animals. However, other antioxidants, like (+)-cyanidanol-3 or diethyldithiocarbamate are effective in inhibiting lipid peroxidation also in glutathione-depleted cells. The results are attributed to a GSH peroxidase-like activity of PZ 51. Addition of the chemically synthetized compound, PZ 51-SG, a glutathione adduct of PZ 51, does not provide extra protection in GSH-depleted cells in comparison to the parent compound, PZ 51. Dithioerythritol exhibits a protective effect, and PZ 51 is more efficient than in the absence of this thiol reductant. Dithioerythritol also exerts an effect in glutathione-depleted cells. A peroxidase-like activity using DTE as reductant is demonstrated in vitro.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL2M7pvFWqsA%253D%253D&md5=9c105e936b8f63bb05adea11a9e3ceb3
      18. 18
        Wendel, A.; Fausel, M.; Safayhi, H.; Tiegs, G.; Otter, R. A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--II. Activity of PZ 51 in relation to glutathione peroxidase. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1984, 33, 3241â 3245, Â DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(84)90084-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        18
        A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - II. Activity of PZ 51 in relation to glutathione peroxidase
        Wendel, Albrecht; Fausel, Martina; Safayhi, Hasan; Tiegs, Gisa; Otter, Rainer
        Biochemical Pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3241-5CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
        The antiinflammatory compd. PZ 51 (I) [60940-34-3] catalyzed GSSG formation from GSH in the presence of hydroperoxides in an NADPH/GSSG reductase system with the following rates (Î log GSH/min per M selenium): 1.1 Ã 106 with H2O2, 1.2 Ã 106 with butylhydroperoxide, 1.7 Ã 106 with cumenehydroperoxide. The reaction catalyzed by the sulfur analog of PZ 51 was negligible. Similar results were obtained in a direct assay of glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) [9013-66-5] activity based on GSH estn. by dithionitrobenzoate. The activation energy of the reaction was detd. as 55 kJ/molÂ·deg in the presence of 30 Î¼mol/L PZ 51 compared to 36.5 kJ/molÂ·deg obtained in the presence of 1 nmol/L pure GSH-Px isolated from bovine red blood cells. In mouse liver microsomes NADPH-dependent aminopyrine dealkylase [9037-69-8] activity was totally inhibited in the presence of 50 Î¼mol/L PZ 51. In vivo expts. with Se-deficient mice showed that the Se-moiety of PZ 51 is not available for the synthesis of the selenoenzyme GSH-Px after dietary treatment or i.p. doses up to 25 mg Se as PZ 51 per kg body wt. After oral administration of labeled PZ 51, unlike with selenite, no radioactivity was incorporated into GSH-Px within 48 h. The data suggest that several similarities between PZ 51 and the active site of GSH-Px exist, resulting in the capability of the compd. to catalyze the GSH-Px reaction. An extracellular pharmacodynamic action of the drug seems likely.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2MXjvFKitw%253D%253D&md5=a1475814e1a0c5ab4599dd82235b2993

        19
        A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound - III. Effects of PZ 51 (ebselen) on glutathione peroxidase and secretory activities of mouse macrophages
        Parnham, Michael J.; Kindt, Sabine
        Biochemical Pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3247-50CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
        PZ 51 (I) a selenium-contg. compd. with glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px)-like activity, was administered to selenium-deficient mice for 5 days. A significant increase in peritoneal macrophage GSH-Px activity after treatment was only obsd. when basal GSH-Px activity was almost zero (i.e. in 19 wk selenium-deficient animals), possibly due to binding of PZ 51 to the macrophages. This indicates that PZ 51 releases very little, if any, free selenium for incorporation into endogenous GSH-Px. The compd. in vitro exerted a concn.-dependent inhibition of the generation of chemiluminescence by resident mouse peritoneal macrophages and a partial inhibition of the prodn. of prostaglandin E2 by resident peritoneal macrophages. Î²-Glucuronidase prodn. by C. parvum-activated peritoneal macrophages was unaffected by PZ 51. These in vitro data can be explained on the basis of a selective peroxide scavenging and/or GSH-Px-like activity of PZ 51, offering a novel approach to anti-inflammatory therapy.

        A novel biologically active seleno-organic compound--I. Glutathione peroxidase-like activity in vitro and antioxidant capacity of PZ 51 (Ebselen)
        Muller A; Cadenas E; Graf P; Sies H
        Biochemical pharmacology (1984), 33 (20), 3235-9 ISSN:0006-2952.
        a synthetic seleno-organic compound, 2-phenyl-1,2-benzoisoselenazol-3(2H)-one (PZ 51), exhibits GSH peroxidase-like activity in vitro, in contrast to its sulfur analog, PZ 25. In addition, PZ 51 behaves as an antioxidant shown by a temporary protection of rat liver microsomes against ascorbate/ADP-Fe-induced lipid peroxidation, an effect also elicited by PZ 25 but to a smaller extent. This protection against lipid peroxidation is independent of GSH and of P-450 monooxygenase activity.

      21. 21
        Martini, F.; Rosa, S. G.; Klann, I. P.; Fulco, B. C. W.; Carvalho, F. B.; Rahmeier, F. L.; Fernandes, M. C.; Nogueira, C. W. A multifunctional compound ebselen reverses memory impairment, apoptosis and oxidative stress in a mouse model of sporadic Alzheimerâs disease. J. Psychiatr. Res. 2019, 109, 107â 117, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2018.11.021
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        21
        A multifunctional compound ebselen reverses memory impairment, apoptosis and oxidative stress in a mouse model of sporadic Alzheimer's disease
        Martini Franciele; Rosa Suzan Goncalves; Klann Isabella Pregardier; Fulco Bruna Cruz Weber; Carvalho Fabiano Barbosa; Rahmeier Francine Luciano; Fernandes Marilda Cruz; Nogueira Cristina Wayne
        Journal of psychiatric research (2019), 109 (), 107-117 ISSN:.
        Alzheimer 's disease (AD) is characterized by progressive cognitive decline including memory impairment, cortical dysfunction, and neuropsychiatric disturbances. The drug discovery to treat AD consists to develop compounds able to act in multiple molecular targets involved in the pathogenesis of the disease and the repositioning of old drugs for new application. This way, the intracerebroventricular (icv) injection of streptozotocin (STZ) has been used as a metabolic model of sporadic AD. The aim of the present study was to investigate whether ebselen (1-10 mg/kg), a multifunctional selenoorganic compound, ameliorates memory impairment, hippocampal oxidative stress, apoptosis and cell proliferation in a mouse model of sporadic AD induced by icv STZ (3 mg/kg, 1 Î¼l/min). The administration of ebselen (10 mg/kg, i.p.) reversed memory impairment and hippocampal oxidative stress, by increasing the activities of antioxidant enzymes and the level of a non-enzymatic antioxidant defense, in Swiss mice administered with icv STZ. The anti-apoptotic property of ebselen was demonstrated by its effectiveness against the increase in the ratios of Bax/Bcl-2, cleaved PARP/PARP and the cleaved caspase-3 levels in the hippocampus of icv STZ mice. Although ebselen reversed memory impairment, it was ineffective against the reduction in the number of BrdU positive cells induced by icv STZ. In conclusion, the multifunctional selenoorganic compound ebselen was effective to reverse memory impairment, hippocampal oxidative stress and apoptosis in a mouse model of sporadic AD induced by icv STZ.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3crpt1KjsA%253D%253D&md5=3d86850110eb7986c65035f3c5e29f16

        Chen, Z.; Jiang, Z.; Chen, N.; Shi, Q.; Tong, L.; Kong, F.; Cheng, X.; Chen, H.; Wang, C.; Tang, B. Target discovery of ebselen with a biotinylated probe. Chem. Commun. (Cambridge, U. K.) 2018, 54, 9506â 9509, Â DOI: 10.1039/C8CC04258F
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        22
        Target discovery of ebselen with a biotinylated probe
        Chen, Zhenzhen; Jiang, Zhongyao; Chen, Nan; Shi, Qian; Tong, Lili; Kong, Fanpeng; Cheng, Xiufen; Chen, Hao; Wang, Chu; Tang, Bo
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2018), 54 (68), 9506-9509CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Despite numerous studies on ebselen over the past decade, its cellular targets remain obscure. Here we synthesized a biotinylated ebselen probe (biotin-ebselen) and characterized ebselen-binding proteins via an efficient activity-based protein profiling (ABPP) method, which allowed for the robust identification of 462 targeted proteins in HeLa cells. This first work of global target profiling of ebselen will be helpful to re-design ebselen-based therapy appropriately in clin. trials.

        Parnham, M. J.; Sies, H. The early research and development of ebselen. Biochem. Pharmacol. 2013, 86, 1248â 1253, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bcp.2013.08.028
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        23
        The early research and development of ebselen
        Parnham, Michael J.; Sies, Helmut
        Biochemical Pharmacology (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2013), 86 (9), 1248-1253CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Ebselen (2-phenyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one; PZ-51, DR-3305), is an organoselenium compd. with glutathione peroxidase (GPx)-like, thiol-dependent, hydroperoxide reducing activity. As an enzyme mimic for activity of the selenoenzyme GPx, this compd. has proved to be highly useful in research on mechanisms in redox biol. Furthermore, the reactivity of ebselen with protein thiols has helped to identify novel, selective targets for inhibitory actions on several enzymes of importance in pharmacol. and toxicol. Importantly, the selenium in ebselen is not released and thus is not bioavailable, ebselen metabolites being excreted in bile and urine. As a consequence, initial concerns about selenium toxicity, fortunately, were unfounded. Potential applications in medical settings have been explored, notably in brain ischemia and stroke. More recently, there has been a surge in interest as new medical applications have been taken into consideration. The first publication on the biochem. effects of ebselen appeared 30 years ago, which prompted the authors to retrace the early development from their perspective. It is a fascinating example of fruitful interaction between research-oriented industry and academia.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVylu7fN&md5=76722e2600ba62e2f6be8334593c1c05
      24. 24
        Noguchi, N. Ebselen, a useful tool for understanding cellular redox biology and a promising drug candidate for use in human diseases. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2016, 595, 109â 112, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.abb.2015.10.024
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        24
        Ebselen, a useful tool for understanding cellular redox biology and a promising drug candidate for use in human diseases
        Noguchi, Noriko
        Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics (2016), 595 (), 109-112CODEN: ABBIA4; ISSN:0003-9861. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Ebselen is an organoselenium compd. with glutathione peroxidase (GPx)-like hydroperoxide reducing activity. Moreover, ebselen has its own unique reactivity, with functions that GPx does not have, since it reacts with many kinds of thiols other than glutathione. Ebselen may affect the thioredoxin systems, through which it may contribute to regulation of cell function. With high reactivity toward thiols, hydroperoxides, and peroxynitrite, ebselen has been used as a useful tool in research on cellular redox mechanisms. Unlike Î±-tocopherol, ebselen does not scavenge lipid peroxyl radicals, which is another advantage of ebselen for use as a research tool in comparison with radical scavenging antioxidants. Selenium is not released from the ebselen mol., which explains the low toxicity of ebselen. To further understand the mechanism of cellular redox biol., it should be interesting to compare the effects of ebselen with that of selenoprotein P, which supplies selenium to GPx. New medical applications of ebselen as a drug candidate for human diseases such as cancer and diabetes mellitus as well as brain stroke and ischemia will be expected.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmtleisL0%253D&md5=1296b21fdafafec78648801c59adc9dc
      25. 25
        Azad, G. K.; Tomar, R. S. Ebselen, a promising antioxidant drug: mechanisms of action and targets of biological pathways. Mol. Biol. Rep. 2014, 41, 4865â 4879, Â DOI: 10.1007/s11033-014-3417-x
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        25
        Ebselen, a promising antioxidant drug: mechanisms of action and targets of biological pathways
        Azad, Gajendra Kumar; Tomar, Raghuvir S.
        Molecular Biology Reports (2014), 41 (8), 4865-4879CODEN: MLBRBU; ISSN:0301-4851. (Springer)
        A review. Ebselen, an organoselenium compd., mimics glutathione peroxidase activity. It is a multifunctional compd., which catalyzes several essential reactions for the protection of cellular components from oxidative and free radical damage. Based on a no. of in vitro and in vivo studies, various mechanisms are proposed to understand the biomedical actions of ebselen in health and diseases. It modulates metallo-proteins, enzymic cofactors, gene expression, epigenetics, antioxidant defenses and immune systems. Owing to these properties, ebselen is currently under clin. trials for the prevention and treatment of various disorders such as cardiovascular diseases, arthritis, stroke, atherosclerosis, and cancer. A few ebselen-based pharmaceutical agents are under extensive investigation. As ebselen has been shown to have significant cellular toxicity, appropriate studies are needed to redesign the ebselen-based therapy for clin. trials. This review summarizes current understanding of the biochem. and mol. properties, and pharmacol. applications of ebselen and future directions in this area of research.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXos1Gntbw%253D&md5=9592c6d44387e26927af07e3c7d39b9c

        Santofimia-CastaÃ±o, P.; Izquierdo-Alvarez, A.; Plaza-Davila, M.; Martinez-Ruiz, A.; Fernandez-Bermejo, M.; Mateos-Rodriguez, J. M.; Salido, G. M.; Gonzalez, A. Ebselen impairs cellular oxidative state and induces endoplasmic reticulum stress and activation of crucial mitogen-activated protein kinases in pancreatic tumour AR42J cells. J. Cell. Biochem. 2018, 119, 1122â 1133, Â DOI: 10.1002/jcb.26280
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        26
        Ebselen impairs cellular oxidative state and induces endoplasmic reticulum stress and activation of crucial mitogen-activated protein kinases in pancreatic tumour AR42J cells
        Santofimia-Castano, Patricia; Izquierdo-Alvarez, Alicia; Plaza-Davila, Maria; Martinez-Ruiz, Antonio; Fernandez-Bermejo, Miguel; Mateos-Rodriguez, Jose M.; Salido, Gines M.; Gonzalez, Antonio
        Journal of Cellular Biochemistry (2018), 119 (1), 1122-1133CODEN: JCEBD5; ISSN:0730-2312. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        Ebselen (2-phenyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one) is an organoselenium radical scavenger compd., which has strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. However, evidence suggests that this compd. could exert deleterious actions on cell physiol. In this study, we have analyzed the effect of ebselen on rat pancreatic AR42J cells. Cytosolic free-Ca2+ concn. ([Ca2+]c), cellular oxidative status, setting of endoplasmic reticulum stress, and phosphorylation of major mitogen-activated protein kinases were analyzed. Our results show that ebselen evoked a concn.-dependent increase in [Ca2+]c. The compd. induced an increase in the generation of reactive oxygen species in the mitochondria. We also obsd. an increase in global cysteine oxidn. in the presence of ebselen. In the presence of ebselen an impairment of cholecystokinin-evoked amylase release was noted. Moreover, involvement of the unfolded protein response markers, ER chaperone and signaling regulator GRP78/BiP, eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2Î± and X-box binding protein 1 was detected. Finally, increases in the phosphorylation of SAPK/JNK, p38 MAPK, and p44/42 MAPK in the presence of ebselen were also obsd. Our results provide evidences for an impairment of cellular oxidative state and enzyme secretion, the induction of endoplasmic reticulum stress and the activation of crucial mitogen-activated protein kinases in the presence of ebselen. As a consequence ebselen exerts a potential toxic effect on AR42J cells.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhs1SksbzN&md5=24ed1266651fcc6e434e41b6279e61bc

        Zhang, L.; Zhou, L.; Du, J.; Li, M.; Qian, C.; Cheng, Y.; Peng, Y.; Xie, J.; Wang, D. Induction of apoptosis in human multiple myeloma cell lines by ebselen via enhancing the endogenous reactive oxygen species production. BioMed Res. Int. 2014, 2014, 696107, Â DOI: 10.1155/2014/696107
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        27
        Induction of apoptosis in human multiple myeloma cell lines by ebselen via enhancing the endogenous reactive oxygen species production
        Zhang Liang; Zhou Liwei; Du Jia; Li Mengxia; Qian Chengyuan; Cheng Yi; Peng Yang; Xie Jiayin; Wang Dong
        BioMed research international (2014), 2014 (), 696107 ISSN:.
        Ebselen a selenoorganic compound showing glutathione peroxidase like activity is an anti-inflammatory and antioxidative agent. Its cytoprotective activity has been investigated in recent years. However, experimental evidence also shows that ebselen causes cell death in several cancer cell types whose mechanism has not yet been elucidated. In this study, we examined the effect of ebselen on multiple myeloma (MM) cell lines in vitro. The results showed that ebselen significantly enhanced the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) accompanied by cell viability decrease and apoptosis rate increase. Further studies revealed that ebselen can induce Bax redistribution from the cytosol to mitochondria leading to mitochondrial membrane potential ÎÎ¨m changes and cytochrome C release from the mitochondria to cytosol. Furtherly, we found that exogenous addition of N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) completely diminished the cell damage induced by ebselen. This result suggests that relatively high concentration of ebselen can induce MM cells apoptosis in culture by enhancing the production of endogenous ROS and triggering mitochondria mediated apoptotic pathway.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2cvpvVWjtA%253D%253D&md5=22d209ef9051e3a5eb15d39dd08775ed
      28. 28
        Hanavan, P. D.; Borges, C. R.; Katchman, B. A.; Faigel, D. O.; Ho, T. H.; Ma, C.-t.; Sergienko, E. A.; Meurice, N.; Petit, J. L.; Lake, D. F. Ebselen inhibits QSOX1 enzymatic activity and suppresses invasion of pancreatic and renal cancer cell lines. Oncotarget 2015, 6, 18418â 18428, Â DOI: 10.18632/oncotarget.4099
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        28
        Ebselen inhibits QSOX1 enzymatic activity and suppresses invasion of pancreatic and renal cancer cell lines
        Hanavan Paul D; Lake Douglas F; Borges Chad R; Katchman Benjamin A; Faigel Douglas O; Ho Thai H; Meurice Nathalie; Petit Joachim L; Ma Chen-Ting; Sergienko Eduard A
        Oncotarget (2015), 6 (21), 18418-28 ISSN:.
        Quiescin sulfhydryl oxidase 1 (QSOX1) is a highly conserved disulfide bond-generating enzyme that is overexpressed in diverse tumor types. Its enzymatic activity promotes the growth and invasion of tumor cells and alters extracellular matrix composition. In a nude mouse-human tumor xenograft model, tumors containing shRNA for QSOX1 grew significantly more slowly than controls, suggesting that QSOX1 supports a proliferative phenotype in vivo. High throughput screening experiments identified ebselen as an in vitro inhibitor of QSOX1 enzymatic activity. Ebselen treatment of pancreatic and renal cancer cell lines stalled tumor growth and inhibited invasion through Matrigel in vitro. Daily oral treatment with ebselen resulted in a 58% reduction in tumor growth in mice bearing human pancreatic tumor xenografts compared to controls. Mass spectrometric analysis of ebselen-treated QSOX1 mechanistically revealed that C165 and C237 of QSOX1 covalently bound to ebselen. This report details the anti-neoplastic properties of ebselen in pancreatic and renal cancer cell lines. The results here offer a "proof-of-principle" that enzymatic inhibition of QSOX1 may have clinical relevancy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC28%252Fhs1ertQ%253D%253D&md5=7b5f38602a2396a04779bdb1fe504417
      29. 29
        Thabet, N.; Moustafa, E. Synergistic effect of ebselen and gamma radiation on breast cancer cells. Int. J. Radiat. Biol. 2017, 93, 784â 792, Â DOI: 10.1080/09553002.2017.1325024
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        29
        Synergistic effect of Ebselen and gamma radiation on breast cancer cells
        Thabet, Noura M.; Moustafa, Enas M.
        International Journal of Radiation Biology (2017), 93 (8), 784-792CODEN: IJRBE7; ISSN:0955-3002. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        Purpose: To explore the synergistic effect of a seleno-org. compd. Ebselen (Ebs) and/or Î³-radiation to exert antitumor effects on human breast cancer (MCF-7) cell line in vitro. Materials and methods: Ebs cytotoxicity at various concns. (10, 25, 50 and 75 Î¼g), cell proliferation and clonogenic assay of Ebs and/or Î³-radiation (at 1, 3 and 6 Gy), expression of p-IÎºBÎ± and NF-ÎºB, inflammatory cytokines levels (TNF-Î±, IL-2, INF-Î³, IL-10 and TGF-Î²), apoptotic factors (Caspase-3, Granzyme-B and TRAIL) and angiogenic factor (VEGF) were investigated. Results: The results showed that the effective dosage of this combination was obsd. at 25 Î¼g/mL of Ebs with Î³-radiation at 6 Gy. Data displayed a significant redn. in NF-ÎºB mRNA along with an elevation in granzyme-B mRNA and TRAIL mRNA expression. Furthermore, protein expression of caspase-3 was elevated, whereas p-IÎºBÎ± and p-NF-ÎºB(p65) protein expression was reduced significantly. Also, a significant decline in TNF-Î±, IL-2, INF-Î³, TGF-Î² with a significant increase in IL-10 levels were revealed. Meanwhile, a significant decrease in VEGF level and proliferation capacity were obsd. Conclusions: We conclude that a combination of Ebs with radiotherapy has a major antitumor efficiency in inducing apoptosis and inhibiting cancer cell progression, due to the synergistic effect in regulating gene and protein expression, and in a modulating response of pro-and anti-inflammatory cytokines.

        Ye, S. F.; Li, J.; Ji, S. M.; Zeng, H. H.; Lu, W. Dose-biomarker-response modeling of the anticancer effect of ethaselen in a human non-small cell lung cancer xenograft mouse model. Acta Pharmacol. Sin. 2017, 38, 223â 232, Â DOI: 10.1038/aps.2016.114
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        30
        Dose-biomarker-response modeling of the anticancer effect of ethaselen in a human non-small cell lung cancer xenograft mouse model
        Ye, Suo-fu; Li, Jian; Ji, Shuang-min; Zeng, Hui-hui; Lu, Wei
        Acta Pharmacologica Sinica (2017), 38 (2), 223-232CODEN: APSCG5; ISSN:1671-4083. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) is a component of several redox-sensitive signaling cascades that mediate important biol. processes such as cell survival, maturation, growth, migration and inhibition of apoptosis. The expression levels of TrxR1 in some human carcinoma cell lines are nearly 10 times higher than those in normal cells. Ethaselen is a novel antitumor candidate that exerts potent inhibition on non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) by targeting TrxR. In this study we explored the relationship between the ethaselen dose and TrxR activity level and the relationship between TrxR degrdn. and tumor apoptosis in a human lung carcinoma A549 xenograft model. BALB/c nude mice implanted with human NSCLC cell line A54 were administered ethaselen (36, 72, 108 mgÂ·kg-1Â·d-1, ig) or vehicle for 10 d. The tumor size and TrxR activity levels in tumor tissues were daily recorded and detected. Based on the exptl. data, NONMEM 7.2 was used to develop an integrated dose-biomarker-response model for describing the quant. relationship between ethaselen dose and tumor eradication effects. The time course of TrxR activity levels was modeled using an indirect response model (IDR model), in which the influence of the tumor growth rates on Kin with the linear correction factor Î³1 (0.021 d/mm). The drug binding-inhibition effects on Kout was described using a sigmoidal Emax model with Smax (5.95), SC50 (136 mg/kg) and Hill's coeff. Î³2 (2.29). The influence of TrxR activity inhibition on tumor eradication was characterized by an Emax model with an Emax (130 mm3/d) and EC50 (0.0676). This model was further validated using a visual predictive check (VPC) and was used to predict the efficacy of different doses. In conclusion, the properties and characteristics of ethaselen acting on TrxR degrdn. and subsequently resulting in tumor apoptosis are characterized by the IDR model and integrated dose-biomarker-response model with high goodness-of-fit and great predicative ability. This approach shed new light on the detailed processes and mechanism of ethaselen action and may offer a valuable ref. for an appropriate dosing regimen for use in further clin. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXitFemu70%253D&md5=44d18ca03808ccd049b7a3e3e9aea222
      31. 31
        Zheng, X.; Xu, W.; Sun, R.; Yin, H.; Dong, C.; Zeng, H. Synergism between thioredoxin reductase inhibitor ethaselen and sodium selenite in inhibiting proliferation and inducing death of human non-small cell lung cancer cells. Chem.-Biol. Interact. 2017, 275, 74â 85, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.cbi.2017.07.020
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        31
        Synergism between thioredoxin reductase inhibitor ethaselen and sodium selenite in inhibiting proliferation and inducing death of human non-small cell lung cancer cells
        Zheng, Xiaoqing; Xu, Wei; Sun, Ruoxuan; Yin, Hanwei; Dong, Chaoran; Zeng, Huihui
        Chemico-Biological Interactions (2017), 275 (), 74-85CODEN: CBINA8; ISSN:0009-2797. (Elsevier Ireland Ltd.)
        New effective treatment for human non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is needed. The thioredoxin (Trx) system composes of thioredoxin reductase (TrxR), Trx and NADPH. In this study, we combined an org. selenium compd.--TrxR inhibitor ethaselen (BBSKE) with low dosage sodium selenite to inhibit proliferation and induce death of NSCLC cells, and identified underlying mechanisms. Synergistic anti-proliferation effect of BBSKE and selenite was found in human NSCLC cell lines, A549, NCI-H1299 and NCI-1266. A significant increase of apoptosis, necrosis and autophagy were obsd. in the group of BBSKE plus selenite in A549 cells. The autophagy induced by BBSKE and selenite inhibited apoptosis and necrosis. In addn., BBSKE plus selenite induced G2/M arrest, which was verified by the alteration of gene and protein expression of cell cycle regulatory complexes. The intracellular enzyme activity of TrxR was remarkably decreased by cotreatment of BBSKE and selenite. Besides, the mRNA and protein level of TrxR1 and Trx1 were significantly inhibited by cotreatment of BBSKE and selenite. HEK 293 cells overexpressing TrxR1 were more sensitive to BBSKE plus selenite. The nuclear translocation of Trx1 and Ref-1, as well as expression of Ref-1 and AP-1 were inhibited by combination treatment. In short, BBSKE synergizes selenite in inhibiting proliferation and inducing death of NSCLC cells; BBSKE combined with selenite may be a treatment strategy for NSCLC.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1OhsrbO&md5=72836b3fd29501295b99d449f1af1f3f
      32. 32
        Zheng, X.; Zhang, Y.; Zhang, L.; Xu, W.; Ma, W.; Sun, R.; Zeng, H. Synergistic inhibition of sunitinib and ethaselen against human colorectal cancer cells proliferation. Biomed. Pharmacother. 2016, 83, 212â 220, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.biopha.2016.06.040
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        32
        Synergistic inhibition of sunitinib and ethaselen against human colorectal cancer cells proliferation
        Zheng, Xiaoqing; Zhang, Yunhan; Zhang, Lei; Xu, Wei; Ma, Weiwei; Sun, Ruoxuan; Zeng, Huihui
        Biomedicine & Pharmacotherapy (2016), 83 (), 212-220CODEN: BIPHEX; ISSN:0753-3322. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Sunitinib, a multi-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, has been widely used in the therapy of advanced renal cell cancer and imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors. However, little benefits could be obtained from sunitinib for patients with other types of solid tumors including colorectal cancer (CRC). Ethaselen (BBSKE), a specific thioredoxin reductase 1 inhibitor, has shown convincing anticancer effects both in vivo and in vitro. In this study, we explored the combinatory effect of sunitinib and BBSKE in human CRC cell lines LoVo, HT-29 and RKO. Cotreatment of BBSKE and sunitinib with the ratio of 2:1 for 24 h displayed synergistic effect against CRC cells proliferation. Apoptosis anal. also revealed that combination treatment of BBSKE and sunitinib (2:1) for 24 h induced higher apoptosis rate than either single treatment. The synergistic effect against LoVo cells proliferation may be explained by sharp redn. of Bcl-2/Bax protein expression ratio, decrease of pro-Caspase-3 protein expression along with significantly augmented Caspase-3 enzymic activity, and release of cytochrome C from mitochondria to cytoplasm in the combination treatment group. The significant inhibition of vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2) phosphorylation might also account for the synergism in cotreatment group. In short, sunitinib plus BBSKE is perhaps a promising strategy for colorectal cancer therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFWht73I&md5=35e1dd73f9e370306ecc8f8dc17e6d99

        Ye, S. F.; Yang, Y.; Wu, L.; Ma, W. W.; Zeng, H. H. Ethaselen: a novel organoselenium anticancer agent targeting thioredoxin reductase 1 reverses cisplatin resistance in drug-resistant K562 cells by inducing apoptosis. J. Zhejiang Univ., Sci., B 2017, 18, 373â 382, Â DOI: 10.1631/jzus.B1600073
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        33
        Ethaselen: a novel organoselenium anticancer agent targeting thioredoxin reductase 1 reverses cisplatin resistance in drug-resistant K562 cells by inducing apoptosis
        Ye, Suo-fu; Yang, Yong; Wu, Lin; Ma, Wei-wei; Zeng, Hui-Hui
        Journal of Zhejiang University, Science, B (2017), 18 (5), 373-382CODEN: JZUSAM; ISSN:1673-1581. (Springer)
        It has been reported that Ethaselen shows inhibitory effects on thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) activity and human tumor cell growth. In order to find an efficient way to reverse cisplatin resistance, we investigated the reversal effects of Ethaselen on cisplatin resistance in K562/cisplatin (CDDP) cells that were established by pulse-inducing human erythrocyte leukemic cell line K562, which are fivefold more resistant to cisplatin compared to K562 cells. The morphol. and growth showed that the adhesion of K562/CDDP further decreased while the cell vol. increased. The proliferation of K562/CDDP is strengthened. The antitumor activities in vitro were assessed by MTT (3-(4,5- dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay and combination index (CI), showing the significant synergic effects of cisplatin and Ethaselen. Focusing on apoptosis, a series of comparisons was made between K562 and K562/CDDP. Cisplatin induced higher reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation in K562 and subsequently induced the formation of mitochondrial permeability transition pores (PTPs). In addn., cisplatin increased the ratio of Bax to Bcl-2 in K562, which can influence the mitochondrial membrane permeability. PTP formation and mitochondrial membrane permeabilization eventually resulted in the release of cytochrome c and activation of the Caspase pathway. However, these effects were not clearly seen in K562/CDDP, which may be the reason for the acquired CDDP resistance. However, Ethaselen can induce a high level of ROS in K562/CDDP by TrxR activity inhibition and increased ratio of Bax to Bcl-2 in K562/CDDP by nuclear factor ÎºB (NF-ÎºB) suppression, which subsequently induces the release of cytochrome c in K562/CDDP. This response is partly responsible for the reversal of the cisplatin resistance in K562/CDDP cells.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXnsVarsL0%253D&md5=5a37af3e551326fe6ec06f4c25ef1da6
      34. 34
        Zheng, X. Q.; Chen, Y. F.; Bai, M.; Liu, Y. X.; Xu, B. Y.; Sun, R. X.; Zeng, H. H. The antimetastatic effect and underlying mechanisms of thioredoxin reductase inhibitor ethaselen. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2019, 131, 7â 17, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2018.11.030
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        34
        The antimetastatic effect and underlying mechanisms of thioredoxin reductase inhibitor ethaselen
        Zheng, Xiaoqing; Chen, Yifan; Bai, Man; Liu, Yuxi; Xu, Binyuan; Sun, Ruoxuan; Zeng, Huihui
        Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2019), 131 (), 7-17CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Treating cancer metastasis is of vital importance to prolong patients' survival. Thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) is overexpressed in many cancer types and has been recognized as an anticancer target. The organoselenium compd. ethaselen (BBSKE) has been proved to be a TrxR inhibitor and inhibit various types of tumor growth. However, whether BBSKE could inhibit tumor metastasis remains unclear. In this study, the authors aim to explore the antimetastatic effect of BBSKE and underlying mechanisms. BBSKE was found to dose-dependently suppress migration and invasion of MCF-7 and LoVo cells in vitro. The underlying mechanisms may include inhibition of TrxR activity, elevation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), decrease of EGFR activation and HER2 expression. Besides, the epithelial to mesenchymal transition process and expression of CD44, MMP-9, VEGFR2 and PD-L1 were also abrogated. Decreased migration and invasion, lower expression levels of EGFR, HER2, N-cadherin, CD44, MMP-9, VEGFR2 and PD-L1 were also obsd. in TrxR1-knockdown MCF-7 and LoVo cells. In the mouse breast cancer 4T1 model, BBSKE not only inhibited progression of primary tumor, but also suppressed formation of metastatic lung nodules and liver micro-metastases, indicating that BBSKE could effectively abolish tumor metastasis. In conclusion, the findings show that BBSKE is able to inhibit migration and invasion of cancer cells in vitro and in vivo, and may be used to prevent and treat metastasis.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitl2it7zN&md5=f634374d0a08160fa0a9dda5ff816725

        Yan, J.; Guo, Y.; Wang, Y.; Mao, F.; Huang, L.; Li, X. Design, synthesis, and biological evaluation of benzoselenazole-stilbene hybrids as multi-target-directed anti-cancer agents. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2015, 95, 220â 229, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2015.03.030
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        35
        Design, synthesis, and biological evaluation of benzoselenazole-stilbene hybrids as multi-target-directed anti-cancer agents
        Yan, Jun; Guo, Yueyan; Wang, Yali; Mao, Fei; Huang, Ling; Li, Xingshu
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 95 (), 220-229CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        To identify novel multi-target-directed drug candidates for the treatment of cancer, a series of benzoselenazole-stilbene hybrids I [ R1 = H, OMe; R2 = H, OMe; R3 = H, OMe; R4 = H, OMe, Cl; R5 = H, OMe, F, Cl.] were synthesized by combining the pharmacophores of resveratrol and ebselen. The biol. assay indicated that all of the hybrids exhibited antiproliferative activities against four human cancer cell lines and demonstrated good TrxR inhibitory activities. The mechanism of cell apoptosis was investigated in G2/M cell cycle arrest induced by compd. I [ R1 = R2 = OMe, R3 = R4 = R5 = H] and the apoptosis of the human liver carcinoma Bel-7402 cell line. The significant increase in intracellular ROS confirmed that compd. I [ R1 = R2 = OMe, R3 = R4 = R5 = H] was capable of causing oxidative stress-induced apoptosis in cancer cells. Our results support the potential of compd. I [ R1 = R2 = OMe, R3 = R4 = R5 = H] as a candidate for further studies examg. the development of novel drugs for cancer treatment.

        Synthesis and antiproliferative evaluation of novel 1,2,4-triazole derivatives incorporating benzisoselenazolone scaffold
        Li, Bao-Lin; Li, Bo; Zhang, Rui-Lian; Zhao, Ji-Jun; Wang, Xue-Feng; Liu, Yu-Ming; Shi, Yan-Ping; Liu, Jin-Biao; Chen, Bao-Quan
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2016), 26 (4), 1279-1281CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of novel 1,2,4-triazole derivs. incorporating benzisoselenazolone scaffold were designed, synthesized and evaluated for their in vitro antiproliferative activities against human cancer cell lines SMMC-7721, HeLa, A549, and normal cell lines L929 by CCK-8 assay. The preliminary bioassay results demonstrated that most of the tested compds. exhibited antiproliferative activity with different degrees and some compds. showed better effects than pos. controls 2,2'-(1,2-ethanediyl)bis[1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one] (i.e., ethaselen) and 5-fluorouracil (i.e., 5-FU) against various cancer cell lines. Several compds. displayed highly effective biol. activity against SMMC-7721 cells with IC50 values of 6.02 and 6.01 Î¼M, resp. One compd. showed significant y antiproliferative activities against HeLa cells with IC50 value of 3.94 Î¼M. One compd. exhibited the best inhibitory effect against A549 cells with IC50 value 9.14 Î¼M. Furthermore, most of the tested compds. showed weak cytotoxic effect against the normal cell lines L929. The pharmacol. results suggest that the substituent groups are vital for improving the potency and selectivity of this class of compds. The synthesis of the target compds. was achieved by a reaction of 2-(chloroseleno)benzoyl chloride with 5-(alkylthio)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-amine derivs. The title compds. thus formed included [[(alkyl)thio]triazolyl]-1,2-benzisoselenazolone derivs. (ebselen analogs, ethaselen analogs).

        Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Novel 1,3,4-thiadiazole Derivatives Incorporating Benzisoselenazolone Scaffold as Potential Antitumor Agents
        Fu, Xiaoyun; Li, Sha; Jing, Fen; Wang, Xuefeng; Li, Baolin; Zhao, Jijun; Liu, Yuming; Chen, Baoquan
        Medicinal Chemistry (Sharjah, United Arab Emirates) (2016), 12 (7), 631-639CODEN: MCEHAJ; ISSN:1573-4064. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        Background: Based on the biol. signicance of benzisoselenazolone and 1,3,4-thiadiazole, a series of novel 1,3,4-thiadiazole derivs. incorporating benzisoselenazolone scaffold were designed and synthesized with ebselen as a lead compd. Methods: Meanwhile, their in vitro antitumor activities were evaluated against SMMC-7721, MCF-7 and A549 human cancer cell lines by CCK-8 assay. Results: The preliminary bioassay results demonstrated that all tested compds. 4a-q showed potent antitumor activities, and some compds. exhibited better effects than pos. control ethaselen and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) against various cancer cell lines. Furthermore, compds. 4b and 4m showed significant antitumor activities against SMMC-7721 cells with IC50 values of 1.89 and 1.89 M, resp. Compds. 4c and 4n displayed highly effective biol. activities against MCF-7 cells with IC50 values of 2.88 and 2.28 M, resp. Compd. 4i showed the best inhibitory effect against A549 cells with IC50 value of 1.76 M. Conclusion: The pharmacol. results suggest that the substituent groups of Ph ring on the 1,3,4-thiadiazole are vital for modulating antitumor activities against various cancer cell lines.

I (R = H, 2-CH3, 3-OCH3, 4-Br, 2-NO2, etc.) showed potent antiproliferative activity, and some compds. exhibited better effects than pos. control ethaselen and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) against various cancer cell lines. I (R = F) exhibited the best inhibitory effect against A549 cells with an IC50 value of 1.03 Î¼M.

        New chiral ebselen analogues with antioxidant and cytotoxic potential
        Pacula, Agata J.; Kaczor, Katarzyna B.; Antosiewicz, Jedrzej; Janecka, Anna; Dlugosz, Angelika; Janecki, Tomasz; Wojtczak, Andrzej; Scianowski, Jacek
        Molecules (2017), 22 (3), 492/1-492/14CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
        New chiral camphane-derived benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones and corresponding diselenides was synthesized using a convenient one-pot procedure. Se-N bond was efficiently converted to an Se-Se bond, which could also be easily re-oxidized to the initial benzisoselenazolone moiety. The antioxidant activity of camphor derivs. was evaluated and compared to the reactivity of a series of N-amino acid benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones obtained by a modified procedure involving the improved synthesis and isolation of the diseleno bis(dibenzoic) acid. The most efficient peroxide scavengers, N-bornyl and N-leucine Me ester benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones, were further evaluated as cytotoxic agents on four cancer cell lines (MCF-7, HEP G2, HL 6, and DU 145) and normal cell line PNT1A. The highest antiproliferative potential was evaluated for two compds. bearing a 3- methylbutyl carbon chain, N-leucine Me ester and N-3-methylbutyl benzisoselenazol- 3(2H)-ones.

        Kumar, S.; Yan, J. J.; Poon, J. F.; Singh, V. P.; Lu, X.; Ott, M. K.; Engman, L.; Kumar, S. Multifunctional antioxidants: Regenerable radical-trapping and hydroperoxide-decomposing ebselenols. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 3729â 3733, Â DOI: 10.1002/anie.201510947

        Multifunctional Antioxidants: Regenerable Radical-Trapping and Hydroperoxide-Decomposing Ebselenols
        Kumar, Shailesh; Yan, Jiajie; Poon, Jia-fei; Singh, Vijay P.; Lu, Xi; Karlsson Ott, Marjam; Engman, Lars; Kumar, Sangit
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (11), 3729-3733CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Regenerable, multifunctional ebselenol antioxidants were prepd. that could quench peroxyl radicals more efficiently than Î±-tocopherol. These compds. act as better mimics of the glutathione peroxidase enzymes than ebselen. Prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) in human mononuclear cells was considerably decreased upon exposure to the organoselenium compds. At a concn. of 25 Î¼M, the ebselenol derivs. showed minimal toxicity in pre-osteoblast MC3T3 cells.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        Nitro-, Azo-, and Amino Derivatives of Ebselen: Synthesis, Structure, and Cytoprotective Effects
        Singh, Vijay P.; Poon, Jia-fei; Yan, Jiajie; Lu, Xi; Ott, Marjam Karlsson; Butcher, Ray J.; Gates, Paul J.; Engman, Lars
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2017), 82 (1), 313-321CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Novel azo-bis-ebselen compds. I [R = Ph, 4-MeC6H4, 4-MeOC6H4, 1-naphthyl] were prepd. by redn. of 7-nitro-2-aryl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones II with sodium benzenetellurolate, NaTeC6H5, and by reaction of 2-bromo-3-nitrobenzamides with Na2Se2. The X-ray structure of I [R = 4-MeC6H4] showed that the mol., due to strong intramol. secondary Seâ¢â¢â¢N interactions, is completely planar. Azo-compds. I upon further reaction with NaTeC6H5 were reductively cleaved to provide two equiv. of the corresponding arom. amine. The weak Se-N bond was not stable enough to survive the reaction conditions and diselenides III [R = 4-MeC6H4, 1-naphthyl] were isolated after work-up. Whereas azo-bis-ebselens I were poor mimics of the glutathione peroxidase (GPx)-enzymes, nitroebselens II and IV and diselenides III were 3-6 fold more active than ebselen. Based on 77Se NMR spectroscopy, a catalytic cycle for diselenide III [R = 1-naphthyl], involving aminoebselen V, was proposed. As assessed by chemiluminescence measurements, the good GPx-mimics could reduce prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in stimulated human mononuclear cells more efficiently than Trolox. No toxic effects of the compds. were seen in MC3T3-cells at 25 Î¼M.

        Wang, Y.; Wallach, J.; Duane, S.; Wang, Y.; Wu, J.; Wang, J.; Adejare, A.; Ma, H. Developing selective histone deacetylases (HDACs) inhibitors through ebselen and analogs. Drug Des., Dev. Ther. 2017, 11, 1369â 1382, Â DOI: 10.2147/DDDT.S124977

        Developing selective histone deacetylases (HDACs) inhibitors through ebselen and analogs
        Wang, Yuren; Wallach, Jason; Duane, Stephanie; Wang, Yuan; Wu, Jianghong; Wang, Jeffrey; Adejare, Adeboye; Ma, Haiching
        Drug Design, Development and Therapy (2017), 11 (), 1369-1382CODEN: DDDTAQ; ISSN:1177-8881. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
        Histone deacetylases (HDACs) are key regulators of gene expression in cells and have been investigated as important therapeutic targets for cancer and other diseases. Different subtypes of HDACs appear to play disparate roles in the cells and are assocd. with specific diseases. Therefore, substantial effort has been made to develop subtype-selective HDAC inhibitors. In an effort to discover existing scaffolds with HDAC inhibitory activity, we screened a drug library approved by the US Food and Drug Administration and a National Institutes of Health Clin. Collection compd. library in HDAC enzymic assays. Ebselen, a clin. safe compd., was identified as a weak inhibitor of several HDACs, including HDAC1, HDAC3, HDAC4, HDAC5, HDAC6, HDAC7, HDAC8, and HDAC9 with half maximal inhibitory concns. approx. single digit of Î¼M. Two ebselen analogs, ebselen oxide and ebsulfur (a diselenide analog of ebselen), also inhibited these HDACs, however with improved potencies on HDAC8. Benzisothiazol, the core structure of ebsulfur, specifically inhibited HDAC6 at a single digit of Î¼M but had no inhibition on other HDACs. Further efforts on structure-activity relationship based on the core structure of ebsulfur led to the discovery of a novel class of potent and selective HDAC6 inhibitors with RBC-2008 as the lead compd. with single-digit nM potency. This class of histone deacetylase inhibitor features a novel pharmacophore with an ebsulfur scaffold selectively targeting HDAC6. Consistent with its inhibition on HDAC6, RBC-2008 significantly increased the acetylation levels of Î±-tubulin in PC-3 cells. Furthermore, treatment with these compds. led to cell death of multiple tumor cell lines in a dose-dependent manner. These results demonstrated that ebselen and ebsulfur analogs are inhibitors of HDACs, supporting further preclin. development of this class of compds. for potential therapeutic applications.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslKns7rM&md5=7c71fca15cacf6026275682e886245b2
