        Ebselen and analogs as inhibitors of Bacillus anthracis thioredoxin reductase and bactericidal antibacterials targeting Bacillus species, Staphylococcus aureus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
        Gustafsson, Tomas N.; Osman, Harer; Werngren, Jim; Hoffner, Sven; Engman, Lars; Holmgren, Arne
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2016), 1860 (6), 1265-1271CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax, a disease assocd. with a very high mortality rate in its invasive forms. We studied a no. of ebselen analogs as inhibitors of B. anthracis thioredoxin reductase and their antibacterial activity on Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The most potent compds. in the series gave IC50 values down to 70 nM for the pure enzyme and minimal inhibitory concns. (MICs) down to 0.4 Î¼M (0.12 Î¼g/mL) for B. subtilis, 1.5 Î¼M (0.64 Î¼g/mL) for S. aureus, 2 Î¼M (0.86 Î¼g/mL) for B. cereus and 10 Î¼g/mL for M. tuberculosis. Minimal bactericidal concns. (MBCs) were found at 1-1.5 times the MIC, indicating a general, class-dependent, bactericidal mode of action. The combined bacteriol. and enzymol. data were used to construct a preliminary structure-activity-relationship for the benzoisoselenazol class of compds. When S. aureus and B. subtilis were exposed to ebselen, we were unable to isolate resistant mutants on both solid and in liq. medium suggesting a high resistance barrier. These results suggest that ebselen and analogs thereof could be developed into a novel antibiotic class, useful for the treatment of infections caused by B. anthracis, S. aureus, M. tuberculosis and other clin. important bacteria. Furthermore, the high barrier against resistance development is encouraging for further drug development. We have characterized the thioredoxin system from B. anthracis as a novel drug target and ebselen and analogs thereof as a potential new class of antibiotics targeting several important human pathogens.

        Thermal and Photoinduced Copper-Promoted C-Se Bond Formation: Synthesis of 2-Alkyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones and Evaluation against Mycobacterium tuberculosis
        Thanna, Sandeep; Goins, Christopher M.; Knudson, Susan E.; Slayden, Richard A.; Ronning, Donald R.; Sucheck, Steven J.
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2017), 82 (7), 3844-3854CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        2-Alkyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones, represented by ebselen (1a), are being studied intensively for a range of medicinal applications. We describe both a new thermal and photoinduced copper-mediated cross-coupling between potassium selenocyanate (KSeCN) and N-substituted ortho-halobenzamides to form 2-alkyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones contg. a C-Se-N bond. The copper ligand (1,10-phenanthroline) facilitates C-Se bond formation during heating via a mechanism that likely involves atom transfer (AT), whereas, in the absence of ligand, photoinduced activation likely proceeds through a single electron transfer (SET) mechanism. A library of 15 2-alkyl-1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-ones was prepd. One member of the library was azide-contg. deriv. 1j that was competent to undergo a strain-promoted azide-alkyne cycloaddn. The library was evaluated for inhibition of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) growth and Mtb Antigen 85C (Mtb Ag85C) activity. Compd. 1f was most potent with a minimal inhibitory concn. (MIC) of 12.5 Î¼g/mL and an Mtb Ag85C apparent IC50 of 8.8 Î¼M.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        84
        Exploring covalent allosteric inhibition of antigen 85C from Mycobacterium tuberculosis by ebselen derivatives
        Goins, Christopher M.; Dajnowicz, Steven; Thanna, Sandeep; Sucheck, Steven J.; Parks, Jerry M.; Ronning, Donald R.
        ACS Infectious Diseases (2017), 3 (5), 378-387CODEN: AIDCBC; ISSN:2373-8227. (American Chemical Society)
        Previous studies identified ebselen as a potent in vitro and in vivo inhibitor of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) antigen 85 (Ag85) complex, comprising three homologous enzymes required for the biosynthesis of the mycobacterial cell wall. In this study, the Mtb Ag85C enzyme was cocrystd. with azido and adamantyl ebselen derivs., resulting in two crystallog. structures of 2.01 and 1.30 Ã resoln., resp. Both structures displayed the anticipated covalent modification of the solvent accessible, noncatalytic Cys209 residue forming a selenenylsulfide bond. Continuous difference d. for both thiol modifiers allowed for the assessment of interactions that influence ebselen binding and inhibitor orientation that were unobserved in previous Ag85C ebselen structures. The kinact/KI values for ebselen, adamantyl ebselen, and azido ebselen support the importance of obsd. constructive chem. interactions with Arg239 for increased in vitro efficacy toward Ag85C. To better understand the in vitro kinetic properties of these ebselen derivs., the energetics of specific protein-inhibitor interactions and relative reaction free energies were calcd. for ebselen and both derivs. using d. functional theory. These studies further support the different in vitro properties of ebselen and two select ebselen derivs. from our previously published ebselen library with respect to kinetics and protein-inhibitor interactions. In both structures, the Î±9 helix was displaced farther from the enzyme active site than the previous Ag85C ebselen structure, resulting in the restructuring of a connecting loop and imparting a conformational change to residues believed to play a role in substrate binding specific to Ag85C. These notable structural changes directly affect protein stability, reducing the overall melting temp. by up to 14.5 Â°C, resulting in the unfolding of protein at physiol. temps. Addnl., this structural rearrangement due to covalent allosteric modification creates a sizable solvent network that encompasses the active site and extends to the modified Cys209 residue. In all, this study outlines factors that influence enzyme inhibition by ebselen and its derivs. while further highlighting the effects of the covalent modification of Cys209 by said inhibitors on the structure and stability of Ag85C. Furthermore, the results suggest a strategy for developing new classes of Ag85 inhibitors with increased specificity and potency.

        Xu, L.; Gong, C.; Li, G.; Wei, J.; Wang, T.; Meng, W.; Shi, M.; Wang, Y. Ebselen suppresses inflammation induced by Helicobacter pylori lipopolysaccharide via the p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase signaling pathway. Mol. Med. Rep. 2018, 17, 6847â 6851, Â DOI: 10.3892/mmr.2018.8641

        Ebselen suppresses inflammation induced by Helicobacter pylori lipopolysaccharide via the p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase signaling pathway
        Xu, Ling; Gong, Changguo; Li, Guangming; Wei, Jue; Wang, Ting; Meng, Wenying; Shi, Min; Wang, Yugang
        Molecular Medicine Reports (2018), 17 (5), 6847-6851CODEN: MMROA5; ISSN:1791-3004. (Spandidos Publications Ltd.)
        Ebselen is a seleno-org. compd. that has been demonstrated to have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. A previous study detd. that ebselen inhibits airway inflammation induced by inhalational lipopolysaccharide (LPS), however, the underlying mol. mechanism remains to be elucidated. The present study investigated the effect of ebselen on the glutathione peroxidase (GPX)-reactive oxygen species (ROS) pathway and interleukin-8 (IL-8) expression induced by Helicobacter pylori LPS in gastric cancer (GC) cells. Cells were treated with 200 ng/mL H. pylori-LPS in the presence or absence of ebselen for various durations and concns. (Î¼mol/l). The expression of toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), GPX2, GPX4, p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (p38 MAPK), phosphorylated-p38 MAPK, ROS prodn. and IL-8 expression were detected with western blotting or ELISA. The present study revealed that TLR4 expression was upregulated; however, GPX2 and GPX4 expression was reduced following treatment with H. pylori LPS, which led to increased ROS prodn., subsequently altering the IL-8 expression level in GC cells. Addnl., it was detd. that ebselen prevented the redn. in GPX2/4 levels induced by H. pylori LPS, however, TLR4 expression was not affected. Ebselen may also block the expression of IL-8 by inhibiting phosphorylation of p38 MAPK. These data suggest ebselen may inhibit ROS prodn. triggered by H. pylori LPS treatment via GPX2/4 instead of TLR4 signaling and reduce phosphorylation of p38 MAPK, resulting in altered prodn. of IL-8. Ebselen may, therefore, be a potential therapeutic agent to mediate H. pylori LPS-induced cell damage.

        Zou, L.; Lu, J.; Wang, J.; Ren, X.; Zhang, L.; Gao, Y.; Rottenberg, M. E.; Holmgren, A. Synergistic antibacterial effect of silver and ebselen against multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections. EMBO Mol. Med. 2017, 9, 1165â 1178, Â DOI: 10.15252/emmm.201707661
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        88
        Synergistic antibacterial effect of silver and ebselen against multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections
        Zou, Lili; Lu, Jun; Wang, Jun; Ren, Xiaoyuan; Zhang, Lanlan; Gao, Yu; Rottenberg, Martin E.; Holmgren, Arne
        EMBO Molecular Medicine (2017), 9 (8), 1165-1178CODEN: EMMMAM; ISSN:1757-4684. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        Multidrug-resistant (MDR) Gram-neg. bacteria account for a majority of fatal infections, and development of new antibiotic principles and drugs is therefore of outstanding importance. Here, we report that five most clin. difficult-to-treat MDR Gram-neg. bacteria are highly sensitive to a synergistic combination of silver and ebselen. In contrast, silver has no synergistic toxicity with ebselen on mammalian cells. The silver and ebselen combination causes a rapid depletion of glutathione and inhibition of the thioredoxin system in bacteria. Silver ions were identified as strong inhibitors of Escherichia coli thioredoxin and thioredoxin reductase, which are required for ribonucleotide reductase and DNA synthesis and defense against oxidative stress. The bactericidal efficacy of silver and ebselen was further verified in the treatment of mild and acute MDR E. coli peritonitis in mice. These results demonstrate that thiol-dependent redox systems in bacteria can be targeted in the design of new antibacterial drugs. The silver and ebselen combination offers a proof of concept in targeting essential bacterial systems and might be developed for novel efficient treatments against MDR Gram-neg. bacterial infections.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpsFSqur0%253D&md5=308903f6cbcf5644372e3d64920c5b4d

        Jin, W. B.; Xu, C.; Cheng, Q.; Qi, X. L.; Gao, W.; Zheng, Z.; Chan, E. W. C.; Leung, Y. C.; Chan, T. H.; Wong, K. Y.; Chen, S.; Chan, K. F. Investigation of synergistic antimicrobial effects of the drug combinations of meropenem and 1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one derivatives on carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae producing NDM-1. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 155, 285â 302, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2018.06.007

        89
        Investigation of synergistic antimicrobial effects of the drug combinations of meropenem and 1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one derivatives on carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae producing NDM-1
        Jin, Wen Bin; Xu, Chen; Cheng, Qipeng; Qi, Xiao Lin; Gao, Wei; Zheng, Zhiwei; Chan, Edward W. C.; Leung, Yun-Chung; Chan, Tak Hang; Wong, Kwok-Yin; Chen, Sheng; Chan, Kin-Fai
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 155 (), 285-302CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        The worldwide prevalence of NDM-1-producing bacteria has drastically undermined the clin. efficacy of the last line antibiotic of carbapenems, prompting a need to devise effective strategy to preserve their clin. value. Our previous studies have shown that ebselen can restore the efficacy of meropenem against a lab. strain that produces NDM-1. Here we report the construction of a focused compd. library of 1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one derivs. which comprise a total of forty-six candidate compds. The structure-activity relationship of these compds. and their potential to serve as an adjuvant to enhance the antimicrobial efficacy of meropenem against a collection of clin. NDM-1-producing carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae isolates was examd. Drug combination assays indicated that these derivs. exhibited synergistic antimicrobial activity when used along with meropenem, effectively restoring the activity of carbapenems against the resistant strains tested in a Galleria mellonella larvae in vivo infection model. The mode of inhibition of one compd., namely 11_a38, which was depicted when tested on the purified NDM-1 enzyme, indicated that it could covalently bind to the enzyme and displaced one zinc ion from the active site. Overall, this study provides a novel 1,2-benzisoselenazol-3(2H)-one scaffold that exhibits strong synergistic antimicrobial activity with carbapenems, and low cytotoxicity. The prospect of application of such compds. as carbapenem adjuvants warrants further evaluation.

        AbdelKhalek, A.; Abutaleb, N. S.; Mohammad, H.; Seleem, M. N. Repurposing ebselen for decolonization of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE). PLoS One 2018, 13, e0199710, Â DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0199710
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        90
        Repurposing ebselen for decolonization of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE)
        AbdelKhalek, Ahmed; Abutaleb, Nader S.; Mohammad, Haroon; Seleem, Mohamed N.
        PLoS One (2018), 13 (6), e0199710/1-e0199710/14CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
        Enterococci represent one of the microbial world's most challenging enigmas. Colonization of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) of high-risk/immunocompromised patients by enterococci exhibiting resistance to vancomycin (VRE) can lead to life-threating infections, including bloodstream infections and endocarditis. Decolonization of VRE from the GIT of high-risk patients represents an alternative method to suppress the risk of the infection. It could be considered as a preventative measure to protect against VRE infections in high-risk individuals. Though multiple agents (ramoplanin and bacitracin) have been evaluated clin., no drugs are currently approved for use in VRE decolonization of the GIT. The present study evaluates ebselen, a clin. mol., for use as a decolonizing agent against VRE. When evaluated against a broad array of enterococcal isolates in vitro, ebselen was found to be as potent as linezolid (min. inhibitory concn. against 90% of clin. isolates tested was 2 Î¼g/mL). Though VRE has a remarkable ability to develop resistance to antibacterial agents, no resistance to ebselen emerged after a clin. isolate of vancomycin-resistant E. faecium was serially-passaged with ebselen for 14 days. Against VRE biofilm, a virulence factor that enables the bacteria to colonize the gut, ebselen demonstrated the ability to both inhibit biofilm formation and disrupt mature biofilm. Furthermore, in a murine VRE colonization redn. model, ebselen proved as effective as ramoplanin in reducing the bacterial shedding and burden of VRE present in the fecal content (by > 99.99%), cecum, and ileum of mice. Based on the promising results obtained, ebselen warrants further investigation as a novel decolonizing agent to quell VRE infection.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvFait7jO&md5=8c992314d7bc28fe7d41d3d18626f6c5
      91. 91
        May, H. C.; Yu, J. J.; Guentzel, M. N.; Chambers, J. P.; Cap, A. P.; Arulanandam, B. P. Repurposing auranofin, ebselen, and PX-12 as antimicrobial agents targeting the thioredoxin system. Front. Microbiol. 2018, 9, 336, Â DOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2018.00336
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        91
        Repurposing Auranofin, Ebselen, and PX-12 as Antimicrobial Agents Targeting the Thioredoxin System
        May Holly C; Yu Jieh-Juen; Guentzel M N; Chambers James P; Arulanandam Bernard P; May Holly C; Yu Jieh-Juen; Guentzel M N; Chambers James P; Arulanandam Bernard P; Cap Andrew P
        Frontiers in microbiology (2018), 9 (), 336 ISSN:1664-302X.
        As microbial resistance to drugs continues to rise at an alarming rate, finding new ways to combat pathogens is an issue of utmost importance. Development of novel and specific antimicrobial drugs is a time-consuming and expensive process. However, the re-purposing of previously tested and/or approved drugs could be a feasible way to circumvent this long and costly process. In this review, we evaluate the U.S. Food and Drug Administration tested drugs auranofin, ebselen, and PX-12 as antimicrobial agents targeting the thioredoxin system. These drugs have been shown to act on bacterial, fungal, protozoan, and helminth pathogens without significant toxicity to the host. We propose that the thioredoxin system could serve as a useful therapeutic target with broad spectrum antimicrobial activity.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MnivVWqtQ%253D%253D&md5=5143dcfa510396a56a1700799ec9c20a

      93. 93
        Thangamani, S.; Eldesouky, H. E.; Mohammad, H.; Pascuzzi, P. E.; Avramova, L.; Hazbun, T. R.; Seleem, M. N. Ebselen exerts antifungal activity by regulating glutathione (GSH) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in fungal cells. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 2017, 1861, 3002â 3010, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bbagen.2016.09.029
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        93
        Ebselen exerts antifungal activity by regulating glutathione (GSH) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in fungal cells
        Thangamani, Shankar; Eldesouky, Hassan E.; Mohammad, Haroon; Pascuzzi, Pete E.; Avramova, Larisa; Hazbun, Tony R.; Seleem, Mohamed N.
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (2017), 1861 (1_Part_A), 3002-3010CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Ebselen, an organoselenium compd. and a clin. safe mol. has been reported to possess potent antifungal activity, but its antifungal mechanism of action and in vivo antifungal activity remain unclear. The antifungal effect of ebselen was tested against Candida albicans, C. glabrata, C. tropicalis, C. parapsilosis, Cryptococcus neoformans, and C. gattii clin. isolates. Chemogenomic profiling and biochem. assays were employed to identify the antifungal target of ebselen. Ebselen's antifungal activity in vivo was investigated in a Caenorhabditis elegans animal model. Ebselen exhibits potent antifungal activity against both Candida spp. and Cryptococcus spp., at concns. ranging from 0.5 to 2 Î¼g/mL. Ebselen rapidly eradicates a high fungal inoculum within 2 h of treatment. Investigation of the drug's antifungal mechanism of action indicates that ebselen depletes intracellular glutathione (GSH) levels, leading to increased prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and thereby disturbs the redox homeostasis in fungal cells. Examn. of ebselen's in vivo antifungal activity in two Caenorhabditis elegans models of infection demonstrate that ebselen is superior to conventional antifungal drugs (fluconazole, flucytosine and amphotericin) in reducing Candida and Cryptococcus fungal load. Ebselen possesses potent antifungal activity against clin. relevant isolates of both Candida and Cryptococcus by regulating GSH and ROS prodn. The potent in vivo antifungal activity of ebselen supports further investigation for repurposing it for use as an antifungal agent.. The present study shows that ebselen targets glutathione and also support that glutathione as a potential target for antifungal drug development.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1ajsLrP&md5=c2503ad29a4ab169d4f58e5857c1307a
      94. 94
        Venturini, T. P.; Chassot, F.; Loreto, E. S.; Keller, J. T.; Azevedo, M. I.; Zeni, G.; Santurio, J. M.; Alves, S. H. Antifungal activities of diphenyl diselenide and ebselen alone and in combination with antifungal agents against Fusarium spp. Med. Mycol. 2016, 54, 550â 555, Â DOI: 10.1093/mmy/myv120
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        94
        Antifungal activities of diphenyl diselenide and ebselen alone and in combination with antifungal agents against Fusarium spp
        Venturini, Tarcieli Pozzebon; Chassot, Francieli; Loreto, Erico Silva; Keller, Jessica Tairine; Azevedo, Maria Izabel; Zeni, Gilson; Santurio, Janio Morais; Alves, Sydney Hartz
        Medical Mycology (2016), 54 (5), 550-555CODEN: MEMYFR; ISSN:1369-3786. (Oxford University Press)
        Herein, we describe the in vitro activity of a combination of the organoselenium compds. di-Ph diselenide and ebselen alone and in combination with amphotericin B, caspofungin, itraconazole, and voriconazole against 25 clin. isolates of Fusarium spp. For this anal., we used the broth microdilution method based on the M38-A2 technique and checkerboard microdilution method. Di-Ph diselenide (MIC range = 4-32 Î¼g/mL) and ebselen (MIC range = 2-8 Î¼g/mL) showed in vitro activity against the isolates tested. The most effective combinations were (synergism rates): ebselen + amphotericin B (88%), ebselen + voriconazole (80%), di-Ph diselenide + amphotericin B (72%), and di-Ph diselenide + voriconazole (64%). Combination with caspofungin resulted in low rates of synergism: ebselen + caspofungin, 36%, and di-Ph diselenide + caspofungin, 28%; combination with itraconazole demonstrated indifferent interactions. Antagonistic effects were not obsd. for any of the combinations tested. Our findings suggest that the antifungal potential of di-Ph diselenide and ebselen deserves further investigation in in vivo exptl. models, esp. in combination with amphotericin B and voriconazole.

        Eltahan, R.; Guo, F.; Zhang, H.; Xiang, L.; Zhu, G. Discovery of ebselen as an inhibitor of Cryptosporidium parvum glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (CpGPI) by high-throughput screening of existing drugs. Int. J. Parasitol.: Drugs Drug Resist. 2018, 8, 43â 49, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ijpddr.2018.01.003
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        97
        Discovery of ebselen as an inhibitor of Cryptosporidium parvum glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (CpGPI) by high-throughput screening of existing drugs
        Eltahan Rana; Guo Fengguang; Zhang Haili; Xiang Lixin; Zhu Guan
        International journal for parasitology. Drugs and drug resistance (2018), 8 (1), 43-49 ISSN:.
        Cryptosporidium parvum is a water-borne and food-borne apicomplexan pathogen. It is one of the top four diarrheal-causing pathogens in children under the age of five in developing countries, and an opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised individuals. Unlike other apicomplexans, C. parvum lacks Kreb's cycle and cytochrome-based respiration, thus relying mainly on glycolysis to produce ATP. In this study, we characterized the primary biochemical features of the C. parvum glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (CpGPI) and determined its Michaelis constant towards fructose-6-phosphate (Km = 0.309 mM, Vmax = 31.72 nmol/Î¼g/min). We also discovered that ebselen, an organoselenium drug, was a selective inhibitor of CpGPI by high-throughput screening of 1200 known drugs. Ebselen acted on CpGPI as an allosteric noncompetitive inhibitor (IC50 = 8.33 Î¼M; Ki = 36.33 Î¼M), while complete inhibition of CpGPI activity was not achieved. Ebselen could also inhibit the growth of C. parvum in vitro (EC50 = 165 Î¼M) at concentrations nontoxic to host cells, albeit with a relatively small in vitro safety window of 4.2 (cytotoxicity TC50 on HCT-8 cells = 700 Î¼M). Additionally, ebselen might also target other enzymes in the parasite, leading to the parasite growth reduction. Therefore, although ebselen is useful in studying the inhibition of CpGPI enzyme activity, further proof is needed to chemically and/or genetically validate CpGPI as a drug target.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1Mvos12msQ%253D%253D&md5=cc0135747a87c15169c6f94aba7101b6
      98. 98
        Gordhan, H. M.; Patrick, S. L.; Swasy, M. I.; Hackler, A. L.; Anayee, M.; Golden, J. E.; Morris, J. C.; Whitehead, D. C. Evaluation of substituted ebselen derivatives as potential trypanocidal agents. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2017, 27, 537â 541, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2016.12.021
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        98
        Evaluation of substituted ebselen derivatives as potential trypanocidal agents
        Gordhan, Heeren M.; Patrick, Stephen L.; Swasy, Maria I.; Hackler, Amber L.; Anayee, Mark; Golden, Jennifer E.; Morris, James C.; Whitehead, Daniel C.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2017), 27 (3), 537-541CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Human African trypanosomiasis is a disease of sub-Saharan Africa, where millions are at risk for the illness. The disease, commonly referred to as African sleeping sickness, is caused by an infection by the eukaryotic pathogen, Trypanosoma brucei. Previously, a target-based high throughput screen revealed ebselen (EbSe), and its sulfur analog, EbS, to be potent in vitro inhibitors of the T. brucei hexokinase 1 (TbHK1). These mols. also exhibited potent trypanocidal activity in vivo. In this manuscript, we synthesized a series of sixteen EbSe and EbS derivs. bearing electron-withdrawing carboxylic acid and Me ester functional groups, and evaluated the influence of these substituents on the biol. efficacy of the parent scaffold. With the exception of one Me ester deriv., these modifications ablated or blunted the potent TbHK1 inhibition of the parent scaffold. Nonetheless, a few of the Me ester derivs. still exhibited trypanocidal effects with single-digit micromolar or high nanomolar EC50 values.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVyltQ%253D%253D&md5=98d0198882e5c9aeabdad4cf16660994

        Felli Kubica, T.; Bedin Denardi, L.; Silva de Loreto, E.; Zeni, G.; Weiblen, C.; Oliveira, V.; Morais Santurio, J.; Hartz Alves, S. In vitro activity of diphenyl diselenide and ebselen alone and in combination with antifungal agents against Trichosporon asahii. Mycoses 2019, 62, 428â 433, Â DOI: 10.1111/myc.12906
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        99
        In vitro activity of diphenyl diselenide and ebselen alone and in combination with antifungal agents against Trichosporon asahii
        Felli Kubica, Thais; Bedin Denardi, Laura; Silva de Loreto, Erico; Zeni, Gilson; Weiblen, Carla; Oliveira, Vanessa; Morais Santurio, Janio; Hartz Alves, Sydney
        Mycoses (2019), 62 (5), 428-433CODEN: MYCSEU; ISSN:1439-0507. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        Summary : This study evaluated the in vitro susceptibility of Trichosporon asahii strains to di-Ph diselenide (DPDS) and ebselen (EBS) alone and in combination with amphotericin B (AMB), fluconazole (FCZ), itraconazole (ITZ) and caspofungin (CAS) using the microdilution method. EBS showed in vitro activity against T asahii strains with minimal inhibitory concn. (MIC) ranged from 0.25 to 8.0 Î¼g/mL. For DPDS, the MIC ranged from 8.0 to 64 Î¼g/mL. The combinations demonstrating the greatest synergism rate against fluconazole-resistant T asahii strains were the following: CAS + DPDS (96.67%), AMB + DPDS (93.33%), FCZ + DPDS (86.67%) and ITZ + DPDS (83.33%). The combinations AMB + DPDS and AMB + EBS exhibited the highest synergism rate against the fluconazole-susceptible (FS) T asahii strains (90%). Antagonism was obsd. in the following combinations: FCZ + EBS (80%) and FCZ + DPDS (13.33%) against the FS strains, and ITZ + EBS (20%) against the FR strains. Our findings suggest that the antimicrobial activity of DPDS and EBS against T. asahii and its use as an adjuvant therapy with antifungal agents warrant in vivo exptl. investigation.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXnsV2ktL8%253D&md5=75c857326f4754f1d9121b2249709437

        Debnath, A.; Nelson, A. T.; Silva-Olivares, A.; Shibayama, M.; Siegel, D.; McKerrow, J. H. In vitro efficacy of ebselen and BAY 11-7082 against Naegleria fowleri. Front. Microbiol. 2018, 9, 414, Â DOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2018.00414
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        100
        In Vitro Efficacy of Ebselen and BAY 11-7082 Against Naegleria fowleri
        Debnath Anjan; McKerrow James H; Nelson Andrew T; Siegel Dionicio; Silva-Olivares Angelica; Shibayama Mineko
        Frontiers in microbiology (2018), 9 (), 414 ISSN:1664-302X.
        Primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is a fatal infection caused by the free-living ameba Naegleria fowleri, popularly known as the "brain-eating ameba." The drugs of choice in treating PAM are the antifungal amphotericin B and an antileishmanial miltefosine, but these are not FDA-approved for this indication and use of amphotericin B is associated with severe adverse effects. Moreover, very few patients treated with the combination therapy have survived PAM. Therefore, development of efficient drugs is a critical unmet need to avert future deaths of children. Since N. fowleri causes extensive inflammation in the brain it is important to select compounds that can enter brain to kill ameba. In this study, we identified two central nervous system (CNS) active compounds, ebselen and BAY 11-7082 as amebicidal with EC50 of 6.2 and 1.6 Î¼M, respectively. The closely related BAY 11-7085 was also found active against N. fowleri with EC50 similar to BAY 11-7082. We synthesized a soluble ebselen analog, which had amebicidal activity similar to ebselen. Transmission electron microscopy of N. fowleri trophozoites incubated for 48 h with EC50 concentration of ebselen showed alteration in the cytoplasmic membrane, loss of the nuclear membrane, and appearance of electron-dense granules. Incubation of N. fowleri trophozoites with EC50 concentrations of BAY 11-7082 and BAY 11-7085 for 48 h showed the presence of large lipid droplets in the cytoplasm, disruption of cytoplasmic and nuclear membranes and appearance of several vesicles and chromatin residues. Blood-brain barrier permeable amebicidal compounds have potential as new drug leads for Naegleria infection.

        Synthesis, antimicrobial evaluation and theoretical prediction of NMR chemical shifts of thiazole and selenazole derivatives with high antifungal activity against Candida spp.

        Journal of Molecular Structure (2016), 1108 (), 427-437CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Synthesis and investigation of antimicrobial activities of novel (E)-thiazoles and (E)-selenazoles I (R = CH3, 4-O2NC6H4, CH2CO2CH2CH3, etc.; R1 = CO2CH2CH3, H; X = S, Se) is presented. I. Among the derivs., compds. I (R = 4-FC6H4, 4-CH3C6H4, CH2CO2CH2CH3, 2,4-F2C6H3, CH3; R1 = H; X = S) Candida albicans ATCC and Candida parapsilosis ATCC 22019 with MIC = 0.49-7.81Î¼g/mL. I (R = 4-FC6H4, 4-OCH3C6H4, 4-CH3C6H4, CH2CO2CH2CH3, CH3; R1 = H; X = S), the activity was very strong against of Candida spp. isolated from clin. materials, i.e. C. albicans, Candida krusei, Candida inconspicua, Candida famata, Candida lusitaniae, Candida sake, C. parapsilosis and Candida dubliniensis with MIC = 0.24-15.62 Î¼g/mL.         Synthesis, antimicrobial and anticonvulsant screening of small library of tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran-4-yl based thiazoles and selenazoles
        Laczkowski, Krzysztof Z.; Biernasiuk, Anna; Baranowska-Laczkowska, Angelika; Zielinska, Sylwia; Salat, Kinga; Furgala, Anna; Misiura, Konrad; Malm, Anna
        Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2016), 31 (sup2), 24-39CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        Synthesis and investigation of antimicrobial activity of 22 novel thiazoles and selenazoles derived from dihydro-2H-thiopyran-4(3H)-one are presented. I (X = S, Se; R = F, Cl) demonstrate a statistically significant anticonvulsant activity in the pentylenetetrazole model, whereas compds. and showed protection in 6-Hz psychomotor seizure model. Noteworthy, none of these compds. I (X = S, Se; R = F) impaired animals' motor skills in the rotarod test. We also performed quantum chem. calcn. of interaction and binding energies in complex of I (X = S; R = F) with cyclodextrin.

        Angeli, A.; Trallori, E.; Ferraroni, M.; Di Cesare Mannelli, L.; Ghelardini, C.; Supuran, C. T. Discovery of new 2, 5-disubstituted 1,3-selenazoles as selective human carbonic anhydrase IX inhibitors with potent anti-tumor activity. Eur. J. Med.         103
        Discovery of new 2,5-disubstituted 1,3-selenazoles as selective human carbonic anhydrase IX inhibitors with potent anti-tumor activity
        Angeli, Andrea; Trallori, Elena; Ferraroni, Marta; Di Cesare Mannelli, Lorenzo; Ghelardini, Carla; Supuran, Claudiu T.
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 157 (), 1214-1222CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of disubstituted selenazole derivs. was synthesized and evaluated as carbonic anhydrase (CA, EC 4.2.1.1) inhibitors against the human (h) isoforms hCA I, II, IV, VA, VB and IX, involved in a variety of diseases including glaucoma, retinitis pigmentosa, epilepsy, arthritis and tumors. The investigated compds. showed potent inhibition against the tumor-assocd. transmembrane hCA IX, with KIs in the subnanomolar low nanomolar range, and were evaluated for their effects on cell viability against the human prostate (PC3) and breast (MDA-MB-231) cancer cell lines, showing effective anti-tumor activity. These selenazoles are interesting leads for the development of new, isoform-selective CA IX inhibitors.

        Mbaveng, A. T.; Ignat, A. G.; Ngameni, B.; Zaharia, V.; Ngadjui, B. T.; Kuete, V. In vitro antibacterial activities of p-toluenesulfonyl-hydrazinothiazoles and hydrazinoselenazoles against multi-drug resistant Gram-negative phenotypes. BMC Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2016, 17, 3, Â DOI: 10.1186/s40360-016-0046-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        104
        In vitro antibacterial activities of p-toluenesulfonyl-hydrazinothiazoles and hydrazinoselenazoles against multi-drug resistant Gram-negative phenotypes
        Mbaveng, Armelle T.; Ignat, Adriana Grozav; Ngameni, Bathelemy; Zaharia, Valentin; Ngadjui, Bonaventure T.; Kuete, Victor
        BMC Pharmacology and Toxicology (2016), 17 (), 3/1-3/7CODEN: BPTMAB; ISSN:2050-6511. (BioMed Central Ltd.)
        Background: Bacterial multidrug resistance (MDR) constitutes a major hurdle in the treatment of infectious diseases worldwide. The present study was designed to evaluate the antibacterial activities of synthetic p-toluenesulfonyl-hydrazinothiazoles against multidrug resistant Gram-neg. bacteria. Methods: The broth microdilution method was used to det. the minimal inhibitory concns. (MIC). Results: The results demonstrated that the best activities were obtained with hydrazinoselenazoles. p-Chlorobenzyliden- selenosemicarbazide, 4-methyl-2-[(4-chloro-benzyliden)-hydrazinyl]-1,3-selenazole, p-chloro-benzoylselenosemicarbazide and 4-chloromethyl-2-[(4-chlorobenziliden)-N-acetyl-hydrazinyl]-1,3-selenazole were more active than the choramphenicol on Klebsiella pneumoniae KP63. Tested alone, the lowest MIC value of 16 mg/L was obtained with p-methoxy-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide against Enterobacter aerogenes ATCC13048, K. pneumoniae ATCC112296 and KP55. Tested in the presence of an efflux pump inhibitor, phenylalanine arginine Î²-naphthylamide (PAÌI2N), the activity of p-chloro-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide, 4-methyl-2-[(4-chloro-benzyliden)-hydrazinyl]-1,3-selenazole, p-chlorobenzoyl-selenosemicarbazide and p-methoxy-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide significantly increased with MIC values below 10 mg/L obtained resp. on 43.8 %, 31.3 %, 62.5 % and 100 % of the 16 tested bacterial strains. The lowest MIC value of 0.5 mg/L in the presence of PAÎ²N was recorded with p-chloro-benzoyl-selenosemicarbazide against Escherichia coli ATCC8739 and KP55 as well as p-methoxybenzyliden- selenosemicarbazide against E. aerogenes KP55. p-Chloro-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide and p-chloro-benzoyl-selenosemicarbazide contained the same pharmacophore as p-methoxy-benzylidenselenosemicarbazide. Conclusion: This study indicates that p-chloro-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide, p-chloro-benzoyl-selenosemicarbazide and p-methoxy-benzyliden-selenosemicarbazide could be explored more to develop novel antimicrobial drugs to fight MDR bacterial infections.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXls1ejtL8%253D&md5=5d2c32df7b38f113ba3fcbbdc25494b3
      105. 105
        Al-Rubaie, A. Z.; Al-Jadaan, S. A. S.; Muslim, S. K.; Saeed, E. A.; Ali, E. T.; Al-Hasani, A. K. J.; Al-Salman, H. N. K.; Al-Fadal, S. A. M. Synthesis, characterization and antibacterial activity of some new ferrocenyl selenazoles and 3,5-diferrocenyl-1,2,4-selenadiazole. J. Organomet.         [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        105
        Synthesis, characterization and antibacterial activity of some new ferrocenyl selenazoles and 3,5-diferrocenyl-1,2,4-selenadiazole
        Al-Rubaie, Ali Z.; Al-Jadaan, Shaker A. S.; Muslim, Salah K.; Saeed, Eman A.; Ali, Eman T.; Al-Hasani, Amer K. J.; Al-Salman, Hussien N. K.; Al-Fadal, Sabaa A. M.
        Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2014), 774 (), 43-47CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        New ferrocenyl contg. selenazole derivs. were synthesized from reactions of aryl selenocarboxamide (i.e. Ar-C:Se(NH2); Ar = C6H5 (1), 4-Br-C6H4 (2), 4-PhC6H4 (3), 4-CH3OC6H4 (4), 4-CH3SC6H4 (5), 6-MeO-naphthyl (6), 4-MeO-naphthyl (7), 4-C2H5OC6H4 (8), 3,4-(CH3O)2C6H3 (9), and 3,5-(CH3O)2C6H3 (10)) with (2-bromoacetyl)ferrocene. The structures of the new compds. were detd. by elemental analyses, IR, 1H and 13C NMR and mass spectroscopic data. Reaction of 1-cyanoferrocene with sodium hydrogen selenide (NaHSe) in methanol gave the new ferrocenyl selenocarboxamide (11) in 27% yield. Treatment of compd. 11 with a catalytic amt. of Na2[PdCl4] gave 3,5-diferrocenyl-1,2,4-selenadiazole (12) in 35% yield. Both compds. were characterized elemental analyses and spectroscopic techniques. Compds. 1-10 and 12 were screened as antibacterial agents against Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa and showed promising properties.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslOru7%252FF&md5=3c8e3ea3aeb8926cc928720b0c30a267

        Xu, B.-B.; Shi, P.; Guan, Q.-Y.; Shi, X.; Zhao, G.-L. Synthesis, crystal structure, and biological activity of a nickel(II) complex constructed by 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylic acid and 1,10-phenanthroline. J. Coord. Chem. 2013, 66, 2605â 2614, Â DOI: 10.1080/00958972.2013.811497

        Synthesis, crystal structure, and biological activity of a nickel(II) complex constructed by 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylic acid and 1,10-phenanthroline
        Xu, Bao-Bao; Shi, Pei; Guan, Quan-Yin; Shi, Xia; Zhao, Guo-Liang
        Journal of Coordination Chemistry (2013), 66 (15), 2605-2614CODEN: JCCMBQ; ISSN:0095-8972. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
        A nickel(II) complex, [NiL(phen)2]LÂ·5H2O (HL = 2-phenyl-4-selenazolecarboxylic acid, C10H7O2NSe, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), was synthesized and characterized by elemental anal. and IR. The single crystal structure was detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. C88H78N12Ni2O19Se4 crystd. in the triclinic system, space group Pi. The interaction between the complex and the calf thymus DNA was studied by an ethidium bromide fluorescent probe. The antibacterial activities of the complex and ligand against five species of bacteria, Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus and Acinetobacter baumanii, were tested. The anticancer activities of the complex against human pancreatic cancer line PANC-28 and human hepatocarcinoma line HuH7 were also studied by employing an MTT assay.

        Synthesis and antitumor-evaluation of 1,3-selenazole-containing 1,3,4-thiadiazole derivatives
        Zhao, Hai-Chuan; Shi, Yan-Ping; Liu, Yu-Ming; Li, Cai-Wen; Xuan, Li-Na; Wang, Peng; Zhang, Kai; Chen, Bao-Quan
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2013), 23 (24), 6577-6579CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of novel 1,3-selenazole-contg. 1,3,4-thiadiazole derivs. bearing Schiff base moieties were synthesized and evaluated for their in vitro antiproliferative activities against human breast cancer cells MCF-7 and mouse lymphocytic leukemia cells L1210 by CCK-8 assay. The majority of the compds. showed better activity against MCF-7 cells, compared with lead compd. PCS. In particular, compd. I was the most potent compd. with IC50 value of 4.02 Î¼M.

        Zhou, M.; Ji, S.; Wu, Z.; Li, Y.; Zheng, W.; Zhou, H.; Chen, T. Synthesis of selenazolopyridine derivatives with capability to induce apoptosis in human breast carcinoma MCF-7 cells through scavenge of intracellular ROS. Eur. J. Med.         [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        108
        Synthesis of selenazolopyridine derivatives with capability to induce apoptosis in human breast carcinoma MCF-7 cells through scavenge of intracellular ROS
        Zhou, Meiyun; Ji, Shengbin; Wu, Zhaojun; Li, Yiqun; Zheng, Wenjie; Zhou, Hua; Chen, Tianfeng
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 96 (), 92-97CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of selenazolopyridine derivs. have been synthesized and characterized by X-ray diffraction, high resoln. NMR and mass spectroscopy. The in vitro anticancer activities of the synthetic compds. were screened against a panel of human cancer cell lines, human breast carcinoma MCF-7 cells, human liver carcinoma HepG2 cells and L02 normal cell line by MTT assay. By analyzing the structure-activity relationship among the synthetic compds., it was found that 2-(phenylamino)selenazolo[5,4-b]pyridine, (PSeD, 7) had higher growth inhibitory effect on MCF-7 cells. The intracellular mechanism of cell death was evaluated by flow cytometric anal. and ROS assay, which revealed that PSeD could induce MCF-7 cells apoptosis by scavenging intracellular ROS (reactive oxygen species). Taken together, the authors regard PSeD as an antioxidant which could inhibit cancer cell growth through induction of apoptosis.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlslyqurg%253D&md5=0adf84483128fa441d0c2707c52da1a2

        Hong, M.; Yang, Y.; Li, C.; Xu, L.; Li, D.; Li, C.-z. Study of the effect of molecular structure and alkyl groups bound with tin(IV) on their cytotoxicity of organotin(IV) 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylates. RSC Adv. 2015, 5, 102885â 102894, Â DOI: 10.1039/C5RA18445B
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        109
        Study of the effect of molecular structure and alkyl groups bound with tin(IV) on their cytotoxicity of organotin(IV) 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylates
        Hong, Min; Yang, Yuanguang; Li, Chuan; Xu, Lidan; Li, Dacheng; Li, Chen-zhong
        RSC Advances (2015), 5 (124), 102885-102894CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Five organotin(IV) compds. Ph3SnL (1), (R2Sn)4O2L4 [R = n-Bu (2), n-Oct (3)], (R2Sn)4O2L2Cl2 [R = n-Bu (4), Me (5)], have been synthesized from the reactions of 2-phenyl-4-selenazole carboxylic acid (HL) with the corresponding organotin(IV) oxide or chlorides. These compds. have been characterized by elemental anal., IR, 1H, 13C and 119Sn NMR spectroscopy, and single crystal x-ray diffraction anal. Structural studies reveal that compd. 1 exhibits a mononuclear four-coordinated tetrahedral geometry. Differently, the crystal structures of compds. 2-5 reveal the formation of the tetranuclear species contg. a planar Sn4O4 core. All compds. were screened for their in vitro cytotoxic activities toward three cancer cell lines (Caco-2, A549, and HCT-116) and one normal rat hepatocyte cell line (BRL). The results indicate that both di-n-butyltin(IV) and triphenyltin(IV) derivs. not only show excellent cytotoxic activities on cisplatin-sensitive lung cancer cell line A549 and but also exhibit good cytotoxicity against cisplatin-insensitive colon cancer cell lines HCT-116 and Caco-2. Whereas, dimethyltin(IV) and di-n-octyltin(IV) complexes exhibit lower or no cytotoxic activity. The structure-activity relationship of the cytotoxicity of the title complexes has also been discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFWlu7zI&md5=8aaa8f77727d6daaaf1f27f6b694f1e5
      110. 110
        Elshaflu, H.; Todorovic, T. R.; Nikolic, M.; Lolic, A.; Visnjevac, A.; Hagenow, S.; Padron, J. M.; Garcia-Sosa, A. T.; Djordjevic, I. S.; Grubisic, S.; Stark, H.; Filipovic, N. R. Selenazolyl-hydrazones as novel selective MAO inhibitors with antiproliferative and antioxidant activities: experimental and in-silico studies. Front. Chem. 2018, 6, 247, Â DOI: 10.3389/fchem.2018.00247
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        110
        Selenazolyl-hydrazones as novel selective MAO inhibitors with antiproliferative and antioxidant activities: experimental and in-silico studies
        Elshaflu, Hana; Todorovic, Tamara R.; Nikolic, Milan; Lolic, Aleksandar; Visnjevac, Aleksandar; Hagenow, Stefanie; Padron, Jose M.; Garcia-Sosa, Alfonso T.; Djordjevic, Ivana S.; Grubisic, Sonja; Stark, Holger; Filipovic, Nenad R.
        Frontiers in Chemistry (Lausanne, Switzerland) (2018), 6 (), 247/1-247/18CODEN: FCLSAA; ISSN:2296-2646. (Frontiers Media S.A.)
        The novel approach in the treatment of complex multifactorial diseases, such as neurodegenerative disorders and cancer, requires a development of efficient multitargeting oriented drugs. Since oxidative stress significantly contributes to the pathogenesis of cancer and neurodegenerative disorders, potential drug candidates should possess good antioxidant properties. Due to promising biol. activities shown for structurally related (1,3-thiazol-2-yl)hydrazones, a focused library of 12 structurally related benzylidene-based (1,3-selenazol-2-yl)hydrazones was designed as potential multi-targeting compds. Monoamine oxidases (MAO) A/B inhibition properties of this class of compds. have been investigated. Surprisingly, the p-nitrophenyl-substituted (1,3-selenazol-2-yl)hydrazone 4 showed MAO B inhibition in a nanomolar concn. range (IC50 = 73 nM). Excellent antioxidant properties were confirmed in a no. of different in vitro assays. Antiproliferative activity screening on a panel of six human solid tumor cell lines showed that potencies of some of the investigated compds. was comparable or even better than that of the pos. control 5-fluorouracil. In-silico calcns. of ADME properties pointed to promising good pharmacokinetic profiles of investigated compds. Docking studies suggest that some compds., compared to pos. controls, have the ability to strongly interact with targets relevant to cancer such as 5'-nucleotidase, and to neurodegenerative diseases such as the small conductance calcium-activated potassium channel protein 1, in addn. to confirmation of inhibitory binding at MAO B.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFaisbzF&md5=f9512cd703f6b1c05239935efdb3849f

        Guan, Q.; Cheng, Z.; Ma, X.; Wang, L.; Feng, D.; Cui, Y.; Bao, K.; Wu, L.; Zhang, W. Synthesis and bioevaluation of 2-phenyl-4-methyl-1,3-selenazole-5-carboxylic acids as potent xanthine oxidase inhibitors. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2014, 85, 508â 516, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2014.08.014

        112
        Synthesis and bioevaluation of 2-phenyl-4-methyl-1,3-selenazole-5-carboxylic acids as potent xanthine oxidase inhibitors
        Guan, Qi; Cheng, Zengjin; Ma, Xiaoxue; Wang, Lijie; Feng, Dongjie; Cui, Yuanhang; Bao, Kai; Wu, Lan; Zhang, Weige
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 85 (), 508-516CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of 2-phenyl-4-methyl-1,3-selenazole-5-carboxylic acid derivs. were synthesized and evaluated for inhibitory activity against xanthine oxidase in vitro. Structure-activity relationship analyses have also been presented. Most of the target compds. exhibited potency levels in the nanomolar range. Compd. I emerged as the most potent xanthine oxidase inhibitor (IC50 = 5.5 nM) in comparison to febuxostat (IC50 = 18.6 nM). Steady-state kinetics measurements with the bovine milk enzyme indicated a mixed type inhibition with Ki and Ki' values of 0.9 and 2.3 nM, resp. A mol. modeling study on compd. I was performed to gain an insight into its binding mode with xanthine oxidase, and to provide the basis for further structure-guided design of new non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitors related with the 2-phenyl-4-methyl-1,3-selenazole-5-carboxylic acid scaffold.

        Design and synthesis of selenazole-substituted ritonavir analogs
        Qiao, Junfei; Zhao, Chuanfang; Liu, Jun; Du, Yuguo
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2018), 28 (14), 2379-2381CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        With the help of Surflex-Dock calcn., two ritonavir analogs, e.g., I, in which one thiazole unit was replaced by selenazole have been designed and synthesized. The key selenazole structure was constructed from Î²-azido diselenide through a cascade diselenide cleavage/selenocarbonylation/Staudinger redn./aza-Wittig reaction and a following MnO2 oxidn. The accordingly prepd. compds. exhibited good anti-HIV-1 (IIIB) activities comparable to that of the original ritonavir, as well as the pos. SI values.

        El-Desoky, S. I.; Badria, F. A.; Abozeid, M. A.; Kandeel, E. A.; Abdel-Rahman, A. H. Synthesis and antitumor studies of novel benzopyrano-1,2,3-selenadiazole and spiro[benzopyrano]-1,3,4-thiadiazoline derivatives. Med. Chem. Res. 2013, 22, 2105â 2114, Â DOI: 10.1007/s00044-012-0201-0

        114
        Synthesis and antitumor studies of novel benzopyrano-1,2,3-selenadiazole and spiro[benzopyrano]-1,3,4-thiadiazoline derivatives
        El-Desoky, S. I.; Badria, F. A.; Abozeid, M. A.; Kandeel, E. A.; Abdel-Rahman, A. H.
        Medicinal Chemistry Research (2013), 22 (5), 2105-2114CODEN: MCREEB; ISSN:1054-2523. (Birkhaeuser Boston)
        A convenient and efficient synthetic protocol toward new selenadiazole and thiadiazoline derivs. incorporating a benzopyranone moiety from readily available starting materials was described. The reaction of different 2,2-dialkyl and 2,2-spirocycloalkyl dihydrobenzopyranones I [R1 = R2 = Me; R1 = Me, R2 = Et; R1, R2 = (CH2)4, (CH2)5, (CH2)6] with semicarbazide hydrochloride and thiosemicarbazide afforded the corresponding semicarbazones and thiosemicarbazones, resp. Furthermore, cyclization of the semicarbazones via oxidn. using selenium dioxide gave a novel series of chromenoselenadiazoles II. A series of spirobenzopyrano-1,3,4-thiadiazolines III was synthesized by refluxing the thiosemicarbazones in acetic anhydride. The synthesized compds. were tested in vitro against four cancer cell lines namely: MCF-7, VERO, WI-38, and HEPG-2. In vivo studies were also performed using Ehrlich ascites carcinoma for antitumor activity. Interestingly, compds. II (R1 = Me, R2 = Et) and III (R1 = R2 = Me) showed significant antitumor activities and were capable of improving the hematol. parameters as well as increasing the mean survival time of the mice bearing tumors.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Synthesis, spectral- and theoretical study, x-ray analysis, and antiproliferative activity of 4,5-dihydrobenzoferroceno[1,2-d][1,2,3]selenadiazole and its benzo-fused analogue
        Pasinszki, Tibor; Dzsotjan, Daniel; Lajgut, Gyozo Gyorgy; Harmat, Veronika; Bor, Andrea; Zupko, Istvan; Csampai, Antal
        Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2018), 863 (), 70-76CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Synthesis, structure detn., and in vitro antiproliferative effect of 4,5-dihydronaphto[1,2-d][1,2,3]selenadiazole (1) and 4,5-dihydrobenzoferroceno[1,2-d][1,2,3]selenadiazole (2) are presented. The synthesized mols. were characterized by NMR, IR, Raman, mass, and UV spectroscopies. The equil. structures of 1 and 2 were calcd. using the B3LYP/6-31+G* quantum-chem. method, and the solid phase structure of 2 was detd. by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The antiproliferative effect of 1 and 2 was investigated against three tumorous human cell lines. Both compds. were active against cervical HeLa and ovarian A2780 cell lines, and 2 was also active against breast MDA-MB-231 cell growth. The ferrocene deriv. 2 was found to be more effective than its org. analog 1.

        Cui, J.; Pang, L.; Wei, M.; Gan, C.; Liu, D.; Yuan, H.; Huang, Y. Synthesis and antiproliferative activity of 17-[1â²,2â²,3â²]-selenadiazolylpregnenolone compounds. Steroids 2018, 140, 151â 158, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.steroids.2018.10.004

        116
        Synthesis and antiproliferative activity of 17-[1',2',3']-selenadiazolylpregnenolone compounds
        Cui, Jianguo; Pang, Liping; Wei, Meizhen; Gan, Chunfang; Liu, Dandan; Yuan, Haiyan; Huang, Yanmin
        Steroids (2018), 140 (), 151-158CODEN: STEDAM; ISSN:0039-128X. (Elsevier)
        Using pregnenolone as a starting material, some 3-substituted 17-[1',2',3']-selenadiazolylpregnenolone derivs. I (R = COEt, 2-MeC6H4CO, 2-furylcarbonyl, etc.) were synthesized, and their structures were characterized by IR, NMR and HRMS. The in vitro antitumor activity of the compds. was assayed against PC-3,SKOV3,T47D,MCF-7 and HEK293T cell lines. The results show that some compds. display selective antiproliferative activity against PC-3 and SKOV3 cells lines and are almost inactive to normal kidney epithelial cells (HEK293T). The IC50 value are much better than that of abiraterone (pos. control).

      117. 117
        Mhaidat, N. M.; Al-Smadi, M.; Al-Momani, F.; Alzoubi, K. H.; Mansi, I.; Al-Balas, Q. Synthesis, antimicrobial and in vitro antitumor activities of a series of 1,2,3-thiadiazole and 1,2,3-selenadiazole derivatives. Drug Des., Dev. Ther. 2015, 9, 3645â 3652, Â DOI: 10.2147/DDDT.S86054
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        117
        Synthesis, antimicrobial and in vitro antitumor activities of a series of 1,2,3-thiadiazole and 1,2,3-selenadiazole derivatives
        Mhaidat, Nizar M.; Al-Smadi, Mousa; Al-Momani, Fouad; Alzoubi, Karem H.; Mansi, Iman; Al-Balas, Qosay
        Drug Design, Development and Therapy (2015), 9 (), 3645-3652CODEN: DDDTAQ; ISSN:1177-8881. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
        Three derivs. of substituted 1,2,3-thia- or 1,2,3-selenadiazole (4a-c) were prepd. and characterized by different chem. techniques. These compds. were evaluated for their antimicrobial and antitumor activities. Compds. 4a (propenoxide deriv.), 4b (carbaldehyde deriv.), and 4c (benzene deriv.) were active against the yeast-like fungi Candida albicans. Compd. 4a was active against gram-neg. Escherichia coli, and compd. 4c was active against the gram-pos. Staphylococcus aureus. For the antitumor activity, both compds. 4b and 4c were active against all tested tumor cell lines, namely, SW480, HCT116, C32, MV3, HMT3522, and MCF-7. The activity of compd. 4c was greater than that of compd. 4b and more than that of the ref. antitumor 5-flourouracil against the SW480, HCT116, and MCF-7 tumor cell lines. In conclusion, a no. of the prepd. 1,2,3-thia- or 1,2,3-selenadiazole compds. showed promising antifungal, antibacterial, and in vitro antitumor activities. Further investigations are required to explore the mechanism by which active compd. are inducing their cytotoxicity.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        A facile synthesis of carbocycle-fused mono and bis-1,2,3-selenadiazoles and their antimicrobial and antimycobacterial studies
        Chitra, Selvam; Paul, Nidhin; Muthusubramanian, Shanmugam; Manisankar, Paramasivam; Yogeeswari, Perumal; Sriram, Dharmarajan
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 46 (11), 5465-5472CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of mono and bis-1,2,3-selenadiazole derivs. have been synthesized by the oxidative cyclization of mono and bis semicarbazones of 2-(3-oxo-1,3-diarylpropyl)-1-cyclohexanones using selenium(IV) oxide. The newly synthesized compds. were evaluated for their in vitro antimicrobial activity against Escherichia coli (ATCC 25922), Staphylococcus aureus (ATCC 11632) and Candida albicans (ATCC 90028) and in vitro antituberculosis activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis H37Rv (MTB). Among these compds., 1,3-di(4-chlorophenyl)-3-(4,5,6,7-tetrahydro-1,2,3-benzoselenadiazol-4-yl)-1-propanone (I) and 3-(4-chlorophenyl)-1-(4-methylphenyl)-3-(4,5,6,7-tetrahydro-1,2,3-benzoselenadiazol-4-yl)-1-propanone (II) were found to be the most active compds. with MIC of 3.3 and 3.5 Î¼M resp. against MTB.

        Aerobic radical-cascade cycloaddition of isocyanides, selenium and imidamides: facile access to 1,2,4-selenadiazoles under metal-free conditions
        Fang, Yi; Zhu, Zheng-Lin; Xu, Pei; Wang, Shun-Yi; Ji, Shun-Jun
        Green Chemistry (2017), 19 (7), 1613-1618CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A novel and facile metal-free method for the green synthesis of 1,2,4-selenadiazol-5-amine derivs. through the aerobic radical-cascade multi-component reactions of isocyanides, Se powder and imidamides is reported herein. O2 in the air was employed as the green oxidant to achieve the cycloaddn. with the generation of H2O as the sole byproduct. It also features good functional group compatibility and broad substrate scope. This method was successfully applied to the functionalization of biol. active mols.

        The facile and efficient organocatalytic platform for accessing 1,2,4-selenadiazoles and thiadiazoles under aerobic conditions
        Putta, V. P. Rama Kishore; Gujjarappa, Raghuram; Vodnala, Nagaraju; Gupta, Richa; Pujar, Prasad P.; Malakar, Chandi C.
        Tetrahedron Letters (2018), 59 (10), 904-908CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        The organocatalytic approach towards synthesis of rarely explored 1,2,4-selenadiazole and thiadiazole scaffolds have been devised using corresponding carboxamides as substrates. The transformations were realized using two distinct conditions in the presence of catalytic vitamin B3 or thiourea under aerobic conditions. Developed methods overcome the assocd. limitations of previous reported approaches and the desired products were obtained in high yields and selectivity without the formation of toxic side-products.

        He, L. Z.; Ji, S. B.; Lai, H. Q.; Chen, T. F. Selenadiazole derivatives as theranostic agents for simultaneous cancer chemo-/radiotherapy by targeting thioredoxin reductase. J. Mater. Chem. B 2015, 3, 8383â 8393, Â DOI: 10.1039/C5TB01501D
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        Selenadiazole derivatives as theranostic agents for simultaneous cancer chemo-/radiotherapy by targeting thioredoxin reductase
        He, Lizhen; Ji, Shengbin; Lai, Haoqiang; Chen, Tianfeng
        Journal of Materials Chemistry B: Materials for Biology and Medicine (2015), 3 (42), 8383-8393CODEN: JMCBDV; ISSN:2050-7518. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The lack of early and timely diagnosis of tumors and the monitoring of their response to therapeutics have limited the successful cancer treatments. Theranostic agents are expected to realize the dual-purpose of simultaneous diagnosis and therapy for treatments of cancers. In the present study, the authors have examd. the effects of the chem. structure of selenadiazole derivs. (SeDs) on their anticancer efficacy and radio-sensitization against clin. used X-rays. The results showed that the introduction of a nitro group (-NO2) into SeD-3 significantly enhanced the anticancer activity of SeDs. The higher lipophilicity endowed SeD-3 with higher cellular internalization ability, resulting in higher cellular uptake and anticancer efficacy. Specifically, the capacity of autofluorescence allowed the use of SeD-3 as a promising theranostic agent to directly monitor the cellular uptake, localization and biodistribution in vitro and in vivo. Interestingly, SeD-3 also significantly enhanced the sensitivity of HeLa cervical cells to x-ray-induced apoptosis by targeting the inhibition of TrxR and promoting intracellular ROS overprodn., which activated the downstream ROS-mediated signaling pathways to regulate cell apoptosis. Furthermore, SeD-3 exhibited satisfactory in vivo antitumor efficacy through the inhibition of tumor proliferation and induction of tumor cell apoptosis, and showed no toxicity to the main organs. Moreover, from the results of hematol. anal., the authors found that not only inhibiting the tumor growth, treatment of SeD-3 also alleviated the damage of liver, kidney and heart function of nude mice induced by HeLa xenografts. Taken together, this study demonstrates that SeDs could be further developed as an effective and safe theranostic agent for simultaneous cancer chemo-/radiotherapy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsV2jt7fN&md5=b95cb48e9e6f658410f2d847e5d22df6

        Rational Design of Cancer-Targeted Benzoselenadiazole by RGD Peptide Functionalization for Cancer Theranostics
        Yang, Liye; Li, Wenying; Huang, Yanyu; Zhou, Yangliang; Chen, Tianfeng
        Macromolecular Rapid Communications (2015), 36 (17), 1559-1565CODEN: MRCOE3; ISSN:1022-1336. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A cancer-targeted conjugate of the selenadiazole deriv. BSeC (benzo[1,2,5] selenadiazole-5-carboxylic acid) with RGD peptide as targeting mol. and PEI (polyethylenimine) as a linker is rationally designed and synthesized in the present study. The results show that RGD-PEI-BSeC forms nanoparticles in aq. soln. with a core-shell nanostructure and high stability under physiol. conditions. This rational design effectively enhances the selective cellular uptake and cellular retention of BSeC in human glioma cells, and increases its selectivity between cancer and normal cells. The nanoparticles enter the cells through receptor-mediated endocytosis via clathrin-mediated and nystatin-dependent lipid raft-mediated pathways. Internalized nanoparticles trigger glioma cell apoptosis by activation of ROS-mediated p53 phosphorylation. Therefore, this study provides a strategy for the rational design of selenium-contg. cancer-targeted theranostics.

        Tailored mesoporous silica nanosystem with enhanced permeability of the blood-brain barrier to antagonize glioblastoma
        You, Yuanyuan; Yang, Liye; He, Lizhen; Chen, Tianfeng
        Journal of Materials Chemistry B: Materials for Biology and Medicine (2016), 4 (36), 5980-5990CODEN: JMCBDV; ISSN:2050-7518. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Cancer-targeted drug delivery systems with permeability of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) have become of great interest for the rational design of high-efficiency anticancer agents. Herein, a tailored mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) nanosystem modified by RGD (arginine-glycine-aspartate) peptide was designed and tested for use as a carrier of anticancer agents, by using a novel org. selenium compd. BSeC as a model mol. As expected, the nanosystem ([emailÂ protected]) could effectively enhance the BBB permeability and the cellular uptake of BSeC in tumor cells. The internalized [emailÂ protected] triggered mitochondrial dysfunction and intracellular ROS overprodn., which subsequently activated the p53 and MAPKs pathways. Moreover, the nanosystem could inhibit the U87 tumor spheroids growth, significantly prolong the blood circulation time of the loaded drug in vivo and effectively reduce its in vivo toxicity. Taken together, this study provides a strategy for the rational design of a tailored nanomedicine with enhanced BBB permeability to treat human brain glioma.

        Deng, S. L.; Zeng, D. L.; Luo, Y.; Zhao, J. F.; Li, X. L.; Zhao, Z. N.; Chen, T. F. Enhancement of cell uptake and antitumor activity of selenadiazole derivatives through interaction and delivery by serum albumin. RSC Adv. 2017, 7, 16721â 16729, Â DOI: 10.1039/C6RA28801D
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        124
        Enhancement of cell uptake and antitumor activity of selenadiazole derivatives through interaction and delivery by serum albumin
        Deng, Shulin; Zeng, Delong; Luo, Yi; Zhao, Jianfu; Li, Xiaoling; Zhao, Zhennan; Chen, Tianfeng
        RSC Advances (2017), 7 (27), 16721-16729CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Serum albumin is an important carrier in the transport of endogenous and exogenous substances across cell membranes. Small mol. drugs could bind to serum albumin to various extents after i.v. injection, which may affect the bioavailability, metab., pharmacol. and toxicol. potency. Org. selenium (Se) compds. exhibit favorable biocompatibility and low toxicity that attracts increased attention from researchers. Herein, a series of selenadiazole derivs. (4a-e) have been synthesized and their cytotoxicity towards various kinds of cells were evaluated. The results suggested that iso-Pr benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole-5-carboxylate (4d) exhibited a broad inhibition spectrum on the proliferation of tested cancer cells, with a relatively higher anticancer activity than other derivs. We found that the differences in their anticancer activities were attributed to the various binding abilities of the Se compds. toward BSA. The bimol. quenching const. (Kq), apparent quenching const. (KSV), effective binding const. (KA) and binding site no. (n) were obtained through fluorescence quenching calcns., which indicated that all compds. could efficiently bind to BSA mols. and the fluorescence quenching mechanism was mainly a static quenching procedure. Moreover, serum albumin was found to interact with selenadiazole derivs. (4a-e), thus promoting the cellular uptake and anticancer activity of the Se compds. Taken together, this study demonstrated that the synthetic selenadiazole derivs. exhibited high anticancer activity and cellular uptake through delivery by human serum.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlKmsbo%253D&md5=1fa5f893acc43c375fcfacec0be292e4

        Ruberte, A. C.; Plano, D.; Encio, I.; Aydillo, C.; Sharma, A. K.; Sanmartin, C. Novel selenadiazole derivatives as selective antitumor and radical scavenging agents. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 157, 14â 27, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2018.07.063
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        Novel selenadiazole derivatives as selective antitumor and radical scavenging agents
        Ruberte, Ana Carolina; Plano, Daniel; Encio, Ignacio; Aydillo, Carlos; Sharma, Arun K.; Sanmartin, Carmen
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 157 (), 14-27CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Twenty-seven novel benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole-5-carboxylic acid (BSCA) derivs. I [R = Ph, 2-thiazolyl, 4-MeC6H4, etc.; n = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4] were designed and synthesized. Anti-proliferative activity of these structures was tested in vitro against a panel of five human cancer cell lines, including prostate (PC-3), colon (HT-29), leukemia (CCRF-CEM), lung (HTB-54) and breast (MCF-7). Four compds. I [R = 4-MeOC6H4, 4-MeSC6H4, 4-MeSeC6H4, 2-benzothiazolyl; n = 0] showed potent inhibitory activity with GI50 values below 10Î¼M in at least one of the cancer cell lines. The selectivity of these compds. was further examd. in two non-malignant cell lines derived from breast (184B5) and lung (BEAS-2B). Compd. I [R = 4-MeSeC6H4; n = 0] exhibited promising anti-proliferative activity (GI50=3.7Î¼M) in MCF-7cells, together with high selectivity index (SI>27.1). The induction of cell death by compd. I [R = 4-MeSeC6H4; n = 0] was independent of the apoptotic process and it did not affect cell cycle progression either. Likewise, radical scavenging properties of the new selenadiazole derivs. I were confirmed by testing their ability to scavenge DPPH radicals. Four compds. I [R = Ph, 4-MeC6H4, 4-HSC6H4, 4-HSeC6H4; n = 0] showed potent radical scavenging activity, compd. I [R = 4-HSC6H4; n = 0] being the most effective. Overall, while compd. I [R = 4-MeSeC6H4; n = 0] was identified as the most cell growth inhibitory agent and selectively toxic to cancer cells, compd. I [R = 4-HSC6H4; n = 0] proved to be the most potent antioxidant among the selenadiazole derivs. synthesized. This series of compds. I could served as an excellent scaffold to achieve new and potent antioxidant compds. useful for several diseases, i.e. cancer, neurodegenerative, heart diseases and leishmaniasis, considering the high radical scavenging activity and low toxicity showed by most of the compds.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsVWqsLzK&md5=11772165f38a8dc0be2a499a7842ab72

        Activity enhancement of selective antitumoral selenodiazoles formulated with poloxamine micelles
        Uriz, Amaia; Sanmartin, Carmen; Plano, Daniel; de Melo Barbosa, Raquel; Dreiss, Cecile A.; Gonzalez-Gaitano, Gustavo
        Colloids and Surfaces, B: Biointerfaces (2018), 170 (), 463-469CODEN: CSBBEQ; ISSN:0927-7765. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Selenium (Se) incorporated into org. frameworks has demonstrated anticancer activity against several cancer types. One of the drawbacks of most of these constructs is their poor soly. and bioavailability, which can be overcome with the use of suitable nanocarriers. We have synthesized a series of 5-substituted amide selenodiazoles, based on the parent structure of ebselen, an organoselenium drug with proven cytoprotective activity, and solubilized them in polymeric micelles of poloxamines, poly(ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide) X-shaped tetrablock-copolymers. Scattering methods (SANS and DLS) were employed to characterize the micellar nanocarriers. MTT biol. evaluation highlights the selectivity of the Se-compds. towards cancer cells, with MCF-7 standing as the most responsive line. The alkylation of the heterocycle with a 12-carbon hydrophobic tail displays the highest activity, showing a 100-fold increase with respect to ebselen. This compd. also exhibits the greatest increase in soly. in poloxamine micelles, overall resulting in a one-fold increase in activity with respect to the non-formulated form, making it a hit compd. for further optimization.

        Microwave-Assisted Syntheses of Benzimidazole-Containing Selenadiazole Derivatives That Induce Cell-Cycle Arrest and Apoptosis in Human Breast Cancer Cells by Activation of the ROS/AKT Pathway
        Liang, Yuanwei; Zhou, Yangliang; Deng, Shulin; Chen, Tianfeng
        ChemMedChem (2016), 11 (20), 2339-2346CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The use of selenium-contg. heterocyclic compds. as potent cancer chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic agents has been well documented by a large no. of clin. studies. In this study we developed a new approach to synthesize four benzimidazole-contg. selenadiazole derivs. (BSeDs). The method uses a combination of peptide coupling reagents and microwave irradn. This strategy features milder reaction conditions, higher yields, and shorter reaction times. The synthetic BSeDs were identified as potent antiproliferative agents against the human MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell lines. Compds. 1 b (5-(6-methyl-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole), 1 c (5-(6-chloro-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole), and 1 d (5-(6-bromo-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-2-yl)benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazole) were found to show greater cytotoxicity against the triple-neg. breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 than MCF-7, and to exhibit dose-dependent inhibition of cell migration, in which a significant decrease in the zone of cell monolayer wound closure was obsd. relative to untreated controls. Our results demonstrate that BSeDs can cause cell-cycle arrest and apoptosis in MDA-MB-231 cells by inducing DNA damage, inhibiting protein kinase B (AKT), and activating mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) family members through the overprodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Taken together, the results of this study provide a facile microwave-assisted strategy for the synthesis of selenium-contg. org. compds. that exhibit a high level of anticancer efficacy.

        A novel selenadiazole derivative induces apoptosis in human glioma cells by dephosphorylation of AKT
        Zhang, Yikai; Zheng, Shanyuan; Ngai, Sai-Ming; Zheng, Wenjie; Li, Jinying; Chen, Tianfeng; Zhong, Xueyun
        Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin (2014), 62 (10), 994-999CODEN: CPBTAL; ISSN:0009-2363. (Pharmaceutical Society of Japan)
        Selenadiazole derivs. are synthetic organoselenium compds. with improved anticancer activity and greater selectivity than inorg. selenium. In this study, 4-(benzo[c][1,2,5]selenadiazol-6-yl)-benzene-1,2-diamine (BSBD) was shown to induce time- and dose-dependent apoptosis in SWO-38 human glioma cells by accumulation of a sub-G1 cell population, DNA fragmentation, nuclear condensation, caspase activation and poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) cleavage. Further mechanistic investigation showed that BSBD treatment induced dephosphorylation of AKT and DNA damage-mediated activation of p53, leading to extensive apoptosis through the mitochondrial pathway. Our findings suggest that BSBD represents a potential human glioma therapeutic.

        Xie, Q.; Zhou, Y.; Lan, G.; Yang, L.; Zheng, W.; Liang, Y.; Chen, T. Sensitization of cancer cells to radiation by selenadiazole derivatives by regulation of ROS-mediated DNA damage and ERK and AKT pathways. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2014, 449, 88â 93, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.bbrc.2014.04.151
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        129
        Sensitization of cancer cells to radiation by selenadiazole derivatives by regulation of ROS-mediated DNA damage and ERK and AKT pathways
        Xie, Qiang; Zhou, Yangliang; Lan, Guoqiang; Yang, Liye; Zheng, Wenjie; Liang, Yuanwei; Chen, Tianfeng
        Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications (2014), 449 (1), 88-93CODEN: BBRCA9; ISSN:0006-291X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        X-ray-based radiotherapy represents one of the most effective ways in treating human cancers. However, radioresistance and side effect remain as the most challenging issue. This study describes the design and application of novel selenadiazole derivs. as radiotherapy sensitizers to enhance X-ray-induced inhibitory effects on A375 human melanoma and Hela human cervical carcinoma cells. The results showed that, pretreatment of the cells with selenadiazole derivs. dramatically enhance X-ray-induced growth inhibition and colony formation. Flow cytometry anal. indicates that the sensitization by selenadiazole derivs. was mainly caused by induction of G2/M cell cycle arrest. Results of Western blotting demonstrated that the combined treatment-induced A375 cells growth inhibition was achieved by triggering reactive oxygen species-mediated DNA damage involving inactivation of AKT and MAPKs. Further investigation revealed that selenadiazole deriv. in combination with X-ray could synergistically inhibit the activity of thioredoxin reductase-1 in A375 cells. Taken together, these results suggest that selenadiazole derivs. can act as novel radiosensitizer with potential application in combating human cancers.
